Praefatio.	Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	After I have completed to you, O sons, this book, which is the last of science in medicine with its supplement, and having finished it with its expositions and declarations, it has seemed right to me that I complete it for you with this treatise, which is a part of surgery, namely, with the hand.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	Since operation with the hand is laid down in our region and in our time exclusively: until perhaps knowledge of it has perished, and its trail has been lost: and there remain of it, only a few descriptions in ancient books, which hands have changed: and error and uncertainty occurred to them, until their intentions were closed, and his intention was prolonged. It seemed right to me that I should clarify it with this arrangement of this treatise according to two things, that is, by exposition and declaration, and abbreviation: and that I bring it closer with the forms of tools Cautery, and other instruments of work: for it is necessary to add a declaration, and to distinguish it, because there remains.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	The reason why there is no good craftsman of this hand in our time: for the art of medicine is long, and it is necessary that the author of it should exercise himself before it in the science of anatomy, which Galen narrated, until he knows the functions of the limbs, and their forms, and their connection, and separation, and has knowledge of the bones, and nerves, and ligaments, and the number of them, and their course, and their pulsations, and quiet, and places of exit:
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	And because of that Hippocrates said, since a name is much with a name, and little with an operation, especially in the art of the hand.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	We have already said about it at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Since he who is not knowing that we have said about anatomy will fall into error, to which human beings are subject: as I saw many of them form about this science, and boast themselves of it without knowledge, and without experiment.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	That is because I saw a doctor cut an aposteme scar on the neck of a woman, and he struck some arteries in her neck. Why did the blood flow from the woman's body until she died between his hands?
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	And I saw another doctor who assumed that he would extract a large stone from the bladder of a man who had been suffering for a long time, and the stone was big.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	So he approached him and removed it with a twig.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	Why did the man die on the third day?
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	And I had already been called to extract it; and I saw from the great size of the stone and the care of the nurse that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	And I saw another doctor who was taking a fee from the Duke of our land for medicine; and there happened to be a black eunuch near him, who broke his thigh bone near the heel: and the doctor continued in his ignorance, and he bound the fracture tightly with strong threads, and did not leave the wound's discharge undischarged.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	Then he discharged him according to his desires.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	Then he discharged him after a few days, and he ordered that the ligatures not be removed: and so he stood until his leg and foot were withered away, and came to destruction.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	So I was called up to him; and I set out to loosen the ligatures; and the result was calmness, and he was free of his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	However, the corruption had already become established in the member; and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	Then the corruption stopped walking in the member until it perished.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	And I saw another doctor who pierced an aposteme cancerosa; and it was ulcered after a few days until the maliciousness of it increased with his lord.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	That is because when it is cancer pure from melancholic humor, then one should not approach it at all with iron unless it sits in a member that can bear it so that the whole of it may be cut off.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	And for this reason, my sons, you need to know that surgery is divided into two parts: one in which health is associated with the operation and another in which there is danger in many dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	And I have already aroused it in all places of this book, where the operation comes, in which there is fear and dread.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	Why do you need to be afraid of that, and to diminish it: so that the blind may not get accustomed to speaking and being dishonorable.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	Therefore take a measure with care and protection, and bring the sick among you with ease and firmness, and use a better way that leads to grace by the mercy of God for salvation and a worthy succession: and remove the terrible diseases from among you, which make you afraid, so that hesitation may come upon you in your faith and your confidence.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	For there remains more for our glory, and higher in the world, and lastly to the quantities of us.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	For Galenus has already said in some of his advice.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	Do not cure a disease with medicine: do not call yourself a doctor.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	I have already divided this treatise into three chapters.
Capitulum primum.	Chapter one.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	Chapter one. On cauterizing with fire, and on cauterizing with sharp medicine, on the form of instruments, and on tools for cauterizing: and on everything necessary for the operation.
Capitulum secundum.	Chapter two.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	Chapter two. On cutting and piercing, phlebotomy and tourniquets, and wounds: and on extracting arrows, and similar things: and all the chapter, divided into forms of instruments.
Capitulum tertium.	Chapter three.On bandaging, and on plasters, and on poult
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	On restoration, and dislocation, and cure of twist, and similar things: the whole chapter, divided from the head to the feet, and in forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	Glory be to God only.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	The Book of Surgery of Albucasis.
Pars I.	Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	Regarding the application of cautery and the types of skin lesions that are suitable for it, and at what time of day, and whether with iron or gold.
Caput I.	Head I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	But before I speak about the qualities of the cautery and the contraindications, it is necessary to describe the types of skin lesions that are suitable for it.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	I therefore say that the speech about the quality of cautery and its contraindications is a long, subtle, scientific, and secret speech.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	A multitude of wise men also spoke in it, and they disagreed with each other; but for me, a little of their speech is enough, fearing extension.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	I say that cautery is suitable for all types of skin, whether with or without substance; excepting two types of skin, which are warm and dry without substance, and dry and cold without substance.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	But in the case of warm and dry skin with substance, they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	Some said that cautery is suitable for such skin.
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	But others said the opposite, namely that cautery is not suitable for an illness that is both hot and dry, because fire's nature is hot, and it does not suit to heal a hot and dry disease with hot and dry means.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	And he who says the opposite said this: "But with cautery, an illness that is hot and dry can be cured in any part of the body, because when you compare the human body to the fire's moisture, you will find that the human body is colder.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	And I myself say through my own experience: because through experiment I have often found this to be true.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	But it is not necessary to add anything to that, unless one has already tested and exercised in the exercise of the last chapter on cautery, and has recognized the diversity of human skin types, and the nature of illnesses within them, and the causes of those illnesses, and the accidents associated with them, and the time period of their occurrence.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	Do not fear either to use the ointments left over: and above all when you are dealing with patients who are cold and wet.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	For all doctors have come together on them: and they have not disagreed in the treatment with the use of ointment.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	And know, sons, that the secret of cure by cautery with fire, and its goodness above cautery with medicine burned together, is because fire is simple, whose action does not reach, unless to the limb that is cauterized: and it does not hurt another member joined with it, except with little harm.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	But the action of medicine that is burned comes to that which is prolonged from limbs: and perhaps it causes a difficult cure to heal, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	But fire, because of its slightness and goodness of its substance, does not do that, unless it runs short.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	But this has already become known to us by experimentation, because of the length of use and study with art, and stability on the truth of things: and for this reason I excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	And if it is not allowed, because it is not fitting for my book, I would take away from you the secret hidden thing of fire, and the quality of its action in bodies by its expulsion, which expels diseases with philosophical speech that is demonstrated by the minds of your scholars, which has been acquired.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	And know, sons, that they disagree in time when cauterization is to be made, and set a better time for the wound.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	And I say that cauterization is to be made at all times: because the harm that happens by time is hidden in the treatment, which is drawn with cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	And especially if cauterization is because of the pains from necessary pains, firm, festivals, which do not tolerate tardiness: because they are afraid of them, that evil may happen, which is greater than a little harm that does not pass by time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let not the son of that woman fall in the minds of you all, if he does not take care, unless the people and those who are dull-witted, namely that it is not always a return to health for him when his illness which is cured by cauterization: and they put it down as a consequence, and it is not like what they think; therefore because cauterization is not, except in the place of medicine, which changes the complexion and dries up the humidities that are the causes, why these pains occur.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	But cauterization is superfluous on medicine by its velocity of health, and the merit of its operation, and the severity of its lordship: and it is possible that he returns to health at some time of time according to the complexion of sickness, and the location of his illness, and the merit of it; and that he was prepared in his body from the accumulation of superfluity in him: and that it has come to itself in acquisition from food, and similar things from causes, unless there is an illness, in which cauterization is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	But a slight illness in a small member is superfluous of the excess of moisture, like cauterization of a tooth, for pain, and similar to it; it is possible that he does not return to health in him: that pain.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	But this happens in few things.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	But the words of the people again, that cauterization is the last medicine, are right words: not to what they mean in it: for they believe that there is no cure which confers with medicine, and neither with any other after the occasion of cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	But the thing is opposite to what they say, and the intention, that cauterization is the last medicine, is not, except when we administer ways of cure in some illnesses, and they do not confer with medicines: then we administer at the end of things cauterization, and it confers; then from this it falls, that cauterization is the last medicine, not according to what they understand the people and many dull-witted doctors.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	Yet the old people said that it is better to apply a burn with gold than with iron; and they did not say this except because of the equality of the gold and the poverty of its substance; and they said that there is no place for a burn. But this is not true, for I have tested this and found that it does not work in some bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	And the cautery with itself is good, and better than that with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	But when you apply the fire cautery in the fire from gold, it does not manifest to you, when you set it on fire according to the quantity that you want, because of the redness of gold: and when it comes to its own heat, and if you add ignition to it, it melts in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	Why does the craftsman fall from that one to work: and because of that it is more expedient and closer for us to make a cautery with iron, out of straightness to the work.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	And I too have already arranged this Chapter on the cautery, according to chapters; and I have arranged it from the head down to the feet; that the seeker may find what he wants out of it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	On the mode of applying the cautery to the crown of the mouth.
Caput II.	Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	Here let the cauterization be to the lordship of moisture and coldness on the brain; which two things are the cause of the salt, and of the multitude of flow of humors out of the head to the eyes and ears, and of the multiplicity of sleep, and of the pain of teeth, and of the pain of throat: and universally all sickness that happens from coldness, such as paralysis, and salt, and convulsions, and fainting fits, and those like them from those illnesses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	The method of cauterization is so that you may instruct the sick person: to wash his head with soluable medicine three times a night, or four times, according as the strength of the patient and his age and custom require it.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	Then command him to wash his head with cold water.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	Then make him sit between your hands so that he has already placed his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	Then place the root of your hand over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	So whichever finger of your middle hand touches the place where the nose joins the face, mark it with a burn.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	Then light a cautery with olive oil: whose this is the form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	Then place the person himself on the marked spot with the burn, so that your hand constricts him little by little, and you release him.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	Then quickly release your hand, and look at the spot.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	If you see already a quantity of hair falling out from the bone, or a quantity of herbs, then quickly release your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	And if not, repeat the ironing of the same with another one when it is frigidized: until you see the bones that I told you.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then take some salt, and dissolve it in water, and steep it in the liquid, and place it on the spot: and release him for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	Then place over the soaked cloth in butter, and release him on the spot until the fire scar is destroyed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	Then care for that with the four-part ointment, until it is healed.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	They have already said that since the wound remains open for so long, it emits pus: why is this better and more beneficial.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	And some of them said, Let the skin be cauterized all the way down to the bone: and hold the cautery, until a certain thickness of bone is burned.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	Then burn after that what is burnt out from the bone, then treat with ointment.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	It is said that when the caesarian section is performed to the end, until it impresses the impression on the mouth for a long time, so that the mouth falls down, which is like the shape of kirat: or the instrument that women put in the infusion of letters, and they estimate that from this place the vapours of the head are exhaled, and the opened wound is closed at the right time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	Then let the wound be treated until it has healed.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	But these two kinds of cautery do not seem to me to exist at all unless they are used by some people out of fear the second time.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	And let it be removed; for me, it is better to remove it when the patient is healthy.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	For the head weakens from the continence of its own nature: as we have witnessed in the other members: and especially when the head is weak from sickness; and the species of cautery first are more salutary and better for me, and I use them: therefore let us perform it when healthy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	The way of cauterizing the head when it is in pain throughout the whole head.
Caput III.	Head 3.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	When chronic pain occurs throughout the whole head: and is prolonged in an invalid, and uses soap, and baths, and poultices, and oils, and applications.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	And above all if it has already been cauterized with one kind of cautery which we have described, and does not give any benefit from it: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	For if the head is weak from the strength of nature, and is not weak, and there is a cold feeling: then cauterize with another kind of cautery slightly under it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	Then cauterize it itself on all the corners of the head with its own cautery, and let the skin not be disturbed, and a quantity be taken from the bone which we have described.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	And let it be cauterized with one kind of cautery in the back of the head in the place which is called the air: and this is a place where the wind blows: and wash your hair in this way, and do not discover the mouth.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	This is critical: he became sick because of that painful symptom, and very much relieved from the pain of all other headaches.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	And I will say this about the cautery in its place: and it is necessary that there be a cautery to cauterize the horns of the head, and the back of the skull be slightly cauterized, where the middle of the head is cauterized.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is the shape of it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	**On the way to cauterizing with respect to headaches, both when medicine is applied as well as when iron is used.**
Caput IIII.	**Chapter IV. On the treatment of headache.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	**When there is pain on one side of the head and soda, or the pain extends as far as the eye, and the head is cleansed with cleaning medicines, and the rest of the treatment is administered, which I have described in the divisions of illnesses, and does not provide all of this: then cauterization in it is according to two methods: either cauterization while burning medicine: or with iron.**
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	**But when cauterization is made while burning medicine, it is, as you take one tooth of the other, and scrape it, and cut off its extremities from both sides.**
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	**Then cut the place of pain at a time with the phlebotomator on one side, until it becomes in it a place under the skin, where the bone is captured.**
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	**Then insert it into that place under the skin, until it is concealed:** then bind it with a constrictive string that descends, and let go of it in quantity of fifteen hours then dissolve it, and remove the other, and let it be for two days, or three: then put a cloth over it soaked in butter, until that place makes pus: then care for the pus with ointment until it heals.**
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	**And if you want to make that place with some medicines that burn, which I have written in the twelfth chapter of The Medications That Burn.**
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	**But cauterization with iron is according to this method:**
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	The fire cautery, whose form is this.
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	And it is called the "clavis" (key): because the form of his head is like the form of a key, in which there is something like a knot, and in the middle of it there is a small eminence.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	Then put the iron itself on the spot, and hold your hand: and you shall turn the iron slowly with speed: and let the quantity that is burned from the thickness of the skin be like its half.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And draw your hand away, so that the artery which is below does not burn, and do not let the blood flow.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	Then dip the cloth in salt water and place it on the spot, and leave it for three days: then dip the cloth with butter: afterwards treat it with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	And if you want, cauterize this headache with the second cautery of the blade.
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	And do not cut the artery in this headache, but cut it with your own hand.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	The mode of cauterizing in a headaches.
Caput V.	Head.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	When you cure a headache, with the fact that we have said before in the preceding cure, and which we have said in the division of diseases, and does not be cured: and you shall see from sickness, that it is not enough to him what we have said from the first cautery with medicine, or with cautery with fire, then it is necessary that you should put the fire cautery with a blade, until the white turns after putting the signs on the spot of pain with a line, whose length is half a finger, or nearly so: and set your hand by the edge, and squeeze it until you touch the artery, and reach it up to the mouth.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	However, you must, in order to cauterize the jaw bone, which moves when it grinds, so that it does not burn on the side, or nerve which moves it, from which comes a spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	And this over the protection and care against the flow of blood from the artery, which has been cut off.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	For in the dissection there is fear, and above all things he who does not know that which he does, and is not studious nor expert: and he ceases the operation with him at first.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	And I come with remembrance of the management of the flow of blood from an artery in a second way, and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	That if you see from illness that this cautery is not sufficient to him, and you see the body enduring cautery in the middle of the head, as we have narrated, take care of the wound, until it is healed.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	And if you want to, administer Cautery, which we have said in the chapter of the extraction of the artery with cautery having two scissor-like tools.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	For cauterization is better and gives more benefit in this way.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	Regarding the method of cauterizing for ear pain.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	When it happens in the ear pain from cold, and is cured with solutions, and remaining cure as we have said in the division, and does not remove the pain, then the fire cautery: and that is what is called a dot, whose shape is this.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	Then the dots with it after its burning in the circumference of the whole ear, like a re-growth: or in the circumference of either one, if at the same time pain is in both.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	And make it long with cautery from the root of the ear slightly, after you have marked places with wax: and let be the amount of cautery ten points in all the ear, and almost those same.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	Then take care of the place, until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	Regarding the method of cauterizing for torture:
Caput VII.	Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	The torture which is cured with cautery, is not except from things that happen from the phlegm, according to what we have said in divisions of illnesses.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	And he abstained from cauterizing the wound, which occurred because of dehydration and muscle spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	When you treat this wound of torture with hervium, and headpurifications, and gargarisms, and your cure does not help, then you should cauterize the sick with three cauterizations: one at the root of the ear, and a second little below its place, and a third at the junction of the two lips.
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	And put your cautery on the opposite side of the weak part.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	For softening does not occur unless in the part that appears healthy.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	And the form of the cautery is so that it cauterizes itself directly at the extreme tip of the upper ear next to the corner of the head a little bit: and with another one in time: whose length is according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	And place your hand with the cautery, until a quantity of half the thickness of the skin is burned.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	And this is the form of the cautery, and its kind is from a scalpel, whose form is as follows: verily it is not thinner than you see: and it is necessary that the scalpel be a little bit longer than that.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with what preceded it: until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	The way of cauterizing in ancient apoplexia.
Caput VIII.	Head 8.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	WHEN a person has an ancient apoplexia, and you treat it with what we have said, and your cure does not help, and the sick person is without fever, then cauterize him with four cauterizations all over his head, and with a middle-head cautery, as we have said, and a cautery in the back of the head according to what preceded it: and the mode of the cautery is according to what preceded it.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	Also cauterize with the cautery above the mouth of the stomach: and this is the last.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then care for it with what preceded it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	To cauterize in a defect.
Caput IX.	Chapter IX. On cauterization in a wound.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	It is necessary that, in the first place, the patient be put into the great hypolepidion and the pills which heal the brain be given him.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	Then cut off his whole head and place it on his occipital with a wax plaque described in the book of plaques: and sometimes put some on him.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	This is the method of cauterization: and do it according to the order which I have said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	But if he is healed by it, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	But if he does not [recover]: then do three cauterizations on the posterior part of his head, which descend from the upper part of the head down to the lower part of the eye: and put between every cauterization a thickness of finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	Then take care of the cauterizations, with regard to what preceded them.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	But if you wish to add anything, and the patient is able to endure it: then do a cauterization in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	If you wish to add: then cauterize him over two horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	Then take care of the patient until he is healed: and let the cauterization be oiled according to the form which has been said before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	The way to cauterize in paralysis and мягкотелость.
Caput X.	Chapter X. On cauterization in paralysis and softness.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	It is necessary that you proceed with the head in the process of healing with the herbs, and with regard to what I have said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	Then cut off the head and give it to the nurse: then cauterize him with a middle head cauterization, and a cauterization over each horn of the head, and three over the posterior part of his head, and two over the spine of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	But if the disease of the body is due to softness, and the patient is able to endure it, and the disease is strong: then cauterize him with four cauterizations over the spine of the back, and the last one with a cauterization while burning away much of his skin, and wipe away his hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	Then care for him, until he is healed; and thus cauterize with olive oil.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	§ On the mode of cauterization in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	Head X.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	 § Do not cauterize epilepsy unless it is in one who has a feverish condition.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	Then let the patient's brain ulcers be cured first with honey, and all the other treatment as we have said in the division: when the patient is very ill or tolerates medicinal treatments badly.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	If, however, he is a boy who does not tolerate medicinal treatments, then let him have a gargle and brain-cleansing chewing-gums, before many days of improvement in his diet.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	Then wash his head; afterwards cauterize him with one cautery in the middle of his head, according to the order given above: and with another cautery at the back of his head, and on all the horns of his head.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	If, however, he is a strong man and tolerant, then cauterize him with the cauteries I have described in those who are paralyzed, and in the softening of the body over the vertebrae of the neck, and the spine at the back: and let the cautery be olive oil according to the mode that has been described.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	But if the boy is ill, then place a fine cautery, according to this mode:
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	§ On the mode of cauterization in melancholy.
Caput XII.	Head XII.Non autem cauterizatur, n
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	 § But do not cauterize when the cause of melancholy is corrupt humors and thick phlegm; then cauterize him with the cauteries I have described in those who are paralyzed.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	And if the cause of melancholy is a surplusive closure to melancholy, and the body is damp, then give him a drink that will cleanse his brain, according to what has been said in the division: afterwards wash his head, and then make a wisp of linen into a loop, and twist it round like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	Then place it in the middle of the head; and the patient should sit with his back held straight from all sides.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	Then present the ointment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	And is worthy of being applied with old butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	And heat the ointment over a moderate fire, as much as a finger can tolerate when it is dipped into the ointment.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	Then wash the patient's head in the center with a circle, and let him sit until he is chilled.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	Perform this treatment on the sick person once a week, along with the rest of his treatment, until he recovers.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	Or if you wish, you can burn small spots on the patient's skin with a bit of caustic: however, hold it so that the burn is not too deep.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	This kind of burning moisten the brain with moisture.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	Then place a cloth soaked in butter, or chicken fat, on top of the ointment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	This way, the patient' can look up at the sky while being cauterized.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	When you notice the signs that I mentioned in the division, then begin to drink from the cup and wash the sick person's head, so that it may be cleansed.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	And keep the patient away from all moisture, and let him sit in a bath, on a fast for several days.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	Then tell him to comb his hair, and cauterize the patient' head in the center of his hair.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	Then cauterize the patient' two temples with two burns, if the water is going into both eyes at the same time: or from one side, if the water is entering just one eye: and cut off all the hair with the cautery: and let the cautery be long in width between the temples: and stop any bleeding of blood.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	If you see anything of that, then cut it off right away with whatever medicine is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and their cutting, and taking care to stop any bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	And when cauterization is done on the skin, between two bones, with two fire-brands at the end.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	De modo cauterizandi in lacrymibus antiquis.
Caput XIIII.	CHAPTER XXII.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	When the lachrymae (tears) of the eyes are ancient and frequent and are upon the skin, and the arteries which are manifest upon the outside of the head: it is known that this is from cold and phlegmatic humors; then cauterize with fire the same way as I have spoken at the beginning of the water descending, with fire in the middle of the head, and two fire-brands upon two temples, and two fire-brands in the skin between two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	And if there is a need for an addition, then cauterize it on both sides of the eye, at the end of the brow with a small fire-brand.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	De modo cauterizandi in foeto nasae.
Caput XV.	CHAPTER XV.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	When you treat this, as we have said in the division, and the medicine is not effective: then approach it, and give three nights of milk with honey: afterwards shave its head, and cauterize it with middle cautery, with olive oil cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	Then cauterize it with two cauteries, one above each eyebrow, a little below the hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	And guard against the artery, lest you strike it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	And this is the form of cautery with claws.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	The mode of cauterizing in softening the eyelids.
Caput XVI.	Head 16.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	When the eyelid of the eye is softened by sickness or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, with this lunar cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	And if there is a lump, cauterize it above the two eyelids with two cauteries throughout: and let them be extended from both sides: and let the length of each cautery be according to the length of the lid: and do not put your hand on the cautery at all, except for the third eyelid.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	And this is the form of cautery according to this mode of lunar cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	The mode of cauterizing the eyelid when the hair are directed inward and stinging the eye.
Caput XVII.	Head 17.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	The cautery is in two ways, either with fire: or the cautery with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	In the cautery, however, with fire, direct the patient away from it, so that he does not shed his hair, if he is of those who clean them, until they have grown out and are even.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	But if it stings him near its origin: then squeeze the eyes with vitriolosy, so that they do not move, until they have healed.
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	When they have healed and are even, then put the head in your lap: and then mark the eyelids of his eyes with encaustic, a mark that is according to the shape of the leaf of myrrh: and let the beginning of the mark be near the hair.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	Then put on the wound, either soaked in albumen or in the mucus of the ox's eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then put on fire the cautery whose form is this one.
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	Then cauterize on the figure, which you have marked slowly on many wounds, until it is burned through the skin's surface, which appears like a laurel leaf, all by itself.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	And the sign of your work's health is: if you squeeze the eyelids of the eye and shave the hair near the eye's punctum.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	So bless your hand then: and release him after three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	Then put on the wound, with butter, until the scar is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for the wound with ointment, until it heals.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	That if any hair should fall out after an hour, and the eyelid becomes soft: then once again apply the cautery to that place, as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	But if the hair is on the lower side: then cauterize that, until it moves to its own place: and make sure that the eye' hair does not sting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	In this way, cauterizing with burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	Is as you teach the sick person, that he should shave off his hair, until it is prolonged and even.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	Make in the shape of a laurel leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	Then take from the well-known soap, and from the non-imbibed clay of either weight an ounce or almost like that: then dry it all at once with good friction, and make it with haste, so that it does not freeze.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	Then from the same from, stretch it on the chartum which you made like a laurel leaf, and put that on one or both eyelids.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	And place under the eye the wound soaked in albumen, and have the nurse in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	And place your finger on the medicine, and press the wound slightly.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	And thou shalt move him when he feels weak from the medicine's bite: for his bite is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	While yet it continued to seek out what he himself had found, then dismiss the medicine and touch him with your own finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	When the bite has quieted, then dismiss the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	And then consider if you see the eyelid raised up, like it is raised up during burning or cutting: this is good. And if not, then repeat over the same place from the medicine, where it does not impress and does not harm, until your operation has made it well, and it closes up.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	Then put on top of him Cothum with butter, until the skin that is rough to the touch is eradicated.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with diaphanous ointment, or some other one, until he is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	And it is necessary for you, when you are doing the operation, to keep the last watch, lest anything of the medicine falls into his eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	That if the eyelid becomes soft after a few days, and fights with some hair in the eye, then repeat the medicine over that place which has become soft from the eyelid of itself, as you did before.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for him, until he is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	And this is the form of the ointment of myrtle.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	And you should know that human eyes differ in size and shape.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	Therefore, according to this, your consideration: And may it not be hidden from the straightness of his sight, which is the study concerning this art.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	Regarding the mode of cauterizing in the lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	Chapter 19.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	When you are treating the fistula, in accordance with what we have said regarding the diversions of illnesses, and your treatment does not bring about healing: then you should cauterize it according to this manner.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	Prescribe to the sick person that he puts his head in your lap, and holds it between his hands so that it does not move or shake with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	Then put on cotton wadding, or on slimy mucilage over his eye; then the fire cautery, whose shape is this.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	Then set the cauldron, like the shape of a feather quill from one end, so that it becomes cauterium; and if you set the cauldron to reach to the other end, and if you set the cauldron to rise up thus.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	However, this cauldron is better for your work.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	Then put on a pipe, if it is open, and remove the pus from it, and dry it up; and if it is not open, then open it, and remove the pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	Then put on the cautery then over it, which becomes brightly burning.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	And hold with it your hand somewhat near the cautery from the eye, towards the nose part, so that your hand does not err, or shake: and put on the cautery in the fat of the eye, and corrode it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	If then you cut off in the beginning of your cautery to the mouth, it will be good.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	And if not: then repeat the cautery once, or twice, if you can bear it: and dismiss it after three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	Then put on cotton with butter, and care for the wound with a drying ointment, until it heals.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	That if they have passed forty days and are not healed: then put on the wound an acute corrosive medicine, until you see the mouth: and wash it after what has come out in its own chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	And there is another way of cautery with a pipe, which some first said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	Intend to the place of the pipe, and find it: then put in it a small hole, that is, a fine funnel, whose shape is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	And pour in it a quantity of liquid lead, and hold your hand with the funnel firmly, so that the patient does not move at all, so that he does not run away, or let the liquid lead get to his eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	It is necessary to put on the eye, an infusion of cotton impregnated with albumin, or water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	Plumbum because it burns the site of the fistula and heals it with a miracle cure.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	If the fistula is healed, along with what we said from the Cauterium and Remedy, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	And if not, then it is necessary to open the nasal cavity, and bring the fistula back to the course of the nose, according to which it will go to its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	The mode of cauterizing in wounds of the lips.
Caput XX.	Chapter XX.
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	Often a crack occurs in the lip, which is called a pilus, and especially in the lips of boys.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	When you are dealing with these cracks, along with what we said in the division of diseases, and if the cure is not effective, then a small fire of the cautery knife, according to this form:
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	And let it be pressed down with the sharpness of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	Then place the ignited piece quickly on the cracks, until the cautery reaches the depth of the cracks.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	Then cure it with oil, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	The mode of cauterizing in wounds of the mouth.
Caput XXI.	Chapter XXI.In quibusdam enim in Oris
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	When it occurs in the root of the gums, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then pus is produced, and it breaks: then it dries up, and pus runs, and a fistula forms: then deal with it, and there is no effect from the cure, then you must set fire to the cautery according to the quantity, which enters the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	Then introduce the ignited piece into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand, until the iron is ignited to its depth, and the last part: do it once, or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	Then cure it after that, up to the point where we have said that it will be healed.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	If then a wound has been incised and healed, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	And if not, then it is necessary to remove the place, and take away the corrupted bone according to what comes to its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	De the mode of cauterizing in gingival diseases, and molified teeth.
Caput XXII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	When the gum is softened by moisture, and the teeth move, and does not improve with medicine, then place the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	Then, as the shape of the wand comes after these things, so that you put on a cane over the tooth: and insert the lit cautery quickly into it: and hold your hand a little, until the sick one feels the heat of fire already reaching to the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	And dry your hand: then repeat the cautery several times, according to what you want.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	Then the sick one should fill his mouth with salt water, and hold it for an hour: and spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	For the tooth is made firm by movement, and the softened gum is tightened, and the corrupt moisture is dried up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	The mode of cauterizing in dental pain:
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII.AQuam autem dentis dolor,
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	When the pain of the tooth is because of coldness, or the cold itself is painful, or there is a sore feeling, and the medicine does not improve with drugs: then the cautery must be made in two ways: or with butter-cauterization: or with fire-cauterization.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	But the cautery of this is made by butter, as you take butter and heat it up, and pour it into an ear-trumpet or a pair of shears.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	Then take a wand, and rub it on the tip of the tongue.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	Then submerge the patient's tongue in heated butter: and place the patient's tongue quickly on a painful tooth, and hold it until it is chilled: then repeat the operation several times, until the strength of fire reaches to the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	And if you wish, dip the thread, or wrap it in cold butter, and place it on the tooth that hurts; and place hot iron upon it, until the fire penetrates deeply into the decayed part of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	But cauterization with fire, so that you direct it towards the tube of air, or the tube of iron.
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	And let there be some moisture in his body, so that the sharpness of the fire does not penetrate to the back of the throat.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	Then take the fire-cauterizer, whose shape you have prepared; and place it on the tooth; and hold your hand, until the cauterizer cools down.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	Do this sometimes, for the pain will be relieved, or do it on the same day, or on another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	And it should be impressed into his bad breath so that it fills the sick mouth with good broth, and he should hold it for an hour: then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	This is the form of the cauterizer.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	Cauterize with either hand as well as you can: and this is the form of the tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	The mode of cauterizing in strofuli.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXII.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	When the strofuli are deep-seated in phlegm, and from cold humidities, and do not submit to digestion by medicines, and wish to digest them quickly: then take a narrow-tipped fire-cauterizer, whose shape is as follows.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	It has two open ends, so that smoke can emerge from the fire-cauterizer's one end; and place the hot iron on the apothecary once, and second time, if you can endure it, until the fire penetrates deeply into the apothecary.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	Which if the apothecary is small: then place the cauterizer according to the quantity of the apothecary.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	Then let it be left for three days; and place cold butter on the tooth, so that the fire that burned away is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	Then care for the tooth with dental ointment, until it heals up in the form of a tube.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	To cauterize a sore throat and a constricted windpipe.
Caput XXV.	To cauterize a sore throat and a constricted wind
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	When there is an excess of moisture on the windpipe, and especially when it is accompanied by a cold complexion, then the sick person should be evacuated first with water-based medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	Then cauterize the throat itself with a warm substance in the region of the tonsils in the lower part: and be careful, so that you do not burn with the cautery into the throat or skin, unless there is something on it.
