Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	Then cauterize the throat itself with another cautery at the joint of the neck at the last of the spine of it last: and let the cautery be a clove, according to what preceded.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the person with what preceded, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	The way to cauterize a disease of the lungs and cough.
Caput XXVI.	The head.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When the cough and lung disease are caused by cold humidities, and the sick person does not have a fever or phthisis, and an old disease: then cauterize the throat with two cauters above the jawbone in depressed places, gently and smoothly.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two breasts: and let the cautery be a tube, according to what preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you want your cauterization to be effective by puncturing with the cautery, which is called a Puntum, of the same shape as that which preceded in the puncturing of the pain of the ears: and let there be punctures from twenty to almost thirty.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the person with what preceded, until he is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let there be a cautery with three branches: according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Why the allaying of the pain when you make with the cauterization a single one of three cauteries?
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	The way to cauterize a tickle, in a dislocation of the shoulder joint.
Caput XXVII.	Caput XXVII.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head of the assistant is dislocated, the cause of moistness and not being restored to its original place at the time of its dislocation until it gets used to the return, then dislocates with a little movement, which we have already proven that it happens, then it should be reduced the dislocation in first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then he is laid back on his back or on his side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then with the index of your left hand, rub the skin inside the titillus at the top and if the dislocation is inside.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then take two fire-whips.
Cuius forma est haec.	Whose shape is this:
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then burn the skin until it penetrates to another side, and the figure of the cauterization is obtained with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And when it is cauterized with a fire-whip having three whips, why does the figure of the cauterization then become six smaller cauteries; and the whips are according to the subtlety of the touch.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the shape of the whip-maker having three whips.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And when one is added to this mode, why are there eight cauteries; and they are according to the number eight.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place on the cauterization crushed pores with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make adhere to the calmness of the member so that it does not move at all, until it is comforted.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is above and rarely happens, then burn it with a whip on the shoulder or with many points of cautery.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is secured, and the moisture is removed; and the patient is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	The method of cauterizing the Stomach:
Caput XXVIII.	Head XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When cold and much moisture occur in the stomach, until they extract it from its skin, and multiply the catarrhs to it, and the frequent methods of healing, and does not confer: then the sick person should be laid back on his back, and he should extend his legs, and his hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then he cauterized with three cauterizations, a cauterization under the cochleary chest to the size of a finger with a cauterization of the claw, and two cauterizations lower than the two sides of a cauterization of one, until the figure of the cauterizations becomes triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And lengthen between each other so that they do not join together when it comes to pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of cauterization be the quantity of two thirds of the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of the cauterization be second to this form without addition: and if you want to cauterize with a large cauterization in the middle of the stomach according to this form: and let the cauterization, which is made in this way, be one according to the form of the circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And let the stomach be cauterized by piercing it with that which shivers at this cauterization: and it is, in order to mark the point on the stomach according to the quantity, which you want to use with caustics: then cauterize that same point with a cauterization: then care for that same point with the cure, which preceded, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	The way of cauterizing with fire.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter 29.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When it happens in the liver that there is pain from cold and humidity, or from coarse winds, until it emerges from its natural exit with excess fluid, and the sick person is cared for with what we have said, and does not benefit in him: then it should lie down on a wadded pillow on his back, and sign with caustics three cauterizations according to this form, and this quantity of the same caustic on thespar below the hypochondrius where it reaches the bed of man: and let there be space that is between each cauterization according to the thickness of a finger: and let the cauterization be second to the length of the body straight: and do not compress your hand with the caustic much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity that is burned be from the thickness of the skin, half of that not added: and let the sick person stand on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	But if he is not standing, then let him lie down, for he has already stretched out his legs and raised his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the method of the surgery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And you too can perform this surgery with a knife as your cautery tool, when skill and caution are needed in the craft.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And be careful not to move forward too quickly in the cauterization process, and remember that the skin is fragile; you don’t want it to get damaged because if it does, the whole body will suffer from the damage and the internal organs will be affected: for the skin there is a risk of damage.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	The method for cauterizing the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When a liver abscess occurs and you need to know whether it is located in the liver itself or in its capsule, then if it is in the liver, you will see a painful ache, and there is little pain: but if it is in the capsule of the liver, then you will feel sharp pain; and you will see that the treatment of this hurts doctors.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	It is necessary so that the sick person rests on their bed.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then, the shape of the location of the abscess with the caustic: then, the fire of the cautery so that it is absorbed by radiation.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And cauterize it with one cautery tool until the skin is completely burned and reaches the nipple, then, take care of the cure for the healed abscesses, until they are healed.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not necessary for this cautery tool to appear in a certain way unless the study of medicine is prolonged: and because of this experience, sometimes some diseases can be treated with great care; then, let one dare to perform such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But, I prefer to send it away.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	The method for cauterizing in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancient ones said that the cautery of pleurisy was made with roots of aristaochia, according to this method.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And take from the dry stems of aristaochia a long root, which is found in it, and make it be like the thickness of the finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil and set fire to it.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one cauldron between the continuation of the fork with the neck, and two small caldrons little declined on the part that is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And two caldrons also in it, that is between the fifth and sixth ribs little declined on the back: and a cauldron other in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And three caldrons behind: one in it that is between two spatulas: and two caldrons on the sides of the chest, lower cauldron that is between two spatulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And do not need to squeeze your hand with the cauldron, but let it be in the open skin smelling.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancient people said that who use a cauldron of iron similar in radius: and light it up, and put it inside him that is between the ribs until it reaches with it to the apostema, and comes out pus: as we have said in the apostema of the liver.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this piercing with the cauldron is out of fear that either dies weak immediately, or happens in place fistula, which there is no cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	The mode of cauterizing The Spleen Head IIII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you cure the disease of the spleen, with him that we have said in dividing diseases, and your cure does not bring forth, then cauterize it is in it according to three modes, which are all straight.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	Of which one is, that you make three caldrons or four linear according to the length of the spleen according to the figure of cauterization of the liver, whose preceded the figure.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let there be between every cauldron quantity of thickness of the finger, or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let there be a certain mode of the cautery, which we have spoken of in the surgery of the liver equally.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not compress your hand with the cautery; and let the sick one lie on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another mode of cauterization is: that the cautery has two ends, which we have spoken of in the chapter on shoulder dislocations: and wipe the skin, which is straight in front of the spine, where it reaches the bed on the left side; and let your elevation be as you wipe the skin according to the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then introduce the two hot ends until you penetrate them into the skin from the other part; then remove the cautery: so there are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you want to cauterize with a cautery that has three ends.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the cautery after you have removed it, as it emits pus over many days: because it is more effective if the remaining parts that have preceded in the cure are removed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	The mode of cauterization in Hydropsis.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter 33.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	The cautery does not fall in Hydropsis, unless it is properly raised.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat Hydropsis with the modes of cure which we have spoken of in the division, and there is no effect from the cure, then you should cauterize four times around the navel, and one on the stomach, and one on the liver, and one on the spleen, and two behind the back between the vertebrae, and one directly on the chest, and one directly on the stomach: and let the depth of the cautery be close to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then remove the cautery open, so that it emits pus over a long period of time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not wet the sick one after cauterization with that, for two intentions need to be added to it; and will hasten to recover by the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	Indeed the shape of the cautery with which the stomach is cauterized, should be closed; because the shape preceded it; and with respect to its shape, when the back is cauterized, it should be oliwary.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	Regarding the method of cauterizing the feet and legs:
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter IIII. regarding the head.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When they are laid in the hypospasm and become filled with yellow water: you should cauterize over the back of the foot in the nocrati, which is between the auricular and the ring: and wash your hand with the cautery, and do not twist it: then wash your hand: and do not repeat it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	For the yellow water, the shape of the cautery should be as follows.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make two cauteries on both legs, and the shape of the blade of the cautery should be at the end of a knife-edge cautery: and the shape of the cautery according to the length of the leg, one below the knee, and the other lower than that, about in the middle of the leg: and two cauteries on all the loins: and do not close the cauterium for a long time: so that it returns from it some water: then care for it with the rest as we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	Regarding the method of cauterizing in the solution of the abdomen:
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXV. regarding the head.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When the solution of the abdomen is weakened by cold and moist things that are retained in the stomach and intestines: and treat it with a method of cauterization, and does not heal: and you will see that it tolerates the cautery with great vigor, then cauterize it with a large cautery over its stomach, according to the order preceding in cauterizing the stomach with a circular cautery and four small cauteries around the navel, with a thin knife-edge cautery: and a large cautery on the alcatine above the loins, or two large cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see abundant moistness and the disorder tolerates it, then cauterize it over the pelvis and over all the loins: and perhaps you should add two small cauteries next to the large one on the stomach.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	For the cure is perfect in those for whom it is not a mistake.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	As for the method of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Head 36.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When the hemorrhoids are ancient and many, or one, and they are of gross humors, cold, or corrupt moistures, and they are treated with that which we have said in the division, and the cure does not occur: then cauterize three cauterizations on the lower spine of the back under an amulet a little triangular, and cauterization under the navel almost two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is cold and his food is not digested, and you see that his face is pale, then cauterize him on the stomach with a large cautery, according to what preceded: and cauterize on his epigastrium, and another on his spleen, with another on his clavicle: and leave the cautery open for some time: then cure him himself, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	As for the method of cauterizing athelomas after their amputation.
Caput XXXVII.	Head 37.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut off the atheloma, then light the cautery that is absorbed with a rayon.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the lit cautery into the atheloma that has been cut off: and last, with your hand, until the cautery reaches the orifice of the gut, from which blood flows: do it once, or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If then there are many athelomas, then cauterize each one with a cautery, according to what we have said.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then cure them, with the unguent that is given to them, until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cautery on the alcatine, it is more final in the treatment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	As for the method of cauterizing the fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Head 38.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the sick person does not submit to the section and the work we have described in its place, and trembles because of it, perhaps he will be healed with a cautery.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	So then when a fistula occurs in someone and it is old, pus runs out of it, and corrupted moisture.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Dignified indeed is it that one should test it with subtle attempts when a wound has occurred.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then later know the depth of its extent when you attempt it.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then later use a cautery fire that is like a ray.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then later insert yourself with the ignited thing into the fistula and the quantity in which it enters, seal it up.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeatedly pass the cautery over it until all those corrupt bodies are burned up, once, or twice, or three times, according to the extent of your need.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And guard yourself against any dry heat, if there is one there, or great blisters: or if the fistula opens into a part of the body of the uterus, or of the intestines, then guard yourself from all such places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not make this unless the fistula is in a fleshy place: and think, for it does not pierce.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	But if the place is sealed and the materials are cut away from it, and it remains so for a long time: then you shall know that it has now been completely healed.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if the materials are not cut away from it, then you shall know that it is piercing, or there is a corrupt opening within it, or almost like those things: of whose remembrance the place itself will be a sign.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	The way to cauterize Renes.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain occurs in the kidneys from cold, or from a thick wind, and it keeps because of that urinary fever, then one should cauterize himself above the loins on both sides over the kidneys, cauterizing each kidney with a cautery clauius, whose predecessor was remembrance.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we have cauterized it again in that same place.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Why are there three stripes?
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	So then shall be the last ones in the binding.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	The way to cauterize the vesica.
Caput XL.	Head Forty.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When there is weakness and softening in the bladder from cold and moisture, until it does not retain urine, then cauterize the body below the suprapubian skin on the bladder where the hairs grow between them, and the cautery on the right side below the pubic bone, and another on the left side; and let the length of the cautery on the back be according to the quantity of the knuckle of the thumb: and cauterize it with two cauteries if you can bear it. And let the nail clipper be used for cauterizing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	The way to cauterize the matri
Caput XLI.	Head Forty-One.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When there is cold and moisture in the uterus, and it is prevented from becoming impregnated, and her menstruation corrupts and her inducement is delayed, and pain occurs when she is with her husband, then three cauteries should be applied around the umbilical region as we have said for the cauterizing of the bladder, and one cautery below the back on the alcach, or two; and let the nail clipper be used for cauterizing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	The way to cauterize the anus in a dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Head Forty-Two.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When the mucous membrane of the anus flows out with moisture and causes the exit of waste from its place: and the sign of this is that the flesh prolongs over one side when they are facing each other; and the location of the dislocation is found to be empty.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Then let the sick person be cauterized over the anus with a similar circle of the same cautery: after you have found the signs with the caustice around the anus, as it recedes: and so that it falls on the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let the shape of the one that preceded in the cauterizing of the stomach be used for cauterizing.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If this cautery is not present with you, then cauterize it with three cauteries, with a large olive oil cautery; and let the depth of the cautery be according to the thickness of the skin of all.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Afterwards, care for yourself, until you are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	The way to cauterize the sciatic nerve.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter LIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the ankle joint, and there is a cause for this pain, cold and moisture: care for the sick with it, since we have said in the division, and there is no cure, and it becomes stale: then it is necessary that you separate the sick from thick humors with foul pills, or with artificial pills, and others.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the method of cauterization in her is according to two ways: either with cauterizing medicines applied, or with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	The cauterizing with fire, is according to many ways.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	Of which one is that, as it cauterizes on top of the ankle joint, three triangular cauldron-shaped.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make them a good depth, or bad.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	And there should be a space which is between each cauterization the quantity of the size of a thumb: and let the cauldron be oiled.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	When, however, it is necessary to make the cauterizing in the middle on top of the ankle joint itself.
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Why are there four cauldron-shaped things?
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you want to cauterize with a circle, whose predecessor is the form of the dislocation of the ankle joint, one: so that it includes the whole ankle.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the skin of all.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the method of cauterization in the sciatic nerve, when the pain adheres to the ankle itself, and does not extend up to the hip and the leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	But if it extends up to the hip and the leg, then cauterize it on both sides of the hip, on the spot where the pain is felt, and cauterize it with your knife a little bit on the shin bone, four fingers wide: and let the cauldron be sharp.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And make the depth of the cauterizing according to the depth of the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the sick one complains that the pain extends to near the toes, then cauterize him at that place with a point, three, four, or more, if he needs it.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if he complains of pain under the knee towards the thigh, then cauterize him at that place with a single knife.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And so that you may not finish with the cauterization and burn the flesh, or a large artery, and attract trouble for yourself through it on the sick person's body, or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I have already seen one and the other who cauterized above the knee and finished with the cauterization, and the leg swelled until it reached the foot, and it was completely corroded, and then the water of the wound resolved, and death followed afterwards.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	That if the pain is in two parts at the same time, cauterize each one according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men have said in the cauterization of the anus, whose cauterization is this mode.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a similar model from iron, whose diameter is half the size of the palm: and place it at the opening according to the thickness of the nail, or less than that: and within that third piece, another third.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And place between each finger according to the quantity of the nail's knot: and let there be openings on both sides: and make their height almost like a knot, or two knots: and let them make the handle from iron bent unevenly in the fingers.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then let it be burned in fire until it turns red, and let sparks be thrown off: then let it be placed on a tray of mud at the sick person' side lying on the sound side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Then cauterize him with three round cauterizations in a line.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then let go of him after three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Then bind it with butter: and let the wound remain open for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then treat yourself with ointment until healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasius says, with this kind of burn, we use a little because of the appearance of fear: and therefore, because there are few who wait on him.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	However, it is good for him who suffers from this, and he finds his place with him.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	But the cautery when you are burning, so that you make two strong loops, in which the rod of his door descends from brass or iron, its length being on the sides: their two knots, or almost like himself.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And there is a space between the two, which is the length of the finger's thickness, and are open below and above: and that they contain themselves in this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then put it on a plate of salt, the sick man lying on his healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And compress your hand very much over the salt plate.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between the two circles of warm water, which is a little heated with fire, and hold it for an hour: and let the sick person feel a tingling on him, and his own burning, for he finds the tingling like fire, until he sleeps.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then wipe your hand with an instrument and wash it completely with sweet water: then let go of it for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put on the butter until the blackness of burning is removed: and let go of it for a few days, and wash out the pus.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	It is finally in healing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then treat that with ointment until healed.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If the pain extends to the hip or wound: let him have a standing position in it that holds water, according to what you did in the wide one.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the way of warm water: and I have already written about it in the book on the correction of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take the alkali and raw calcin, both of which are on one side: pour them both out, and put them in a new bowl, whose lower part is pierced with a small hole, according to the quantity that is added into it, radii: and put under the bottom of the bowl another one poured. And throw over the alkali and raw calcin with sweet water, so that they are submerged by one finger: then you squeeze them with your hand good compression: and let go of the bowl, until the sharp water comes out at the lower part of the bowl uitreatam.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then join together the whole water and throw it on another stone: and scratch, until it heals over again.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For she will then be very strong and keen, which is used in many surgical procedures and also in the cauterization of the remaining limbs.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it will perform the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And from the medicines, with which they cauterize the broad, also like theriac, and honey of acorns, and lime mixed with soap, so that both are mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen himself related, telling of a man from ancient times who was cured of pain in the ankle and sciatic nerve: and he magnified that it was very effective.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said, "I do not know of another cure," and that he was cured from one joint, until he told, "Perhaps I entered the warm bath, and came out already healed.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is taken from the joint of the thumb: and if it is not found in the thumb, it is taken so, freshly cut: and placed on the ankle, where the pain is, or in the hip, or tied up and left for a time, three hours, or as much as the sick person feels a sedative pain.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then introduce it into the bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When therefore his body is wet with the water, introduce him into the saucer.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain has subsided, and he is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And you should know that it is not necessary to use any kind of treatment with these medicines, unless after the body has been evacuated.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides who said, that when straw is mixed with him, when it is used to cauterize the sciatic nerve, it serves as a cautery: and becomes a cautery in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Take wool, and dip it in old oil, and place it on the deep place, which is between the thumb of the foot, and between the toe, and it is closer to the fire.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take goat dung mixed with earth and heat it in fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then put the mixture on wool and leave it there until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat this.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	So do not cease to perform this, until the sense has returned in the middle by way of length, and let the pain rest.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	This mode of treatment is called vaccineum.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	§ On the treatment for back pain.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 48.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	When pain occurs in the back for various reasons, or from accident, or from impact, or from excessive evacuation, and similar cases, with cold and moist material: and cauterization does not fall unless it is done alone in this manner only, which is done with an infusion of cold material.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	It is necessary therefore after the evacuation to apply nurses with bitter pills and similar things so as to make them stand on the back where there is pain, three lines according to its width, after the marks have been made by the causticum on each line: five cauterizations, or more according to the quantity which comes from the patient's tolerance of the nurse's virtue: and let cauterization be made with a cauterization needle.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three cauterizations, or four, with the middle closed, in this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	§ On the method of cauterizing in gibbus.
Caput XLV.	Chapter 50.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This malady often occurs in small children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of the onset of this disease in children is that which occurs on him a stricture in swallowing during elevation and movement: and an inflammation in the last spondylum of the back and its nods, which has already begun to emerge above the other spondyles.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	So when you see this and wish to do something about it, then cauterize the affected area with a needle which is a circle in the following form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And he took cautery over all parts of the spine equally: and if you cauterize the spine with cautery two or three lines: and let the points be close to each other.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then care for the place, until it heals with it what I have said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And do not administer cautery to the hunchback, which is made in a spasm of nerve.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	The mode of cauterizing in podagra and painful joints.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLV.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When the pains of joint-aches are caused by cold dampnesses which spread to any part of the body, and when they occur in the feet, it is usual for doctors to call this podagra.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	How then should podagra be cured which is caused by cold, with methods of cure, and if the pains are not removed, then let them be removed by cautery.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is as if he were cauterized after evacuation around the joint of the feet with many cautery: and let the cautery be Oülar.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you can bear it that the points are on the face of the foot, then do so with a single-point cautery.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	That if the pains ascend to the knees, or other joints, and often occur, then cauterize himself over all the knee with three or four cautery's, each from a different side, with this same cautery of Cloyl.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	But if you need many of these cauteries, then cauterize himself.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not submerge your hand with the cautery, but rather let there be a thin layer of skin around it.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	But if the pains ascend to the knees and back: then administer what I have said about cautery in my book.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	That if the pains are only in the hands, then points around a fire, as two lines rotate.
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	But if any of the pains remain in the fingers, then do so, each point over all the knuckle: and on the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If, however, the pains rise after a few days to the shoulders, or to the arms, then cauterize both sides.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not let the sick person's disease improve with good regimen, or with the reception of medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	For if the regimen is made good, and the phlegm is expelled, it will be healed by the help of God with this cauterization.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	§ On the mode of cauterizing in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Head XLVIII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin, and the intestine goes down, or the spermatic cord comes close to the testicle, then you should instruct the sick person to discontinue his food in his own day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use laxatives, so that the manure may come out of his bowels.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then make him sit between your hands on his back; and instruct him to hold his breath until he stands up, or appears in the groin, or moves the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce him with your fingers, and mark with the caustic under the rupture on the top of the spine, with a mark whose extreme is equal to half of a circle towards the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then take the caustic fire, which has this form, until it becomes white, and let it throw off sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine, or the spermatic cord to its concavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then let the minister put his hand on the place so that he does not expel the intestine; and you have already opened between the legs of the sick person, and placed under him a pillow, and one turning with his hands, and another holding up his chest, who holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the caustic fire on the spot, with your hand holding the caustic standing straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold him, until you succeed with him to the teeth: or repeat with him another motion, if you do not succeed with him in the first attempt up to the teeth.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe at the exit of the intestine in the hour of your cauterization, so that you do not burn yourself, and let it go through that into the sick person or death, or great malignity.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not achieve with the cautery the opening of the mouth, your operation does not bring about.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	It is necessary that the cautery of infants be subtle, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care with the other ointments, until it has healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the sick person lie down on his back for forty days, until the wound has closed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you put food for him in the length of his curing time, which softens his stomach: so that he does not excrete from strangeness and stool.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wants to get up after forty days, then administer a loose ligament that has been made differently, and let him hold for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And let him rest from work, and be filled with food and drink, and with loud sounds.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when he uses this regimen, so does he heal with whole health.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	I will speak about the cure of ruptures with incisions in their own chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When, however, ruptures happen in the rest of the body, and are incipient, and do not add to each other, then cauterize the rupture of his own with a round cautery according to its quantity: and let it be as it heals from then on like the third one.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then take care of him, with what I have said: and do not add anything.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And certain ones of the first said: that ruptures be cauterized with a triangular cautery, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	Afterwards sigil it with encaustic, and let a line be put which is across the width in the back of the rupture, and another line down below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And place your hand in the middle with a clauius cautery.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But the first cautery is easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	Về cách thức khử trùng để chữa bệnh do đau đớn hoặc va chạm gây ra.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When it happens in some member from a fall or a blow: and that pain persists for a long time, and does not bring about an operation with medicines: then it is necessary that it be cauterized with a Puncta cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let there be cautery for all members according to the size of it and its goodness and weakness and its strength and the place of twist and pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	But if he is healed by the first cauterization, it is good.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not: then repeat the cauterization over him again.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	Because of the custom of these pains, so that they change from one member to that which approaches it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Why should those who follow be taken away with cauterization until the sick person is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	Regarding the method of cauterizing for lepra.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter 49.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	But lepers should be cauterized by a strong fire.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the species of lepra which is made because of putrefaction of phlegm and melancholy: so that when you cauterize it, consider the wound carefully.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If, however, lepra is resistant and you have treated it with the care we mentioned in the division and it has not fallen off, but the corruption encompasses all its skin: then cauterize it over its head with five cauterizations: one at the top of the head at its middle, and a second lower than that towards its forehead at the end of its hair, and two behind each ear, and one behind the earlobe.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And lastly with your hand a little bit of fire, so that it impresses on the throat a deep impression, and the membranes are torn from it: so that the exhaling of thick vapors from it is relieved, and cauterize with fire also over its spleen, following the above.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	But if lepra has spread over the sick person and appears clearly: then it is necessary to cauterize with these cauterizations which we mentioned in the head, and a cauterization on the tip of the nose, and two cauterizations on each cheek, and two cauterizations on either side of the neck, and six on the back, and one large on the achilles tendons at the heels and one above him, in the middle. And two on the ankles: that is, on each ankle bone one, and two on the shoulders, and two on the elbows, and two on the breasts of his chest: and cauterize over all his joints with fire, starting from the fingers of his hands and feet, and cauterize over all his toes, and over all the bones of his feet, and over the heart of his chest, and over the ribs of his back: and cauterize also over all his joints with fire.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And because you have nerves that are above the heel, so that they do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And when the cautery is applied to the skin with a caustic substance, and with another above the chest bone, and with another above the stomach, and with another above the liver.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you add the caustic substance, the more it is a remedy, and the more it helps.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that a sick person does not feel pain in the cautery, as he feels it when he is healthy: therefore, because his body is already stunned.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And let the caustic substances be of the right size, and with a sharp edge that cuts the flesh, according to the members and joints: and after this, as regards the order of the tools.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care to add the caustic substances made from herbs and honey, and with other cures, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	The way of applying the cautery to stupor.
Caput L.	Head.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When one of the limbs is stupor and is treated with medicines, oils, plasters, and is not healed, then apply the caustic substances to that limb which has stupor, according to the size of the limb or its smallness.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your caustic substance remain in the thickness of the skin a little.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care to cure that with ointment, until it is healed.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And when the caustic is applied to a certain stupor which occurs in the hand or foot at the exit of nerves that move that limb: and the stupor disappears.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But this does not happen to him, except for one who is wise in anatomy of the limbs, and knows the exit of nerves that move the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	The way of applying the caustic substances made by Albucasis.
Caput LI.	Head.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albucasis is applied to a deep place and does not bring any remedy to it: then apply the caustic substance on top of it a little, according to the thickness of the skin, until the skin is blistered and its color changes.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then the care of him with wheat flour, and lentil with olive oil, and leaves of arnoglossa, and pigeon's blood, and hyland's blood: from each one there is a part; all these are mixed together, and laid on a cloth, and adhere to the place until healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	The way of cauterizing in cancer.
Caput LII.	CHAPTER LII.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning, and you stop the flow of blood to it: then cauterize it with a circular cauterizer around its circumference, as though it were turning.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	But the wise have said that it should be cauterized with a last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	But I do not trust that one: for I am afraid that it will ulcerate: and I have seen it sometimes.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better to cauterize it around its circumference with a circle, as we have said: or with many cautery's.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	The way of cauterizing in adebelta (leprosy).
Caput LIII.	CHAPTER LIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an ablation, and it is delayed in healing, or because of its excess, or because of old age, when it is decrepitous with little blood, or because of time, and the wound rushes into healing, then cauterize around it with small cautery puncturing.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then, let go of her.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For she herself will hurry with the healing process.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	But if you pierce her with a cautery, then take this kind of fire cautery, which has this shape.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And place it in the middle of the ablation, until it penetrates the skin: and let the cautery be from it that follows, so that the course of the pure may be relieved.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	The way to cauterize with fire in a corruption.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIIII.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A corruption is not unless it corrupts a member that walks, and corrupts the member itself: like fire that cooks dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	But if you see a corruption in a place that accepts the cautery with fire, then take many cautery fires, small tools and big, according to what suits him in the place where the corruption is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize the member from all parts until you eradicate the entire corruption, and nothing remains of it inside.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then let go of the member for three days, and put sulfur powder with oil on the cauterized places, until all the eschar are eradicated, and all corruption.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then take care of the member with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	But if you see that after three days the flesh is born healthy, and there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	But if not: then repeat the cautery on what remains of the corrupted places.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And the corruption is healed sometimes with sharp medicine.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For she herself rises up in place of the cauterized.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	But the cautery with fire is faster to work: and I have already said that the cauterizing is done with sharp medicine in division: so take it there when you are ready for it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	To cauterize in the claws and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter L.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	Often this disease appears on the lower parts of the feet; and it is a gross disorder, which is produced by filth, and afflicts the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And there are two ways of applying the caustic to them: with fire, and with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	As for how it is to be applied with fire, so as to resemble the feathers of a pluckers knife; that is to be made of iron, and in such a way that the claw may not be at all hurt; and let there be a slight margin.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then put the burned thing on the claw.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then, with the caustic in your hand, turn it round about the claw, until the caustic reaches the depth of the claw; and leave it three days, until the pus begins to come out.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then bind the thing with silk thread, crushed up with salt: and leave the bandage on the thing during the night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	For it will be根除根除
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with a ointment made of flesh, until it is healed.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not turned, and often happen on the surface of the body, especially in the hands and feet; then apply to them a caustic with warm water; and it is like to take a tube made of brass, or iron, or a feather from a pluckers knife; and put it on the claw, or let it flow over it.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then throw into the tube a little quantity of warm water: hold your hand so that the edge of the tube is just pressed into the root of the claw, and let the warm water go down to the root; and wait a while on tiptoe after the tickling of the water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then leave it, for the claw will be根除根除
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	So do with one after another, until you have got rid of all from the body.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then take care of them after they are cut off, as long as they generate flesh from the ointment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	The way to cauterize during tremor.
Caput LVI.	Chapter LVI. On the Treatment of Burned and Frozen Wounds
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When someone happens to be shaken by cold in a nerve, or by fever, or otherwise: then it is necessary to cauterize the same four cauterizations, or five on the back of the spine, and between each rib cauterization, and in the chest itself cauterization, and on the stomach cauterization.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For tremor ceases with the olive oil cauterization, and health of disease of cold speeds up.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	The way to cauterize according to Albatar.
Caput LVII.	Chapter LVII. On the Treatment of Wounds Caused by Fire
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	When any kind of pus is expelled from the body according to Albatar, that is, pustules which arise from coarse corrupted material.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Then it is necessary first when they appear, that they are cauterized over the whole head of the pustule with a fine cautery of myrrh, whose tip is lit up with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or when a long root of aristolochia.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lenticular cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And when they are cauterized with the juice, at first in this way after their expulsion: and do not increase; and breaks up the superfluity by doing so, and heals from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	However, it is necessary for that to be done after evacuation with phlebotomy.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	The way to cauterize during a flow of blood from the artery in the ulnar.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII. On the Treatment of Wounds Caused by Stab
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Often a flow of blood comes from an artery which has been cut at the elbow, or at a cut in the skin, or during a member's cauterization, and so on: and it is difficult to remove him.
