Cum ergo accidit alicui illud, tunc propera cum manu tua ad orificium arteriae, et pone super ipsum digitum tuum indicem: et stringe eum multum, donec obsessus sit sanguis sub digito tuo, et non egrediatur ex eo aliquid.	Then when it has happened to someone of this, then bring your own hand to the orifice of the artery, and place the tip of your finger on it: and hold it tightly until the blood is exhausted under your finger, and does not come out of it.
Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	Then put in fire small oileous cauterizes and many in great number: and blow on them, till they are well burned.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then take out of them one, or small, or great, according to the thickness of the bone and the place where the artery is broken, and put the cautery on it, then, quickly remove your finger: and hold the cautery, till the blood be stopped.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	That if you shall drive away your finger from the opening of the artery with a dry bandage, and put out the fire, then take another fire quickly from those that are prepared in the fire;
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	So therefore cease not to do it one after another, till the blood be stopped.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	And take care, lest you burn up the nerves which are there, and bring on some other mischief to the sick person.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	And know, that when blood flows from an artery, it is then impossible to stop it; especially if the artery be large, except with a four-fold bandage.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	Or with fire, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	Or with extraction, when it is not extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	For when it is extracted, the ends of it are drawn out, and the blood is stopped.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	Or bindeth with a strong ligature.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	Or put on the part with medicine of its property, which is to stop the flow of blood, and bind it with a compressive ligature.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	Whoever administers the cutting of it with a ligature, and the compression with a cloth, or the placing of burning things and like things thereupon, does not give him relief, except rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	But if this thing should happen to anyone, and there be no present doctor, nor medicine: then let the finger of the index begin to be placed on the opening of the vein as we have related, and the compression thereof with great force, till the blood which is above the wound be stopped from flowing into it, and over the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	And the finger should not be moved, above it with cold water always, until the blood has congealed, and thickens, and is cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	And meanwhile he should consider whether it is injured by the cautery or by the medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	[This] is the end of the first part.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	The Book of Surgery of Albucasis, Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	On incision, perforation, and bloodletting on wounds and similar things.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	We have already spoken in the first chapter of all diseases where there is a need for fire to be used as a cautery and medicine combined with burning, and of the causes of these, the causes themselves, their instruments, and the shapes of cauterization.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	And I placed those chapters from the top to the bottom.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	And I will proceed in this chapter in the same way: that is, to answer the question of the inquiry.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	And before I begin that, it is necessary that you should learn from the son, that is, that terror which is in the first chapter about cauterization.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	And for that, it is necessary that there be greater caution in it, since in the operation which is in this chapter, frequently the blood flows out with the sweat, when dealing with a wound, or an incision on a bruise, or an opening of an exit, or curing a wound, or extracting an arrow, or an incision on a stone, and those similar: from all of which tremor and fear arises, and death falls in many of them.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	And I warn you, do not allow that to happen to you which is hesitation, for sometimes men of this art fall into your hands with their many weaknesses.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	For out of them is one who becomes angry with his own illness, and is light-hearted before him because of the severity of his illness and the length of his suffering.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	And when the illness is from fear, which signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	And from these, he who gives you his hand, and says to you, hoping for health, but his illness is pernicious.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	So it is not necessary that you should agree to him who comes to you from these, whose way is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	And let there be more care in your wisdom than your greed and your avarice.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	And do not presume about anyone from that, unless after certain knowledge that confirms with you that it comes to what a worthy succession.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	And so that you may heal all your sick patients, by prognosis and indication of that to which healing is suitable.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	In that, indeed, is an aid for you in acquiring fame and glory, and memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	May God inspire you, O sons, with his understanding, and may he not remove from you his guidance and inspiration: for that is in his hands.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	And I have ordered this Chapter distinguishing it into Chapters, following that which preceded in the Chapter of Cautery from the forehead down to the feet: that you may be relieved in what you ask for from it, and what you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	Of the Cure of Water that is gathered on the heads of boys.
Caput I.	Chapter I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	You should know that this disease often occurs in boys at birth: or when the midwife tightens the boy's head without lightness.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	And whenever it also happens for an unknown reason which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	And I have not seen this disease in any other but in boys; and I would see all of them who suffer from it die: therefore, for that reason, I have dismissed the use of surgery in it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	And I have seen a boy from among those whose head was filled with water, and whose head became magnificent every day, until he could not sit on himself alone, because of the size of his head; and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	And this moisture, or it تجمع between the skin and bone: or it تجمع under the bone above the siffac.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	And the operation in that, if there is moisture between the skin and bone, and the swelling is small, then you should find a crack in the middle of the skull in width: and the length of the crack is almost two knots, until the moisture runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	And this is the shape of a blade.
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	So if the moisture is more increased, and the swelling is larger, then you should place them two cracks, following this form.
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	And if the moisture is under the bone, and the sign of it is that you see the skull openings from all sides: and when you squeeze it with your hand towards the inside, and it does not hide from you: then you should find three cracks in the middle of the skull, following this way.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	And after making an incision remove all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	Then tightly close the cracks with rags and dust.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	Then dip it in wine and oil until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	Then loosen the ligaments, and care for the tendon with tar and wool.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	And do not stop tightening the head with equality.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	And feed the sick with dry and scarce-humor food until their member is comforted and healed.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	Another way of incision is to consider where the swelling appears, and the collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	Because when it is more in the back, or in the forehead, or on the right, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	So go up with the incision where you see the swelling and the filling: and cut it following what is possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	And observe, so that you do not hit the artery, and an accident of blood flow, and the sick person dies from that flow with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	Regarding the incisions of arteries which are behind the ears.
Caput II.	Head.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	When any catarrh happens to the eyes, or to the chest, and it is old, and there is no cure for it with medicines: then the last cure is in that, to cut those two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	Therefore, when you are going to cut these eyes, let the sick person remove his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	Then clean the place with a rough cloth so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	Then the sick person should tie his neck with any of his own cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	Then look where the pulse is throbbing.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	And the places are those which are behind the ears: and they rarely hide except in some people.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	Then mark with caustic on both: and cut one with a sharp knife, while looking towards the mouth: and let it be made through the whole thickness of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	And if you are cutting the eye, insert the sharp instrument under the artery, and cut it towards the top with an incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	And make the length of the incision almost like two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	For when the eye is cut, blood flows out with the pulse, which rises to the inside at a frequent jump.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	If the artery does not appear to the touch, then you must measure the space from the ear to the amount of three fingers.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	Then mark with caustic and find all the way to the mouth.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	And what should be emitted from the blood, is six minutes, and perhaps you emit more or less of it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	All this depends on the amount that appears to you from the eye and the filling of the artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	Then look at the eyeball.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	If there remains in the mouth any siffar [I assume this is a word related to scent or taste], then cut it so that it does not happen that a hot taste remains: and tighten the eyeball with linen threads from a cloth.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the person with ointment, until he is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	The extraction of the arteries which are in the temples.
Caput III.	Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	When a man has an old headache, or acute catarrh through acrid humors and heat in the sinuses, or old soda, bitter, and like things: and is treated with the methods of medical treatment, and does not give it up: then we are skilled in these diseases in extracting the arteries from the sinuses, or cauterizing them, as we have told.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	And the method of operation in extracting them is, that the sick man should shave the hair which is in the sinus, and direct it towards the apparent artery in the sinus.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	This itself shows you from its pulse, and rarely hides unless in a few men, or when there is bitter cold.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	That if it hides from you, then the sick man should tighten his head with whatever cloth he has: and then he should cover the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	Or he should heat the place with warm water until it appears to you in a manifest form.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	Then take a spoonful of the liquid, which little before I made.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	Then scrape with it the skin easily until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	Then throw in it a hook, and extract it upward, until you extract it from the skin, and make it bleed from the clothes which are under it from all parts.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	If, however, the artery is thin: then turn around the hook with its end.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	Then cut from it that side according to the length of its ends, and press them together, and do not allow a flow of blood.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	For if it is not cut, and does not descend, the blood will not go deep.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	Then make bleed from it six ounces of blood up to three times a day.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If, however, the artery is large: then it should be tied to it in two places with a double thread, strong, and silk: or from a cow's stomach, so that it does not tend towards putrefaction before consolidation of the wound, and allow a flow of blood.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	Then cut away the surplus, which is between the two ligaments.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	Do this at that time, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	And if you want, cauterize it with a cauldron until the nose, with a knife-bladed cauldron: until the ends of it are cut, and it remains in place of that work.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	And it is better work if he has a fever, or is a caldred body.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	For the cauldron is from those that remain to finish the moistures.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	Therefore it is better to bandage.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	And it should be after the extraction of the arteries, that the place may be filled with old cooking: and let be put on the top a poultice made in disorderly fashion.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	And after the solution of the medicine with dry medicines, which make grow flesh, and with leech-blood, until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	That if meanwhile while you are doing the work a flow of blood comes out from an artery, then approach to cut it off with a cauldron, or to fill the place with a poultice: and grasp your hand, until the blood is cut off.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	That if you have nothing present to you, then place on the place your finger, until the blood hardens.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	And dip the place in water of cold water, until the sharpness quiets, and grasp it according to what is necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	And from that which is lighter and easier to extraction of the artery, it is, so that the sharpness of two knives is like an almond:
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	However, there is much less sharpness than the two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	For if they are sharp, like the two knives, it is necessary that each one have coldness: and they do not cut flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	So when there is a little roughness in them, it is kept in them heat of fire, and flesh is cut off quickly: so this work then is better for all work, lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	And make a space that is the width of a finger between the two scissors as much as the thickness of a finger, after you have marked two places with the caustics: and place both on fire well, until they come to the mouth, and fall in two places; so that what is between their extremities may be elongated.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	For with this caustic they do not consolidate deeply.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	And this is the form of the caustic.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	§ Of the treatment of acute, sharp, and burning tears from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	When the tears are persistent, and there is a course of tears from the veins that run along the outside of the head's skull: and they do not provide any curative benefit when applied with medicines, and the eyes make the face red, and feel a shivering in the forehead, as though it were shivering like ants: and their eyelids are heated by the acuteness of the tears: then the ancients found cure for them with this operation, and called it the Ense treatment.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	And it is, that you shave off the hair from his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	Then cut in the forehead three slits equidistant according to the length of the forehead: and make the length of the slit nearly as long as two fingers, and the one slit equidistant in length according to the nose in the middle of the forehead, and the second according to the length of half a nostril, and the third from the other: and take care not to cut the arteries that are on either side: and extend your hand from the continuation of the two jawbones, and make the space between each incision as much as the width of three joined fingers: and have a prepared sponge fragment, or many dry cloths, with which to wipe away the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	Then introduce a pair of sharp scissors at the ends of the slits, and whose following form is:
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	From the incision which is from the temporal side, up to the second incision: and scrape off with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, with the caustic, which is on the bone.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	Then also make that from the middle incision to the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	Then also remove this with a chisel, and insert into the first incision again another tool called an acute clement, soft on one side, not acute on the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	And place his acute side opposite the flesh joined with the skin, and his soft side opposite the bone: and push him in until it reaches the middle crack: and cut off everything with him that hangs down from the head to the eyes: except that which continues the incision up to that which appears from the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	Then also make that in the middle crack up to another crack.
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	And when an equal quantity of blood has run out, drain the places from the clotted blood.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	Then also put into every crack a chisel of dried blood, and put on top of them wads dipped in wine, or oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	And be careful so that there is no blistering from the heat.
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	And on the third day resolve the ligaments, and give a strong infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of that with basilicon ointment, and of the others which are treated with ointments: until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	Of the cure for acute tears and cataracts to the eyes from inside the head.
Caput V.	Head
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	When there occur to anyone acute, sharp, persistent: and the eyes of him appear weak, pale, and already weakened is their aspect: and his eyelids are ulcerated, and hairs fall out from them, and in the depths of the head there is an acute pain, stinging, and subsequent sneezing: then do you away with these accidents, that those materials, and cataracts do not come, unless from many sources.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	And the best cure for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	And it is, that you scrape off the sick person his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	Then also cut in that crack one in the middle of the forehead, or another somewhat across the width, and begin with the crack from the left ear to the right: and extend the incision until it reaches the mouth: and dry up all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	Then separate between the two lips of the wound with dried old cloth, or with linen liniments.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	Then tighten from above with dust: and immerse the dust in wine and oil, so that a hot fever does not occur.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	And when you loosen this, and you see that a hot fever is about to break out: then it is necessary that the surgeon's tools be ready, until a new birth begins in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	Then the care of the patient with the drying regime that it makes the birth of flesh: as if you take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony: and prepare an ointment from it, and administer it to the birth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	The care that falls on gold.
Caput VI.	Chapter VI.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	All that falls on gold is of four species: either a mineral rock, or a similar stone, such as iron, and rust: or it is from a plant, such as wheat, and beans: or it is a liquid substance, such as water, and vinegar, and things like them: or some kind of creature.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	When therefore it falls on gold a rock or kind of stone that does not contribute to the growth of gold, expose Gold to the sun alone: but if you see a stone, then distill into Gold some of the oil of spices, or sesame seed.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	Then administer the extraction of it, and cause it to be sneezed out with condiments, and sprinkle the nose with dust near the arrival of the sneeze, after you have placed in the circumambulation of the auricle rolls of cloth, or wool, and spread the ear towards the upper part.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	For this treatment is often repeated.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	But if it does not go out, then administer the extraction of it with a gesticulatory motion, that is, with subtle hand gestures: whose form is this.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	But if it goes out with a gesture, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	Then administer the extraction of it with an invisible little hook: a few times.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	If therefore he does not come out by that means, then make a tube of brass, and insert the extreme end of the tube into the foramen of the ear much, and the dust that is in the circumference of the tube with the brass softened with oil so that there is no way of wind except the tube: then remove it with your breath with strong attraction.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	For very often he comes out with him when we tell him to do so.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	But if he does not come out by this means, then take from the honeycomb, or from the water, that is, the gluten prepared, with which they are caught birds, a little thing: and put it at the end of the radius after you have dried up the ear from the humidity. Then insert it into the foramen of the ear with ease, after you have removed the wax from the ear
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	But if he does not come out with all that we have told you, then approach to cut off, before the hot apoplexy or spasm happens.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	And the way of the wound is so that the phlebotome cuts off the sick first in the head: and remove from him the blood according to the measure of his strength.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	Then make the sick sit between your hands, and turn his ear up to the top, and find a small hole in the base of his ear where there is fat on it: and let the hole be round in shape, until you reach the stone: then remove it with him, as far as you are able with the instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then close the wound from your side with speed, and take care of it, until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	That if the thing falling into the ear is of one grain, which grows and swells up: then administer the extraction of it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	But if it does not obey you in coming out, then take a small, thin, knife, according to this form.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	And administer with him the cutting off of that kind of grain from the ear, which falls and is not caused to come out when you think that it has already been moistened by the vapor of the ear, until you put on it many blows: then remove it with a hook, or with a gentle movement, or with suction, as we have said, for the extraction of it eases.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	For the water which is added to the ear, it is necessary that it should be used by the sick person with sternutation at first; and already he has filled his ear with some boiled old water; and he lies on it, in which water is there.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	If then he goes out through that, it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	And if not: then take many stones, according to the length of a finger, thin, soft, and heat them slightly with fire, and let the sick one put one of them into the hollow of his ear: and let him spit on his foot from that part, and strike it with the stone which is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	Therefore he shall not cease to do this with stones and pebbles, until he has gone out all water.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	And already he has gone out water so that you take from the straw, or from one branch, and put the end of it in the ear; and light the end with fire, until it is burned thoroughly.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	Then take another branch and do this many times, until he has gone out all water; and draw it out with a straw according to what has been said above in the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	In extraction also of an animal which enters into it, if it is a small body, like a flea, and similar to it, care for it as I said in division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	But if it is a body which appears to the sense: then administer its extraction with gestures and with a hook; and its affair is easier for all those who hold it in the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	But in the extraction of a dog which is born in the ear, when you have cared for it with that which we said in division, and in the treatise on distillation, and your cure does not benefit him: then it is necessary that you should look at the ear in the sun.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	But if there appears anything there from dogs, then extract it with gestures, or with a subtle hook.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	But if there appears nothing there, then take the straw which has this shape, strict below, wide above; and put the end into the ear of the sick person with a strong suction; and then suck with it.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	He repeatedly cut it until all the veins had come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	But if they do not obey you at the exit, then bind the cannula around with a cord, as I said in the stone.
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	That if they do not go out with him that we have spoken: then administer the distillations which the ancients have experienced in the infection of veins: and you will find it in the book on distillation.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	And be your pouring so that you pour oil and medicines into the ear with this instrument, whose form is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	As you see make it out of silver, or brass, below tightly packed, in which sits a small hole, wide at the top.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	Then it is that it pushes out what is in the constriction of the cannula, sit from brass made unevenly.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	And if you want, take the radium, and rub it on the end of it with a gentle rubbing: then pour oil, or broth, or what you want from these medicines into the cannula: and let it sit in brass: then throw in the radium with the cotton dropped down, and squeeze it out with your hand moderately, until it pushes out the oil into the constriction of the ear, and feels hot inside: and let that which is infused into the ear be already warmed a little with fire: and let not be what is distilled into it cold: for medicines do not tolerate it.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	Of the treatment of an accidental auricular wound.
Caput VII.	Head VII.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	When certain children come out of their mothers' wombs not pierced through.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	And it has also happened to some men that an auricular wound is caused by a nail, or flesh born in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	And this wound when it happens to be in the deep cavity of the ear, which does not respond to warm: and when it happens to be a little outside the cavity, and it responds to warm.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	That which has happened in the deep ear, and which does not comprehend vision, is in many dispositions difficult to heal.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	And in that which follows the application of the bandage, it is necessary that you place the gold nurse on the sun and look at it: then if you see the operation apparent, open it with a thin spatula whose form is this which follows, let the end of it be in that which there is some little width, and whose part is acute: and the rest of the spatula be soft of both sides: so that it does not hurt the gold.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	If then the operation is from flesh born on the meatus of the ear: then hold it with a little hook, and cut it with ease, until all the flesh is taken away.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	That if the operation is in the deep of the ear: then take a little ray, soft, and heat it slightly: then put it on the meatus of the ear.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	If then you feel the operation with that which is with it, that it is weak with the weight of hearing, try to make the opening of it with ease: and carefully, so as not to hurt the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	Then put in the ear the silver according to the quantity of the width of the hole, which you have opened with Egyptian ointment: make it for a few days, until you are sure of the healing of the wound.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	Or take the silver and pour it into water that has been made pink: and dust it on it, and use it.
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	That if you see the ear already peeling off: then it is necessary that you take out the silver, and let it with the silver of another, which you have opened in a green made with pink oil, until it stops being hot: and then take care of the ear until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	If then happens a flow of blood: then dip a sponge, or rags in cold water, and put it on the ear: and use the remaining cure, which stops the predicted flow of blood in the book of distillation.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	Of the care of the eyelids of Althel.
Caput VIII.	Head VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	Of all the things that happen to the eyelids of the eye, when they are wet and when they are dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	Therefore, you should hold them with tweezers: or with a hook, and strike them with a chisel from their roots.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	Then place on the affected areas three times crushed.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	If, however, blood flows from them, then you should cauterize them with a thin lens cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	And cauterize them, it is better after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	For many times they return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	In the care of the eyelids of the eye:
Caput IX.	Head 9.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	For many times something happens to the eyelids which hardens and becomes tough, and for that reason it is called Grandum: and it is an accumulation of moist grossness on the upper eyelid, and the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	Operation then in them is, so that you consider at the time, if it is Grandum proceeding in it, which appears from the eyelid, and move all around, and its essence is easy.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	Then find on it a slit across the width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	Then remove that skin from all parts with ease until it sheds.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	Then hang it on with a hook and cut it off.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	If, however, you are not prepared to cut off that thing unless after you have made a slight incision on the eyelid, then it will hurt the weak.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	That if the slit is large: then gather it together with a stitch: and care for it, until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	And if it is small, will not harm you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	The ointments restore that, and incrust it.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	And if the Grandum is a decliuis towards the interior of the ear towards the inside surface towards the outside, then upside down the eyelid and hang the Grandum on with a hook: except that you make an incision and press it from all parts.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	If the eyelid is extended by an incision, it does not hurt in any way.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	Then wash the eye after the incision with cold water, and take care of the place where it has become inflamed until the wound heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	Cauterize the eyelids.
Caput X.	Chapter 10.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	The axernath is a fat that is found in the eyelids; and it often happens that children have this fat, which affects their eyes, causing cataracts, so that they cannot see the light of day, because the tears flow towards them, and for that very reason do they lie with their faces down, and sleep on their backs, and their eyelids are always wet and swollen, having become inflamed; and the eminence of axernath is clearly visible to the eye, and when you press the spot with your fingers, you feel the axernath between them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And its mode of action is such that he may place the sick head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	Then take a piece of linen cloth and prepare it with loops, and make from it a circle according to the amount that contains the axernath on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	Then put him on top of it and press him with your fingers from all sides so that the axernath is pressed together in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	Then find in the middle of that wetness with the spatel a crack from top to bottom, and there is no larger crack than that which is made in phlebotomy in the deep.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	Or you should find all the skin, until you reach the axernath; for the axernath often proceeds from a crack according to the form of white-head:
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	Take it out with the cloth that you have immersed between your fingers to the outside: and you should move your hand to the right and left until it disperses; and be careful not to add it to the spatel so that you don't reach the eye, and let it go down.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	If you do not see the axilla at the beginning of the incision, you shall add a little to the incision with ease until the axilla appears.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	Then you shall extract it, as we have said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	Then you shall dip the cloth in vinegar and water, and place them on the spot, and tighten it with flour.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	And there are some who grind salt, and put it in the incision, so that what remains of the moisture is liquified.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then you shall take care of it until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	If, however, a hot blister occurs in the place, then you shall take care of it with soaked plasters, until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	In terms of the Atashmir eyes, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft to the eye, so that it rubs as it should not.
Caput XI.	Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	When hair grows out of the eyelids of the eye in addition to the usual course under the natural hairs, and becomes larger: then they hurt the eye, and cause the following diseases: such as persistent tears, softening of the eyelids, and crusting, until it causes the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	And the Atashmir eyes are treated according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	Or with a caustic, using fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	Or with acute medicine, as specified in the chapter on cauterization.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	Or treated by Atashmir with an incision and suture.
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	Or with a knife, as I say it.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	It is necessary that you place the head of the patient in your lap.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	Then take the eye lid with your left hand.
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	If it is turned, it is good.
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	And if not: insert a needle into it, where lies the hair from the lower part of the eyelid, and let it penetrate with a needle from above, and let it sit next to the hairs themselves, that is, next to the edge of the eyelid, where the hairs grow out: and pull the thread upwards with the eyelid, and turn it around.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	Then find the inner part of the eyelids below the pilus added with the spatula incident from the greater tear to the smaller tear.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	Then remove the fillet, and place a fine feather from a fowl or cloth underneath the eyelid: then mark the eyelid with the caustic substance so that it looks like the figure of a fern leaf.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	However, it should be noted that the shape depends on the quantity and elevation of the eyelid: for this varies widely among individuals.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	From these is one who needs to be incised from the eyelid a great deal, according to the quantity which softens from the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	Then, with the spatula, find the two lines you marked and begin at the larger tear to the smaller tear, and let there be a single crease near the natural hairline, as is the thickness of the radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	Then insert the hook into one of two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	Then scrape it all out.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	Then gather together with sutures the two lips, with a sharp needle and fine thread: and wipe away the blood, and let adhere whatever excess comes from the roots of the two eyebrows, with certain things that shine, if you wish to do so: and if not, then it does not matter.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	Then remove the stitch and thread up to three or four days: then take care of that.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	And if you wish, remove the hook without a stitch, and take care of it with it, so that it dries up and tightens.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	For the eyelid is lifted at the seal of the wound and aggregation thereof: but for the future is better.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	In this way, Ataxmir taught the ancient method of curing.
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	However, there is a concern about the weak spot, and it is from a good surgery, and there is no fear in that.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	And another method is also with Ataxmir: and it is, as to mark on the eyelid a figure, which looks like the figure of a fern leaf, as we have described.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	Then wipe the eyelids with three separate or gathered hooklets, according to this form which follows, and then cut what is superfluous with small scissors, according to this form, with equal incision.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	But if you cannot hold the hook and it does not fit: then take the spike where the filament is, and insert it into the middle of the figure: and insert another filament near the larger tear, and a third near the smaller tear: and bring the filaments together between your fingers with equal tension.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	Then wipe your hand with equal wiping: and wipe the skin above where the knot is marked, as we have said.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bring together the two lips of the wound with a stitch: and take care of it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	But if a bruise happens to be on your incision or a crack: but that bruise with calamine, and these alike, from an ointment sitting.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	And when the eyelids also turn in so that his hair comes out.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	It is therefore necessary that you use on it what we have said in the incision: but the stitch on both sides is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	Of the care of Ataxmir with the dogs.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	AND It is, to turn the eyelid and split the crack which is inside, according to what we have said.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	Then by art make two needles, or two thin sticks: their length be according to the length of the eyelid, and their breadth be less than the width of a toothpick: and you have already incised at the ends on both sides where you hold the threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	Then bring together each with care above that which is superfluous from the eyelid of the eye, and tightly tighten the two needles on both sides with a strong tightening, and leave it for a few days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	For the skin is stiff and will die, and will become brown, and will rot, until it falls away by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	But if it is slow to fall off, then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	When therefore it is healed up, let the eyelid be taken off: and let not the hair be pricked.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	And this is the form of two cannas, which you shall make according to this figure, and their quantity in length and breadth.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	For the eleution of the hair pricking in the eye with an aiguille.
Caput XII.	Head XII.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	The operation in that is, that you take an aiguille fine, and put a thread of silk fine therein, and put it.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	Then bind the ends thereof to each other with a fine knot very well: and let the length of the threads be one palm.
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	Then put another thread of silk fine underneath that, and bind the ends thereof together, if thou wilt: and knott the extremities of it, if thou wilt.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	Then put the sick head in your bosom, and let it be nigh the sun, that the operation may be declared: for this operation is delicate, or minute.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	Then put the aiguille with the Alinxotati in the root of the eyelid, and let it penetrate into the eyelid quickly, until it draw out the natural hair thereof.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	Then draw the hair up to above the Alinxotati: and put that hair into the Alinxotati: if it is one, or two, or three, not more.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	Then draw your hand with him, until he goeth out: and let the hair go out with the Alinxotati in the eyelid with the natural hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	If however the Alinxotati should be drawn out, and the hair not go out with it: then draw the Alinxotati downward, with a thread that you have composed therein, until the Alinxotati goeth out of the upper opening, and covereth the eye with it: then take both out, and close the eye: and let him go closed two days, or three, until the hair be rooted in his place, and grow upon the top thereof.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	If the hair is short, then either attach a long hair from natural hairs, and remove it with it; or leave it until it grows longer after space, and then remove it.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	On the treatment of a condition in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	Chapter XIII: Head.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	When it occurs to the eye, this is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	And this Alxatrati is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	Accidental therefore happens from the consolidation of an injury, or a cut, or cauterization, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	And the mode of operation in it is, that you find that consolidation, and that you separate its lips, and place in it what is between them from linen, and binds it, until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	And it is not necessary, that you use in its treatment things which dry and constrict: for if you do so, Alxatrati will return worse than it was: but rather use in it things which soften, such as fenugreek; and dip it in water, in which althaea has been boiled, flax seed: and spread the ointment dyaquilon, which is liquid with some of the oils: and wrap it up with linen, and treat it with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	And your treasure for treatment is, that you should guard against all devices, so that it does not consolidate, according to the form which it had in the beginning.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	And this operation which we have described is no other than a certain correction of Alxatrati, so that it does not return to the form of the place from which it was entirely removed.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	On the treatment of a condition in the lower eyelid, and is wrinkling or tightening up upwards towards the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	Chapter XVIII: Head.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	This Alxatrati which happens below is what is called Alxatrati.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	And it is either natural or accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	Accidental happens from a wound, or a rift, or cauterization, and similar things.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	And when you come to the operation, so that you take hold of it now, where there is a double thread, and wet it with flesh, and let it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right until the thread reaches the two ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	Then extend the flesh towards the top with a sharp instrument, and cut it with a chisel on the side.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	If therefore the shape of the eyelid returns according to what is necessary, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	And if not, take a thread, and put it in the groove, and turn it with it; and find the two grooves on the inner side of the eyelid, and the ends of the two grooves are from two cutting angles, until they meet and form this shape, and is a Greek letter.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	Then take away that flesh according to the quantity, which is the sharp lower side of it, from there because it follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	Then bring together the separated parts: sew them with a sheep's wool thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	Then take care of them with that which I have said, about medicinal herbs, and bindings, until they are healed.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	And if a sutural or caustic has occurred from the groove, and stitching: then you must find a flat groove under the eyelids, also according to what came before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	Then separate the two lips with a binding, according to what we have said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	And the whole speech about the care of a sutural, when it is on top, or below, it is that it runs in that operation, according to what is prepared from the form of a sutural.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	For it is of many different forms: and the prudent craftsman prepares his mind with whatever way is possible for him, until he returns the form to a natural one, or close to it, and himself, because it suits him, from the operation and the instruments in many dispositions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	Of the adhesion of the eyelid of the eye with the conjunctiva, or the cornea.
Caput XV.	Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	When this consolidation occurs in many people so that the upper eyelid is consolidated with the whiteness of the eye, and prevents itself from its natural operations.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	It is necessary that you introduce the extreme of the radius under the eyelid, and lift it up: or that you extend it with a hook: then you cut the adhesion with a fine chisel that it is not with the keenness of the incision of the chisels, but rather it is slightly blunt: so that the sick person does not disturb at the operation, and moves the chisel, and hurts his eye with his keenness: and your incision is almost like you remove this adhesion with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and heals all the adhesion.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	Then pour at that time in the eye water from salt, with water wash it: or distill in it from a sieved substance, from dissolved zinc with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a line of thread: and put over the eye wool infused with white of egg: and after three days use the sieved, and with solid things, until it heals.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	Regarding the incision of the nail and eminence of the flesh of tears.
Caput XVI.	Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	You know that the nail is according to two ways.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	Or it is nervous: and it is similar to syphac hard wood, fine.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	Or it is not nervous, similar to frozen moisture of white: which when it touches iron, or conaries it with a hook, is cut off, and does not form an incision in it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	And both species do not begin, unless from the greater tear, until it is gradually revealed, so that it forms a little by little, and prevents light and eye movement.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the way of doing this incision is: so that the sick person puts his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	Then open his eyes, and raise his eyelids with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	Then take the toenail with a little hook and extend it towards the top.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	Then take the toenail, and insert a pin from the horse's hair, or a twig: and make the thread strong, and double its end slightly, and fasten it in the middle of the nail: then pierce it with a needle, and bind it with a thread to the nail, and extend it towards the top: and scour the skin on the side of the nail which follows the pupil, as if you were holding it with a pin all the way up to its base.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	Then cut away the residue at the base of the tear with a fine spatula or small forceps: and let go of the natural tear tissue so that it does not stop the flow of tears.
