Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	And when the nail is extended with just an hook: or with a thread, as we have said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	Then scour it with a soft spatula, which has this shape.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	And be careful so that the spatula does not touch the horny tunic, and do not cause a tear, and do not pierce the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then after the cutting, pour into the eye some crushed salt, or made from a paste of zinc: and let it rest until the next day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	Then take care of the eye with whatever is necessary until it heals.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	If the nail is not nerve-laden, and you cannot get a hook into it, and there is no holding it with an uncinus: then often treat this kind of nail with medicines, and heal it like narrh (a certain plant) in its distribution.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	If you want to cut it, then open the eye for nursing, and take a fine spatula, mild of sharpness, in this shape.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	And carefully scrape the nail from top down with subtlety.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	If you see that the eye itself is getting thinner and narrower, and impressing it into the nail: then pour into the eye at your own hour from a paste made of zinc, or red ochre, or ground salt: and coat the eye until the next day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	Then he continued to operate on it, until he had completely removed it.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	Unless you have a red hot poultice in your eye: then indeed let go of it, and take care of the pustule until it heals.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	Then he continued to operate on it with a razor, until it healed.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	Except the glory of the flesh of the eye, if it hurts much in the eye, let it be suspended with an anchor, and cut from that part of it; and do not make the last incision, lest the course of tears run away.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	Then add a drop of red rub to the tear, or make it with a lead pen, until it heals.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	Regarding the incision of Algordano and the flesh born in the eye.
Caput XVII.	Chapter XVII.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	Is sometimes born in the eyes of some men with a red flesh, either placed above or combined with it until it covers the pupil, or approaches or tightens on the eyelids, and perhaps turns them outward: and is absorbed into the rosy balastine.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	And the operation on it also is, that he shall put his sick head in your bosom.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	Then open her eyes, and take all that flesh with an anchor suitable to it: and hold it with one clamp, or gesturing.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	Then cut the flesh first, until you have completely finished cutting it with a knife.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	And cause her to leave the eye, lest you wound it during the operation: and let your incision be wherever you cut it, or with a small chisel, which we have spoken of in the incision of the nail: or with little hooks, with which Asbel is collected, according to which it shall be after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	When your incision is completed and all the Algordano has been removed, then fill her eye with dissolved salt: or distill into it red powder, and similar drugs from the coroner's corrode: and put on her eye a cottage with alume, that she may be secure from the hot poultice.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	If anything remains of the socket, and hot blood flows to you, and the swelling is warm: then let go of the eye, and take care of the socket itself while it sleeps.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	Then bandage again over the eye with the operation, until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	And do likewise for the flesh added which has happened in the eye from this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	However, it is necessary that you refrain from any cure for a weak eye that comes from natural causes, or from accidental causes, with the iron; and do not insert your hand into any of these operations, until you are certain, that that member is able to endure that operation.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	On the collection of sebaceous matter from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	Chapter XVIII.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	These are small red worms that grow on the eye, and prevent the sight; and weaken the eye with the passage of time.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	Therefore it is necessary that you should first consider, if the eye in which Sebel is, is strong, and has no other disease besides Sebel: then gather Sebel from it.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	And is, as you command the sick person, to put his head in your lap.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	Then hang those worms with a single hook, or two according to your discretion: and let the hook be thin, according to this form, or let there be two hooks placed at a distance in the body, according to this form.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	Then with subtle hook-like instruments gather those worms with subtlety, and wipe away the blood hour by hour, until the worms come out from under the eye, and dissolve: and do not leave the eye with the tips of spatulums.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	And let your operation be in the middle of the day before the sun, and be firm in your operation greatly: so that you do not fall but on those worms.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	And when you have drained (it), then distil into the eye strong cider, or red wine: so that its acridity may corrode what remains of Sebel.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	But if you are not able to collect that whole thing in that hour, then bind the eye with that, which sits [the eye] comfortably: and dismiss him for a few days, until his pain is satisfied; and secure him from the heat of an apoplexy: and then repeat over it again in the same way, until he is healed.
Et haec est forma forficis.	And this is the form of the forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	The reduction of a torn nostril to the nose.
Caput XIX.	Chapter XIX.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	The doctors name the nostril-fistula, which they treat with a caustic or with an acute medicine, according to what went before in his narrative.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	And if he is not healed, then there is no skill in it: unless you find out on an apoplexy near his birth, and drain all the moisture that is in him and the pus, until the opening is discovered.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	When therefore the opening is discovered, and you see in it corruption or blackening, then cut it out with an instrument, the form of which is as follows.
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	And it is called the asperity of the head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	Let it be made of iron bar and let the head be round like a ball, that it may be punctured with a file or with fine chisel-notching: and place the piece on the site of the corruption of the bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	Then turn the piece between your fingers and press your hand upon it slightly, until you know that that corruption is now rasped: and do so often.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	Then restore the place with acute medicine of stiptic.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	If therefore the place is consolidated, and a bone grows up in it, and the wound heals over: and remains for forty days, and does not renew, and does not open again, you shall know that he is now healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	And if not, then there is no skill in it, except to reduce the fistula into the nostril, according to this form.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	And it is, so that you can detect the bone with iron, or with acute medicine: and when the bone has been detected, then take a chisel according to this form, its end being a triangle: and let the wood of it be extended towards the end like a pyramid: as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	Then place that above his own skull. And let it be near the lacrimal bone. And extend your hand from the eye a little way.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	Then turn your hand with the knuckles toward the skull, so that it penetrates the bone and feels weak. Through this he will see that vapor is emerging from him when he holds his hand over his nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	Therefore then restore the position with the syringes that dry out, as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	When then the flesh is born and the place hardens. Then the matter that flowed outward returns to the nose. So it is lighter above the weak one.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	On the reduction of the prominence of the eye.
Caput XX.	Chapter 20: On reducing the prominence of the eye
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	When the eye emanates with its entirety, and does not happen to damage the vision or diminish it: then you should remove the weak one: then you should bleed him: then you should place the cooling agents on the skin without scarring, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	Then put over the eye a liniment that is made from oak-galls, and aloe, and myrrh, and white-olibanum, and chalk-lime.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	Then tighten the eye slightly above the plaster with a mixture of many powders.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	And the mode of the powders is: that you take soft cloths, many, and double all the cloths out of them, four by four: make from them many: then put them one on top of the other, second by quantity what the eye needs: then tighten them over themselves with a hard cloth, strong tightening.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	And again place the cooling agents without scarring, but with suction.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	Then remove the cooling agents and release the eye, tightening it slightly during the day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	If however the ligature softens again, then you should tighten it a lot: then remove the ligature after day and night, as we have said.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	If then the eyes of the eye are already red with new ligatures, it is good: and if not, then again the plasters, and the tightening, and the cooling agents, until they heal.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	Regarding the incisions, there are two types of tunica.
Caput XXI.	Chapter 21. On the incision.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	When a rupture occurs in the Vein of King Henry, then it is cut and moved outside the eyelids like a grain of King Henry's seed, and its shape is made into that of a human being so that it can be incised: then the operation on it is this, according to what the surgeon says: and it is, so that you insert the sharp instrument into the root of King Henry from below to above.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	Then introduce another sharp instrument where there is a double filament from the lacrimal part, and let it penetrate: then let go of the first one according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	Then incision is made on the place of the double filament, and the King Henry's Vein part with it is tied around the acu-tip: and tighten it very much.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	Then extract it now, and place on the eye a woolen thread soaked in white of egg: and let go of it until the filament falls with King Henry' Vein.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then take care of the eye with it, which comforts it, until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	And when King Henry' Vein is tightened from all sides with a circle of cloth so that the eye protrudes greatly.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	Then it is pierced with a thin spatula that reaches to the depth of the eye, and the tearful white fluid comes out, and the eye goes down, and is immediately inserted: then tighten it, until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	The Cure of Alcomat.
Caput XXII.	Chapter 22. On the cure of Alcomat
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	This ailment called Alcomat, is not anything else but a kind of mucus gathered in the eye, similar to flowing water, and it is not itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	And the way to operate on it is this, that you make the sick person sit on a prepared seat, or directly facing upwards.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	Then take his head in your hands from the two parts, and move it so that the mucus reaches to the lower eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	Then tighten it, so that it does not fall, and the light is kept in its place: and let the sick person see things as they are: and if it does not go down below, you shall know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	But if he does not prepare the descent of the wound with him as we have said, then make the sick person sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	Then take a thin spittle and find with him above the corneal membrane a little at the place of the intersection with the corneal envelope on the crown, until it is discharged.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	When it is discharged, then dilute in the eye a hot water in which you have mixed honey: or water in which you have already boiled millet and honey: then let it be cared for with the rest of the cure, until it heals.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	As for the care of water that has entered the eye, or a waterfall.
Caput XXIII.	Chapter XXIII
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	We have already spoken about the kind of water, and what is appropriate for piercing with a revealing and explaining speech, then take that same thing according to health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then it is necessary that you make the sick person sit between your hands square, opposite to the light, near the sun: and bandage the healthy eye, and tighten it firmly: then with your hand close to the healthy eye, and with your left hand if the eye in which the water is is on the right: or with your left hand, if the eye is on the left.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	Then take with your hand on the right an almond, if the eye is on the left: or with your left hand, if the eye is on the right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	Then put the tip of the almond close to the crown by the thickness of the radius in the same white of the eye apparent tear of a little one: then push the almond with force: and you roll it with your hand, until it penetrates into the membrane of the eye: and you feel that the almond has already reached the watery part.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	And it is necessary so that the distance of the almond to the bottom is a measure of space which is from the pupil until the end of blackness: and this is the crown of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	You will see it in the same pupil with an eye-watery vision, because of the clarity of the corneal envelope.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	Then put the alмагest until the place where is water.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	Then press the lower part with a single lever after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	If then water has descended at once, then the sick person will see that which opens his own viscus at once, and the almagest in its eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	Then you rest a little.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	If then water has descended, then put it down again, except that the almagest should come out.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	When then does it form, and does not rise up: then pull out the almagest with ease: and you relax your hand little by little.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	Then dissolve in water a little of the clear salt from the gem: and wash with it the inner eye.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	Then put outside all the crust, or wool dipped in oil rosined, and wax: and binds with it the healthy eye.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	But we, and those who are of our time, put on him crushed cumin mixed with wheat flour.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	That if the almagest does not obey you at the entrance to the eye because of its hardness, since it is from men, and whose eye is very hard: then you should take a staff, which is called an alberid, whose this is the form.
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	Then open it with him alone the connection only, and not the end of your hand in the hole: and is there only to make a way for the almagest's place soft.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	Then introduce the almagest, according to what we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	And near the end of your work, prepare for the sick person a dark room in which to sleep on his back in a house that is dark: and prohibit from all movements, and coughing: and do not let him move his head to the right, or at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	And sit fast by his side according to its position until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	Then dissolve it in that dark house, and test his viscus: and let him see things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	Then reduce the ligaments until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	And it is not fit that he should make that operation at the hour of cure, nor yet immediately after the incision: but rather, let him wait until another day: because the water riseth soon through the rough skin.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	But if it happens that the swelling is hot: then it is fit that thou shalt open his eye before the seventh day: and rectify that which is wrong with him, when he doth lie down, until that the swelling hath been healed: then thou shalt let go his water, and put it on his mouth where it goeth under him for some days, while he dwelleth in that dark house.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	Then let him go out of the house little by little, and let him turn round in his bed.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	And knowest thou not that the student is exempt from sight sometimes for a few days? Then let him dare to speak about the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	And now it is come to our ears that a certain one from Al-Rajah has said, "It hath been done in Al-Rajah by means of a piercing, whereby the water is drawn.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	But truly I have not seen anyone in the land of the Arabs do such a thing; nor have I found it in any of the old books: but it is possible that it may be new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	And these are the forms of the wounds from the piercing, that they stand above them who know not.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	Let them be made of pure brass; and let their ends be of this same triangular sutilty, and the point sharp.
Formae magda.	The forms of the piercing.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	On the care for the flesh that is born in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	Chapter XXIII.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	When and what kinds of flesh are added to the flesh that is born in the nose, from which something is made that assimilates the scorpion of many feet: and from this is the flesh of cancer, the lapia, of a pale color; and from this is the meat that is soft, not of a pale color.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	In that which is of the said meats soft and not deceitful, nor cancerous, it is fit that thou shouldest cause him to sit between thine hands opposite to the sun, and open his nostrils, and put in a sharp hook on the side: then draw them towards the exterior, and cut what thou hast taken from them with a sharp and subtle chisel: then shalt thou know that all the flesh is now removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	If anything remains that cannot be cut off: then carefully remove it with a fine instrument until nothing is left.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	If, however, blood is in control of you, or an injury occurs that is warm and swollen: then oppose it with what is necessary; or if it is a malignant apoplexy, then approach cauterizing it, until the blood is cut off, and all flesh is removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	Then let it be applied to the nose after cutting with vinegar, and water, or wine.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	If, however, the nose is opened, and moisture proceeds from it all the way to the palate, then you shall know that he is already well.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	If, however, the moisture does not penetrate, as it should, then you shall know that within the upper bones of the nose there is a birthmark which the knife cannot reach.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	Then it is necessary that you insert a thread of linen which has some grossness, and many nodules in it: and place between each nodule the length of your finger, or less: and let him sneeze, so that he sends one end of the thread into his nose with a ray, or with whatever is possible for him to do after he has done this himself; and let him sniff, until it reaches his throat, and then let him spit it out.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	And many times indeed do these boys make this atom similar in schools; and it is a easy thing for him who wants to do it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	Then place the two ends of the thread, one which goes out over the nose, and the other which remains in the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	Then tie a knot in the thread with the nodules that are in the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	Make it tight so that you shall know that the flesh is already with the nodules in the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	Then pull out the thread: and put into the nose after the removal of blood the liquid that you have imbibed in Egyptian ointment: make it three days, or more, until the ointment has eaten away all that remained of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	Then place at the end of the thing a cannula of lead in the nose for several days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	If it does not heal with the cure that dries up, then use that one.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	For the cure for nosebleeds, when they are distilled with oil and other medicines into the nose, make it of silver or brass: that it be similar to a small lantern, opened like a shell: and its passage also.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	And if you want to make a closed cannula, like a reed.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	And the shell of the instrument for the cure of nosebleeds should be full, and well-sealed: whose handle is at the end of it, which you hold when you heat oil in it, or what you want to pour into it, and fluid things.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	And this is the shape of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	On the cure for nosebleeds.
Caput XXV.	Chapter 25. On the Cure of Nosebleeds
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	Nosebleeds often arise at the end of the nose and become more severe and greater with the passing of days until they appear like a wound.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	And for this, when it first appears, you should cut it all out.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	Then place over the spot, or a caustic, or burning medicine that stands in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	If the incision is then delayed until it becomes more severe, consider it, if it is hard, dry in color, and of few senses: then do not touch it with iron: for it is a cancerous spot.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	For many times water has incised the flesh and led to great evil in that place which had it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	And if the spot is not hard and of few senses, and you see that the incision can be made in all of it, then make the sick person well, and cut him without fear or hesitation: and cure the place along with it, until it heals over.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	On the sewing up of the nose, lips, and ears.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter 26.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	You should know that when a break occurs in one of the cartilages of the nose, surgery is not effective unless in certain people.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Therefore, when such a thing has happened to someone, you should consider whether it is a recent fracture with its own blood: and then add two wounds together with sutures: and then take care of the wound until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	And if the break has already separated the lips, and some healthy parts have been formed: then it is necessary that you cut off all of its skin from the outside, until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	Then add two lips together with sutures, and tie them tightly, and sprinkle the wound with dragon's blood, and crushed holly; and put over the powder a fragment of plaster of Paris, and some other consolidated plaster: and let it be bound for two days, or three.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	Then loosen it, and change the medicine: and let it go, until the hairs grow together by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound with ointment, until it heals.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	The method of suturing is, to add the solution of a break, or with needles, as we have told you about suturing an eye; or to add the solution with a thread, as I have made you aware.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	On the extraction of nodules from the lips:
Caput XXVII.	Chapter 27.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	Many people have hard nodules in the inner part of their lips, similar to small grains of herbs; and some of them are smaller, and others are larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	Therefore, you should turn the lips inside out, and find all the nodule, and hang it by a hook, and drop it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	Then fill the space under the cut with dried blood that has been crushed, until the blood is dried up.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	Then clean it with vinegar, and wash the place with it, where there is pain, until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	Of the incision born of flesh on the gingivae.
Caput XXVIII.	De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	Often a flesh-born wound arises on the gingivae, which the ancients called abluss.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	So it is necessary that you should hang her by a hook; or that you hold her with forceps and cut her close to her root, and let the blood run away, or let the blood flow.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	Then place on the sore-affected part a dried poultice, or other stimulating powders, drying agents.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	That if that flesh returns after cure, it often does so again; then cut it again and cauterize it: for she never returns after cauterization.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	Of the shaving of teeth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	De rasione dentium cum ferro, ut neque fac
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	When the teeth are聚e together in the surface of the tooth from the inner and outer side, and between the gingivae hard tissue, rough hairs, and sometimes wear away, and become yellowed, and white-ish, until the corruption extends to the gingiva, and the teeth become rotten by that.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	So it is necessary that you should place the sick hand between your hands, and the head of the patient in your lap, and shave off the molars and teeth on which appear to you the gums, and similar material like sand: until there remains nothing of them, and likewise do the same for the blackness, and whiteness, and yellowing, and other disorders until they are cleansed.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	If then that which is in them from the beginning of shaving is removed, it is good: but if not, then repeat the shaving on them every other day, and third time, until the final study has come to them what you want.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	And you should know that the teeth are used to different shapes of razors, and to many figures: second, the razor with which it is ras ed from below is different from the razor with which it is ras ed between teeth, according to other forms.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	These forms of razors are prepared for you, which you see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	Regarding the extraction of pain from teeth.
Caput XXX.	Chapter 30.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	It is necessary that you treat the tooth with all your skill and quickly remove it from the source of pain.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	For the tooth should not be left to heal on its own when it is removed, as the substance is delicate: until a time when there is no excuse for the removal of it, then it should be removed carefully, and certified by you to the complaining patient.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	For many times pain deceives the sick person, and he thinks that the pain is in the tooth and removes it himself: afterwards, he does not cease to have pain until the tooth is removed from the source of pain.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	For we have already seen this from the operation of bloodletting.
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	When, therefore, the tooth is certified to you by the complaining patient, then it should be scraped with a small scraper, which has some strength, until the gum is completely removed from all sides: then, with your fingers or with delicate forceps, slowly cut off the tip, until you hear it crack.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	Then, when you have well positioned the forceps in the good place, and the head of the patient is between his knees: which you hold well, so that it does not move: then, pull the tooth along its straight line, so as not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	If, however, it does not come out, then take one of their instruments and push it in from all sides with ease, and try to move it, as you did before.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	If, however, the tooth is either pierced or corroded: then it should be filled with cloth: and you should hold it with a small hook at its tip, so that it does not break when you squeeze it with forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	And it is necessary, so that you do not get the scraping around the gum well.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	And keep your strength, so that you do not break it, and a part of it remains, and returns to the sick from which greater pain comes at first.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	And so, do not do that which the phlebotomators do in their haste, and their boldness in eradicating it, except that they administer to it what we have related.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	For often they bring about great sicknesses in men, which are more difficult to be broken, and leave the roots of them all, or some part thereof; or take it out with certain bones of the jaw: as we have been frequently assured that this is done.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	Then let it be cleansed after its eradication with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	That if a flux of blood should come from the places (for often it comes) then let some of the plaster be removed and filled with the blood, and let that place be so; and if not, let it be cauterized, if it does not give you plaster.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	The shapes of the pincers should be such that they move easily at first, and then do not open when pressure is applied to them on the tooth: they should be like the large fingers, until when you press them they do not open themselves, nor do they open; their ends should be thick, and made of iron or of a hard pewter, straight ends: and in their ends should be teeth, some of which enter into certain ones, and close by constriction, so as to bite strongly.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	And when they are made at the ends like the shape of an ear which is called a crow, and are of strong constriction.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	Of the eradication of teeth and extraction of bones of the jaw fractured.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	When a tooth is broken and something remains after its eradication, then let it be placed on the place with butter one day, or two days, until it softens: then let it be inserted into it with a chisel, or a pincers; their ends should be like an ear which is called a crow.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	The shape of this pincher is as follows.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	Have the extremities made as a file inside: or like an alligator's skin.
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	But if he does not obey you to the exit with these tweezers, then you should caustice on the root, and peel off all the flesh, and insert an instrument called a small tongs, whose shape is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	Set short the end, a little longer the thick one: and let it not be dipped, lest it should break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	But if the root goes out by that, it is good: and if not, you should move with these other instruments whose shapes are these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	The shape of the first end, in which there is some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	The shape of the slim end.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	Also move with this instrument having two branches, whose shape is this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	And with the other instruments and tools which have gone before in the order of teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	Also sit the clamp with this instrument which is like a big hook, of this shape, of the twisted slim end, in which there is some thickness, so that it should not break: and let it not be dipped, lest it should break.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	And know that there are many instruments for teeth: and the other instruments also do not count, and the prudent artisan discovers himself alone the instrument, according to which signified to him the operation and illnesses themselves.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	For from diseases there are to those for which the ancient instrument did not speak, because of the diversity of their species.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	But if a bone breaks from the jaw, or from any other bones of the mouth, then examine above it at its place with that which belongs to it out of the instruments and tweezers which I have spoken in extracting the root, and move with the gesture, whose shape is this.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Set at it some thickness gradually, so that it is stretched, or held with it the jaw bone, and does not move and push, until it goes out the jaw: and restore the place with suitable medicines for it.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	If, however, there is pus in the bone, then saw off the part affected by the pus and treat it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	Of the important locking of teeth on others.
Caput XXXII.	Chapter III. On the locking of teeth.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	When teeth are not at their natural angle, they become rotten from the form of the mouth; and especially when this happens to women and girls, that is, young people.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	It is necessary for you to consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	For if one tooth has come after another, and does not fit in place, nor can its lock be made or the grinding be done; then you should cut it out: and if it is joined to a neighboring tooth, then you should cut it with this instrument, of which the following form is.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	It is like a small chisel, and is made of hard iron, with an acute end.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	And let your cut be deep, so that you cut it over many days, and because of the hardness of the tooth, and so that it does not move one of the other teeth.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	If, however, there is a prominent exposure of its grinding: then grind it with a chisel made of hard iron, the form of which is as follows.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	It should all be made of iron, and the small point of its tip should be ground off like a chisel, as is done with an awl: so that the tooth can be grating little by little over many days with ease, so that it does not move the teeth, and then allow it to be sharpened at the end, grinding it with some rasps.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	If a tooth is broken off, and hurts the tongue: then you should also sharpen that part, until it is smooth, and make it even: and then smooth it out, so that it does not hurt the tongue, nor damage speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	On the retention of teeth with gold fill.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter III. On the retention of teeth with gold fill.Si D
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	When there is a blow and jolt to the anterior teeth from a blow, or by accident: and it cannot be held fast to its place, so that it falls out: and it does not improve with careful treatment, then take a sharp wire and retain them with gold: because gold turns green, and spoils after many days; but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	And let there be a thread medium in subtility and coarseness according to the quantity that it takes between teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	And the form of retraction is such that you take a thread and introduce it between two healthy teeth: then tie it with both ends between them, or one or more, until you come to the other side of the tooth with the thread.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	Then iterate the texture until the part from which you began: and tighten your hand with subtlety and wisdom, until it does not move at all: and let your constriction be where you tighten the thread, near the roots of the teeth, so that it does not move.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	Then cut off the ends of the thread with the forceps: and gather both together, and bend them with your hand: and hide them between a healthy tooth and a moving tooth, so that they do not hurt the tongue: then let it be loosened in such a way as to remain strict.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	If however it has loosened, or has been cut, tighten them with another thread, and let it stand with it in such a way for all the time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	And this is the form of the teeth, and the figure of retraction of two healthy teeth and two moving teeth, as you see them.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	And when it is that one tooth has fallen, or two behind in its place, and remains as we have described, and does not make it except the craftsman be skilled, prudent, and experienced.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	And when one of the ribs is broken: and it is made out of it like the form of a tooth, and is put in its place, from which it is protected, and tightened, as we have said: and remains, and adheres to it for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	Regarding the incision of the ligament that happens under the tongue, and prevents it from speaking.
Caput XXXIIII.	Head 34.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	When the ligament which happens under the tongue, is either natural, with which man is born, or accidental, from an arrow that has already healed.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	And the operation is, so that you open the jaw of the patient in his head in your neck and clear his tongue; and then cut this nerve ligament across its width until the tongue is released from its hold.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	If there is anything hard and stiff in it and it is from the consolidering of a wound, then throw into it a hook and cut it across its width until you hit the ligament, and let go of the stiffness.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And let him not make a crack in the deep flesh there, and cut the artery there, and let there be a flow of blood.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	Then rinse the incision with rosewater, or vinegar, or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	Then put under the tongue a piece of linen that holds the weak one all night, so that it does not harden again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	But if there is a flow of blood, then put on the place a crushed piece.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	But if you are pricked by blood, then cauterize the place with a lentil cautery that suits it; and then care for him with the rest of the cure, until he heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	The extraction of a sore that is under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter LXXXI.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	When a little sore under the tongue is absorbed that has become like a small rana, prohibiting the tongue from its natural function: and perhaps it grows bigger so much that the jaw is filled up.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	And the operation is, so that you open the jaw without a doctor with the sun: and consider the sore.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	But if you see that the color of the sore is dark, or black, or hard, and there is no feeling for it of the patient: then do not touch it, for it is a cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	And if it falls into whiteness, in which there is moisture, then throw into it a hook, and cut the sore with a very fine awl, and free it from all sides.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	If your blood pricks you in the hour of your surgery, then put under the sore a crushed piece, until the blood stops flowing: and then return to your surgery, until it is extracted from its bulk with its supplement.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then clean with vinegar and salt: and care for it with suitable cure until it heals.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	The treatment of abscesses of the two amygdales.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	When abscesses occur between the cheeks, that is, the glands, which are akin to abscesses, and which occur on either side: when cure with the above-mentioned method does not help them, then observe.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	If, however, the abscess is hard, of a pale colour, and of little smell: then do not touch the abscess with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	And if its colour is red, and its root is thick: then do not touch it with iron, fearing a flow of blood, but leave it, until it heals.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	And then either pierce it: or let it burst of itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	And if its colour is white, round, and its root is thin: then the abscess should be opened.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	And the operation on it is such that you should consider before the operation whether the abscess is hot and quiet, completed, or rather threatened with some decrease: then let him sit down in front of the sun, and place his head in your lap: and open his mouth, and take hold between his hands, and press his tongue down with a tool, which has this shape.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	Let it be made of silver, or of brass, that it may be sharp like a knife.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	When you press it with the tongue and a swelling appears on your side: then take hold of a hook, and fix it in the amygdal, and draw it out as far as you can, pulling with it some of the skin.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	Then open it with the instrument which has this shape.
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	It is joined to the other by a ligament: therefore take care that its ends are not cut, so that the opening of each of them is in the direct line of the other: hence the cure should be with iron ingot, or an alloyed copper.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	If this instrument is not present, then cut it with a chisel, which has this form.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	This blade should be sharp on one side and dull on the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	And when you cut one side of the cheekbone, cut the other second according to this form of cutting.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	Then after the incision, the patient should gargle with cold water or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But if there is a flow of blood, gargle with water in which the bark of the willow has been boiled: or leaves of myrtle and like things from the astringent, until the flow of blood stops: and then take care of the wound, until it heals.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	And when there are blisters in the throat that are not attached to the two cheekbones.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	Then cut these according to what I have said in cutting the two cheekbones evenly.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	And I have already treated a woman with a blisters that had grown between her throat, which was causing hoarseness, little sense, and almost closed her throat: and this woman breathed through my narrowed throat, and had already stopped eating, drinking water, and was close to death if it had lasted another day or two.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	And the blister had risen only as much as to make two small bumps, until they had come out of the two nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	So I hurried along and fixed myself on one of their hooks.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	Then I pulled it out, and a large piece came out with it.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	Then I cut it off where it had come out of the nostril hole.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	Then I made her go forward from the other nostril hole.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	Then I opened her mouth and touched her tongue: and then fixed the hook in the blister: and then cut off a part of it, and there was little blood coming out of it: so the woman's throat is absolutely well, and she began to eat right away.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	I did not stop to put on a lot of times for a long time: and the poultice succeeded in place where I hit, until it was too prolonged and with him that thing.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	So then, I put a poultice on it between the teeth.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	Then he stayed away from the addition: then I walked away from that part, and I don't know what God did with it after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	On the poultice on the wound.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter 37. On the poultice on the wound.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	When a catarrh descends to the wound, and is poulticed, and it is long: then it is called perpendicular; and if it is in the lower part thick, round, then it is called a pouch.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	When it is treated with what we said about the separation, and does not bring about a cure; and you see that the poultice has grown cold from it, and has thinned out: then you should hit it.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	And what is gathered together on it round, and has no length, and is bloody or dark in color, or black, and has no feeling: then you should hit the incision.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	For in that poultice there is a fear over the wound.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	Then when you see it in the way that I said out of whiteness, and according to its length, so that you set the sick person before the sun: and press his tongue with an instrument, whose predecessor I told you; then fasten a hook on the wound, and pull it down: and hit it with one or two instruments which I said for hitting the two amygdales.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	And you should not hit out of it, unless that which is added to it on a natural limit without addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	For if you hit out of it more, then you wound the voice and speech.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	Then after hitting it use what I told you in the incision of the two amygdales: and take care of it, until it heals.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	If however the sick person shudders from the incision: then you should use your wit in cauterizing it without fear and anxiety.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	And the mode of cauterization is not in her, except with sharp water: and it is, as you put the head of the nurse in your bosom.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	Then press her tongue with the instrument which we have said.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	Then take from the water which I have told you in the chapter of cauterizing, and bind it to this foot that is not extinguished, and put it not thick or thin, and fill it with this instrument whose this form is.
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	Sit at the end of her where the medicine is placed, as the ear is placed on the radius.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	And place the instrument with the medicine on its upper part: and the sick man shall lie on his side, that he may run a salve from his mouth by internal medicine, so that nothing shall descend from it to his throat, and harm him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	And you from the first shall put on her on a small quantity of the medicine at an hour's time, until you see it has become black, and has eased the tingling of the medicine.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	And if you will that you take a cup, and pour it on him on the end of the radius, and dip the cup with the medicine, and push the radius with the cup into the canula from above, until the cup adheres to the upper part.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	Do this many times, until you get what you want in the new cauterization.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	Then dismiss her: for she will be cured and will fall down after three days, or four.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	That if you will be cured that you go the medicine, repeat it: and after the cauterization wash about her a new one with the butter, and purify with it what is in her from the medicine: and rinse with cold water.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	And he will be cured outwardly with embrocations, and inwardly with gargles, until he is healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	This then is the nature of the cure, more salutary than incising, and farther removed from fear.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	And when ever it is necessary to treat with a ring and also with the thread that is thinner than the cautery and incision: for this reason it should be treated with sufumigation in this way.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	And when ever it is necessary to treat with a ring and also with the thread that is thinner than the cautery and incision: for this reason it should be treated with sufumigation in this way. Take also sumac, hyssop, oregano, rue, sseah (a kind of mint), chamomile, abrotan (mistleto), and similar herbs; and put all of them together, or some of them in a vessel, and immerse them with vinegar and make them boil: and the vessel should be covered with an uneven cloth: and a hole should be made in the middle of the vessel above which should be placed a sharp instrument according to this method.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	Let it be made of silver or of brass; and the end in which is the granule should be put into the nosepiece until the vapour ascends to the tube over the cannula until it is very dark.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	Then repeat this many times, until it burns.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	And do not make this cure at the beginning if there is a wound.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	For this reason, add it to the wound, and do not make this cure unless it is at the decline of the heat of the wound.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.
