If this instrument is not present with you, then take a tube and fit an end with wax so that it does not burn the nose: for the wax prevents the vapour from burning the nose; and this is good cure with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	Regarding the extraction of spines and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Often a tooth or a spine or a bone would adhere to the throat.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Then you should extract what is visible above what causes the pain, when you press the tongue with an instrument against the light and tell me that it is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And if what is hidden in the throat does not appear to you, you should make a sick person fast before food digests in his stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps the part attached to the body should exit through the umbilicus.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Perhaps the sick person should swallow a dry piece of bread, or a leaf of lettuce, or swallow a dry cracker: or take a dry sea sponge and consume it; and bind it with a string, and then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When therefore he has reached the place where there are bristles or a tooth, and is removed (from the body), then he comes out.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If, however, he does not come out with it as I have said above: then use an instrument made of tin in the form of a funnel.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than the radius by a little bit, and at its end let there be a roundness that can easily be inserted into his throat: and he himself should hold his head raised up.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him avoid touching his epiglottis, so that he does not cough, and pushes (the food) with it into his mouth, or inserts a bristle or a tooth with his own hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	But because the sick person swallows it, that is better: according to his knowledge of the site of the attached part; and he pushes down or holds up his hand with the instrument, all this according to the quantity prepared for him, until he comes out.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	Regarding the extraction of blood:
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter 39.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When you treat with blood-suckers as I have said above in the division of cure with the medicines, and they do not yield, then note in the throat in front of the light, or near to the light after having touched his tongue with the instrument that I have told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If your yawn falls on a blood-sucker, extract it with a small hook, or with subtle movements, and turn it away.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If it is not possible with them: then take a closed tube and insert it into the throat up to the place where the throat meets; and then insert into the tube an ignited iron with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Make it many times over: and the sick person should abstain from all water during the day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then he shall take a full cup of cold water and open his mouth to it; and he shall set his mouth to hers and swallow nothing from it; and he shall moisten the water with his hand an hour after another.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For a leech will fall at once when he feels the water.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	But if he does not go out with him as we have described, then he will smoke the sick with lice, or with a tube as an instrument that we described in smoking the uvula.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, for she will fall herself.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the mode of operation in smoking is that you take a bowl, in which there are the uvulae of the louse with fire; and the bowl is covered with a cover, in whose middle there is an opening; and the end of the instrument is placed in it.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then you will throw the smoke and put the sick person's mouth at the end of the tube, and close his mouth so that he does not go out with the smoke until you know that the smoke has reached the leech.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech falls immediately.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If he does not fall, then repeat the smoking many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And the sick person will bear hunger, and eat food, and other things, and will not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he go out with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument from which the leech is removed from the throat when he falls on it and sticks to it.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to pincers, as you see: unless there is a small hole that enters into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its end is similar to an ear, which is called a cicogna, in which there is the keenness of the lime; and when it grasps something, it does not let it go at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	Regarding the opening of the apotomates, and their sectioning, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter 40.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of apotomates, many ways, according to which the memory comes, namely, one, and one in this book: and they differ in the perforation of them, and in the sectioning of them from two kinds.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	There is one which is of the species of aphemia in itself, and because it comprehends from the humors.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second way is because of the places, in which it happens from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Since the aphemia happens in the head, it is different from the accident of aphemia in the anus; and the aphemia which happens in a fleshy place, it is different from the accident of aphemia in joints; and each of them has its own judgment according to operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And of the aphemias are those which do not need to pierce, except after the maturation of blood in them, and its completion; and of these are those which need to pierce when they are raw, and do not mature according to the completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	As aphemia which is near joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Since the aphemia happens when it is near a joint, and its prolongation exists until what is around it is putrefied, so that the ligaments or nerves of that joint may have腐り始め、それゆえそのメンバーの収縮の原因となる。
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or is an aphemia at a main member: for if you delay the piercing of it until it matures, it will hurt either itself or by that main member.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	Or is near a finger, so pierce it when it is immature: and do not need to pierce an raw aphemia, without completion of digestion, because it is near a finger, lest it should putrefy deep, and its lengthen to the inside of the anus, and become a fistula, or in the term of that which does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	It is necessary that you know the time of piercing the aphemia, which has matured according to completion: and it is in the sedating of pain, the receding of fever, and the diminution of rubefaction, and pulse, and acuteness of head for an aphemia: and the other signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is necessary that you make the same piercing in a lower place of aphemia, and more prominent eminence: and let the piercing be cutting along the length of the body, if aphemia are in parts of hand and foot, and places of fingers, and of chords, and nerves, and arteries, and up to the last in all equal places, which is there no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those that reflect, guide with a second perforation according to that member.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When however there is a hematoma in the fleshy places: then it is better that you should cease the perforation of it until its digestion is confirmed, as we have said, according to the complement.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you pierce it before that, the course of the virus will be prolonged from it, and it is full of dirt and stench, and perhaps it will harden its lips, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And certain hematomas are pierced according to the breadth of the body when necessary: or according to that by which the member feels pain.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer a small perforation in hematomas that are small and a wide perforation in hematomas that are large: or several sections according to the size of the hematoma.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are hematomas in which the skin must be closed up: and it happens when it has already been made like a cloth, and has reached its term, because it is already dead: like that which happened to many, such as blisters, and boils.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And there are those that cut off with three angles.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And one of them is like the figure of a fig tree's leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	As the hematoma in the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And there are those in which a round section is administered, and a lunar section: and similar ones to these sections.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	In fact, as for that which has no head, such are the superficial hematomas, you should pierce it with a superficial perforation, or just flatly.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary that when the hematoma is large, and has already gathered much blood, and you pierce it, so that it does not come out with everything, but take out a part of it: but draw out from it all at once.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then cover the hematoma until the next day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then draw out some of the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Make it many times according to a graduation, until it comes out: especially if the person is weak of vigor, or a woman who is pregnant, or a boy who is young, or an old man who is decrepitous: for the spirit of the animal often resolves from the animal with the exit of the blood: and perhaps the sick one will die, and you do not perceive it.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, this chapter is written with great caution.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have made the hole, from which you make the incisions, it should be necessary that you wash off the wound: and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	But if the wound is small or the cut is flat, then administer wine from linen, or old cheesecloth.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	But if the wound is great and there are many cuts of the incision, then you should put licorice into each crease until they have healed together.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if you have cut off a part of the skin in the wound, or if it is circumcised all around: then you should fill it with old cheesecloth, or as when the cloth is wrinkled, or scrubbed with linen thread without moisture: and bind it tightly until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then throw it away, and take care of that with it as you should with ointment, until it is healed.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	But if there is a flow of blood during your operation, then administer cold water and vinegar after it has been soaked up by the cloth: and lay it down repeatedly on the site of the bleeding.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	But if the flow of blood persists, then you should administer a regimen and treatment, and powders which I have mentioned in many places in this book, and by division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	But if it is in the wintertime and the site of the wound has many nerves: then you should put powders on it with wine and hot oil: and lay them down.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in the summer and the places are fleshy: then you should put powders soaked in water and oil, or wine and oil, and all of that cold thing.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we have said, then you should remove the wound, wash it off, and administer to it what is suitable for its cure, until it is healed.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This is therefore what is necessary from the understanding of the treatment of wounds in general.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	Indeed, according to half the distance between the two extremes, I have already spoken about all that concerns the care of the eyes, which is a way leading specifically to their cure.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	§ On the sections of the scars that occur on the scalp.
Caput XLI.	Head 31.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	On the scalp small scars occur, and they are of two kinds: nodules, which are surrounded by membranes that become sacs: they are almost like the feathers of a hen.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these scars.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Of them some are small; and of them some contain moisture similar to a lime; and of them some contain moisture similar to a dew or a mucus; and some are like stones, and some are hard.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the section of all these, nor is there any danger in their extraction, provided that you do not make a contrast with the arteries when you are cutting them out.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation on these sections is such that you should try it out with a tool whose shape has been formed after this, which is called the Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	For if it is that which contains moisture, then dry it up by a second cut along its length: in this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with the cut from line B to line G. When therefore the moisture is drained out, then remove the scab that contains this moisture, and do not leave any of it behind.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	For many times it will return if some of it remains.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then submerge the wound in Egyptian ointment if it is present, and if not, in water and salt: and fill it with the ointment, and leave it until another day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For this destroys what remains of the scab.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the application of the Egyptian ointment on the wound a second and third time, and if your hand can bear it, continue to apply the ointment until you are satisfied that there is no longer any scabs. Indeed, this care with ointment will heal the wound.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If the abscess contains a swollen nodule: then dry it up according to this form, having the shape of a cross: and throw out the hooks between the folds of the incision, and scrape it off from all parts: and try your skill in removing the tickling skin which contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	But if it makes you contrary, then do as I shall tell you after.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And also do the same in the abscess, if it is hard, from the incision, and the cure in the same way as we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the section over a hard abscess is easier: for there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes some of these abscesses which are in the head in certain men do not have any moisture inside.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	Which is this: because I followed over an abscess in the head of a married woman, and found an abscess like a solid and hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken: and if anyone hit it with a blow, he wounded the flesh.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	But in other head abscesses, apart from this, those which happen in the heads of boys, and at the roots of the ears, all of them are only superficial incisions.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or put a perforation in them always from their lower part, so that the course of the poultice goes to the lower parts.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for them with what suits them after the cure is over.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	On the section of the striae in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter LII. The head.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses often happen in the neck, and under the shoulders, and in the groin: and sometimes they happen all over the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And over those which happen from them in the neck, there is one and many: and they are born from one; and every stria comes out of its own tunica, as we have said.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And the kinds of these striae are many.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from these are the leaves; and from these are those which retain moisture; and from these are the evil ones, which do not submit to healing.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	For in that which you see good of disposition in touch, whose color is clear and close to the skin, and moves towards all sides, and is not attached to the nerves of the neck, nor to the jugulars, nor to the arteries, nor is it deep: let it be separated from the superficial section from the upper part to the lower part of the line, c. to the line, g., and scrape it off completely: and extend two skin flaps with a hook, or with multiple hooks, if you wish it, as we have said in the scalp bumps, and pull it out slowly.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is super cautelam, that not incideat venam, or nervum.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let it not be acuter than the knife sharpens: so that it does not give you a hand with the incision, or disturb the sick, and you fall into something that is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	But if you cut a vein, or an artery, or prevents you from the operation, then place in a wooden peg three times broken, or some powder that stops the blood, and tighten the peg, and let it go, until the sharpness of the bump is softened, and the peg is softened: or he begins to rot.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For the blood is stopped by the powder: so that you can proceed with your operation, until you are finished.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then examine it with your index finger, if there is anything left of the warts with a few others: so cut them and clean them up.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	For if there is a large vein in the root of the warts: then let it not be cut from its root; but let it be tied with a strong doubled thread, and let it go until it falls by itself without doing any harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the peg with old tar, which you have already immersed in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then the care for himself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the incised skin is whole, then you should gather two wounds together: and if you see that there is no excess left, then immediately stop.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	But if you see that there is excess because of the size of the Strophe, then you should understand to incise its root and remove it; and administer the suture which we have described.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And which of the Strophae contains moisture, pierce it with a superficial piercing: so that you can see the place of maturity of it: and place the piercing from there because of what follows below the body, as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then administer after the piercing with a liniment ointment and similar to it so that it corrupts what remains from corruption, until when you see that the wound has already been cleaned up: then take care of himself with a ointment for the generation of flesh, until he heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	§ On the section of the epiglottis within the throat due to accident.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancient ones said that this section of the epiglottis, and no one in our land has done it, and this is the writing of their words.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	But in those who have a synechieuzy, the section of the epiglottis should be removed: since it does not form an impediment by that means: because all the nostrils and lung are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In these, however, who have a warm aphemia in the mouth or in the throat or in both amygdali, when there is no disease in the canal, it is necessary to use the section of the epiglottis, so as to escape from the destruction which happens from pre-condition.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	It is necessary, therefore, when we want to cut this, so as to remove the epiglottis with small circles according to their size, which is between two circles according to the quantity, that it be a section in a sifil, not in a cartilage: and this place is fitting for sectioning, because it is apart from flesh, and the blood vessels are far from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If the surgeon is timid, then he should spread the skin with a hook for the gut.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he will find the skin, until he reaches the canal: he must stop the blood if he sees anything come out of it.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he will make a incision in the soft part that we have mentioned: and it is shown on the section of the canal from pus which comes out from it, with what happens when it is interrupted, and with the abruption of the voce.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And let the wound remain open for a while.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore the time is right, so that there is no fear of healing, take two lips of the wound skin, and seal it all by itself without the cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines which make flesh grow, until it heals.
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	Says Albucasis. The summary of this account, which we have mentioned, is not exposed unless it is known that the wound has already started to heal, and the sick person has been raised above death, and his anhelous desire has passed: they go to the throat to let the sick breath on a certain spot, and save him from death: for this reason they ordered to leave the wound open, until the malice of sickness is consumed, and it is as though its malice is itself: then they directed that the wound be closed, and care for himself, until he heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And this which I saw through myself, is that a servant girl took a knife and put it into her mouth, and cut off with it a part of the lung canal.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to cure her, and I found her grunting like a dead person.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	Then I removed the wound thread, and I found blood which was coming out from a small wound.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	I therefore confessed that she had not cut off the nail, and I did not know how to do it: and wind came out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	Therefore, I did not feel pain, and I cared for myself until it healed; and nothing happened to the servant girl except a sore throat, and she recovered after a few days of improved health.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore, I say that there is no fear when it comes to the epiglottis.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	Regarding the hernia of the throat.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter 44: Head
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This swelling, called a hernia of the throat, is a large swelling, second only to color, and it occurs often in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it has two causes: either natural or accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly, there is no fault in nature.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	On the other hand, it is accidental and has two similarities with the lymph nodes.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And the other mode is similar to a swelling that occurs due to the inflammation of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And there is a fear there, and it should not be assumed as such without proof, unless it is small: and you should test it and investigate it with an instrument.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If then the swelling is similar to a large lymph node and is not suspended with any veins: then cut it off as you would cut off the nodes: and remove it along with what contains it if it is in a sac: and if not, then examine it thoroughly.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the spot, as is necessary for healing, until it heals on its own.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	Regarding the section above the nodules:
Caput XLV.	Chapter 50: Head
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of nodules, and I have already spoken about their differences: it is necessary for me to describe the difference between nodules and swollen lymph nodes, as there is some doubt.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	I say that when it comes to the exit, there is heat, fever, and painful pain, until an excess of fluid boils over, and putrefaction is completed: then, indeed, the fever and heat subside.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When it comes to a nodule, there is no heat, fever, or pain, and they are contained in sacs, which are their own sacs, and are of the color of the body: and they begin as beans, and resemble a basket, and are larger and smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are of two kinds: either dry or wet.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of moisture are many, as I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you come to cure a node, you should test it and inquire about it first with the instrument called Intromissum, according to its form in the chapter which is after this one.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the method of examining pustules and all nods is, that you take this instrument and introduce it into a moistened place which you have opened in the pustule: and you shake your fingers with it slowly, until you know that the instrument has penetrated the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then you take the last hand of yours according to the size of the pustule.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then remove Intromissum and examine what comes out of his opening.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If then there comes out a running moisture, whatever its color is: then dry the skin with a section, as I said of all pustules.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	If then there does not come out moisture in the opening of Intromissum, you should know that it is fat: so dry on the skin with a section having the shape of a cross, according to this form, as I have taught you: and suspend it with hooks, and scrape the skin from all parts easily: and guard the cupping glass if you can over it, that you may drain out the healthy fluid with the Node.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If then the cupping glass breaks during the operation and it is not possible to drain out the healthy fluid, since this happens many times: then remove it quickly until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if there remains of it a little bit or much, the Node returns after many things.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	That if it wins you and remains of it a little bit: then fill the wound at your completion with some powdered corrosives acute: and tighten the bandage, and put it above the skin which sits the pustule warm, and take care of the skin with the rest of the cure, until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If then there is a large knot, then cut his two lips and care for it with him as it has become inflamed.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If however you have a new wound that pulses, or not pulsating: then approach, and fill the space under the skin with dried earth, and let it rest for two days, or three, until the tendon rots, and the bleeding stops: then go back to cutting out what is left of the knot.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	§ On the tools for cutting and drilling.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVIII. On tools for cutting and drilling.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	From these are the forms of intromission, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	For from these is a large one, and from these is a medium one, and from these is a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let there be made out of iron a quadrangular piece with depressed ends, that it may prevent the entrance of the incised part.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of percussion, and there is one, that is, the perforating: and they are of three kinds. One is called a mallet, that is, a perforator; and these are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	For from these is a large one, and a medium one, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	Let there be made out of wood the appendages, and the outlets, and the tubes, and the buboes from him who is between them from the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are round, and three-sided, and smooth, like the large needle with which the seats are supported, made of amber, or of brass, or of iron, or of silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And better ones are those made of amber.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	And there are also percussion instruments of black lead, which are to be used that they may experience the outlets, whose reflections are to be managed, so as to reflect with their softness with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And again they are of three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	For from these are long, and from these is medium, and from these is short, according to the quantity of the width of the tube and the strictness of its tightness.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	Form A of Vinculum, and there are many species.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because they are simple ones, that is, those with one curvature: and there are three species as you see, Great, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And from them are Blind Vincula: and there are three species.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And from them are Vincula with two curvatures, and there are three species: and from them are Vincula with three curvatures, and there are three species: and all of these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of Scalpels, with which they cut and ablate Knots and Abscesses: and there are three species: because from them is Great, Medium, and Small.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	Their extremities with which the section is acute, other extremities are not acute: and they do not put them together, unless it is made with them a incision in order to cure an injury of the skin or nerve: and in order that the sick person should heal by it, and find a little bit of calmness from the burning than he finds when excoriating Abscesses.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are Magni, and there are three species.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of brass, and they are similar to the radius, with which it is made alcohol: and in the long edge there is a small dot called "Spatulimilis" hidden: and in it it runs inside and outside when you use it, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	Form of the Spatula which are hidden between fingers at the perforation of Abscesses: and they do not perceive them when they are injured: and there are three species, Great, Medium, and Small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	Form of the Windless which with which is cut off the flow of blood: and there are three species, Great, Medium, and Small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of brass, or yellow, round, about the same length as you see: and let them be delicate.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And let these species of Wind be with you Great and Small: in order that you might cut off blood with them at a high speed when necessary, and then when there is no medicine present for you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	Indeed, you should not use them in the abscission of blood from anywhere on the body, and you should only use them in muscular places: such as the legs, hips, arms, breasts, wrists, groin, and similar places made of muscular tissue, which are moist.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And when they become from them small instruments like the palm of the hand, according to their form: with which blood is cut off when it flows out from the site of phlebotomy, or at the incision of a vein, or an artery; and sometimes they become round according to this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the care of the breasts of men which are like the breasts of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter LVII. On the care of the genitals.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	When the breasts of some men swell at night (that is, when they begin to be irritated in sleep) until they resemble the breasts of women: and remain swollen with milk.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever wishes to avoid this (that is, milk coming out) should bind the breasts with a lunar band, according to this form, from A to B and G. Then scrape the whole area of the skin.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Afterwards fill a wound with an ointment made from incarnated flesh.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with a suture, and take care of it, until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	But if the breast sways towards the lower parts, and becomes soft through its size, as happens to women: then it is necessary that two sections according to the lunar form be found on either side of it, each one joined with the other by a line such as A joins B and G; and then the skin which is between the two lips should be scraped off, and the milk removed, and what we have said about the suture and powders, which are necessary in curing, should be applied, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	But if you do not wish to cut into it, because of the sickness or the flow of blood: then fill it with a corrupted oil-based ointment, and leave it, until what is left of the milk is corroded by it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then the care for himself, until he is well.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	As for the perforation of the abscess, which happened during the Titans.
Caput XLVIII.	Head LXXVIII.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	This abscess that happens during the Titans, is of the kind of hard Strophula, which contains a blister, and from it are those that contain moisture.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Since, therefore, those are of the kind that contain moisture, it should be cut with a lunar section, according to this form, from line b to line g; and then, when all that is in the abscess has been drained out, then fill it with old dung, and let it go until another day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the dung is to be removed, and he is to be cared for with an ointment suitable for it, until he is well.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If the abscess is of the kind of nodular Strophula, then cut on top of it, as we have said in the section on Strophula equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	But if a nerve is extended in this way so that it emits pus, then administer cauterization on it, according to what we said above in that which was premised.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	As for the section of an abscess that happens because of the artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Head LXXIX.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When the artery is broken and the skin that is above it has become hardened, then very often there happens an abscess from it; and also because of the veins, so that it happens to them as it does to the artery, namely, that there happens an abscess and swelling.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that an abscess and swelling are because of the artery and vein, are these: for, when an abscess is because of the artery, it is long, gathered in the depths of the body; and when the swelling of the abscess makes its way to your fingers, you feel as if there were a whistle in them.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is because of the vein, is round in manifest form of the body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And the section on this abscess is a mistake, and especially because it is under the armpits, and in the groin, and in the neck, and in many other places of the body; and it is great and very painful.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore, so that his care may be with iron, and since it is also in the extremities or in the head, let it be used.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, so that his care may be with iron, and since it is also in the extremities or in the head, let it be used. Super this therefore that is out of the inflammation of the opening of the artery, find in the skin section in length.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with a hook, then the artery: and free it from the tunics, until it is detected.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce under it the hook, and let it penetrate all the way to another side, and tighten the artery with a double thread at two places, according to what I taught you in the extraction of two arteries which are in the temporal region.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then pierce the place that is between the two ligaments with a needle, until all the blood inside it comes out, and dissolve the aphthoma.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer the cure that generates pus, until the ligaments fall: then care for it with unguents suitable for it, until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	That if there is an aphthoma due to the section of a vein, then you must hold your hand so that you can get rid of the aphthoma with the skin for you as much as possible.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce the hook under the place that you held with your hand, and let it penetrate: and let it go into it a double thread, until you get it out of the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then bind the aphthoma with that good ligament: according to what I told you in the binding of a vein, from two parts with its two extremities with a thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If however you are going to extract a thread, then introduce another hook with another thread under the aphthoma all along the incision of the blade: press, and tighten your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry up the aphthoma from its middle until it comes out what is inside it: then make an incision on the skin, and let go of what is bound to it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then put on top of that a very fine powder that you immersed in wine, and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer the cure, which is done with liniments and ointments, until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	The next chapter deals with what happens when the nerves are twisted.
Caput L.	Ch. 52
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	As happens with the apostema in an artery or vein, so it happens with nerves; that is, if there is a piercing, or if it comes from excessive work, and similar things: and it often happens to them in the places of the joints, or of the heel, and in any place where the tendons move: and it is a gray apostema.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color is similar to the rest of the body, and it is in many dispositions without pain: and when it is pressed with swelling, it feels like a kind of stupor within it.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an accumulated apostema in the depth of the body, but under the skin, and it moves all over, and does not complain about anything to the front, or ahead, or behind.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore what is in the joints should not be touched with a iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps, however, it happens because of contraction.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	But in that which is in the head, or in the forehead, find a skin with swelling.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If it is then a small apostema, then hold it with forceps and cut it off at the root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is a big one, then hang it on an hook, and scrape it off: then remove it, and gather the wound with a stitch: and take care of it, until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	Ch. 54 De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in ventriculo
Caput LI.	The head of the chapter on the cutting of apostemas,
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	Such things often happen to certain men, and to the rest of their bodies, those growths which are called "fungia", on account of their resemblance to fungi.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	Their roots are small, and their heads are large, and their lips are spread wide.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And they are few in number; and there is one which increases greatly in size.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I did indeed see a man, and in his belly were two worms, which were more than other similar fungi: there was no difference between them, they were white, and their roots were small; and their lips were spread out, and they had a lot of moisture always running from them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	So I did indeed see a man, and in his belly were two worms, which were more than other similar fungi: there was no difference between them, they were white, and their roots were small; and their lips were spread out, and they always had a lot of moisture running from them. So I cut off these, and I found in the weight of one almost ten and eight ounces, and in the other almost six ounces; And the operation in cutting them is, that you should consider then, if he is weak, moist, and the color of the worms is white, moist, subtile roots: then cut him with a wide chisel, and let cauterization be in your presence on fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	Indeed, many times the blood is discharged from him a lot when he is cut: so close if you are defeated by blood, then cauterize him.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	That if you see him weak, timid, and afraid of the cut with iron, then take a wire from lead that is curved: and pull it with him athelum: whose mode I have said, and let go of him for two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add to the tightness of the lead.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	So do not cease to tighten the lead, when it presses on the worms, until it is cut off, and falls by itself without work.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If, however, the worms are big roots, then there is some fear and fear in cutting them: especially because they are in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	But it is possible to cut half of it.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize him, so that he does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the man until he heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And do not suppose that you can cut the worms which are of a dark color, few senses, and an appetizing appearance: for he is indeed an apostema cancerous: and I will come back with the memory of Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the care of the umbilicus.
Caput LII.	Chapter LII. On the care of the umbilical cord.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	To deal with various causes of umbilical care.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	It may emerge from a fistula that opens on the belly below: or it may emerge from the rectum, according to whether it occurs in the remaining ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Or from blood that flows from a vein, or from an artery, as stated above.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or from a constricted pleat of skin.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If, however, it emerges from a fistula that is clean and the discharge is thick: then it resembles the color of fresh blood: it is soft, without pain: and it appears in various places.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is due to the exit of the intestine, then its location is with that which we have mentioned, more varied in character.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When you press upon it with your fingers, it is hidden: then it returns, and perhaps has a sound: and it is very prominent at the entrance of the anus, and causes a rumbling noise.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If, however, it is due to moisture, it is soft, and does not hide itself when pressed by your hand, nor becomes tight, nor does it add to itself.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is due to blood, then with these signs appears a bruise of a dark color at the tip.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If, however, it is due to raw flesh: then it is a bruise of a gray, thick, hard color, and discolors according to the quantity of one unit.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If, however, it is due to a flow of air, then the sensation of touching it is soft.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation in that case is, as you should consider, if the umbilical eminence is due to blood of an artery or vein or a flow of air: then one should refrain from treating it.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For in that is fear and dread, as I taught you in the chapter in which I said that bruises are due to an artery and a flow of air.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the umbilical eminence is due to an intestine or a hernia, then you should prescribe for the sick person to hold his breath and remain standing with his body extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then mark with encaustum around the navel altogether.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then order him to lie down on his back between your hands.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then, with a mallet, beat around the navel from side to side in the place that you marked out with encaustic.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Then extend the mid-line of incision upward, with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then tie him around strongly with thread or silk knot: and let the knot be tied to an unharmed part of his body.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the mid-line incision that you have extended, above the lymphatic duct.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If you have already found the patient's hernia through the lymphatic duct: then pull out the ligature and insert your index finger into him, pushing the intestine towards his insides: and if you find a hernia: then grasp it with the hook, and cut off its surplus.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If, however, the opposite side is an artery, or a vein: then mark him all around.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	And take two needles and insert two strong threads into them: and insert the two needles around what you have marked out around the hernia in the shape of a cross, which you make to penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then tighten the hernia in four places on the needles: and if you wish, remove the needle, and leave the place, until the flesh has become rotting: and let it fall down of itself: or cut it off when it becomes slimy and rotten.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the patient with unguents as needed, until he is healed.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If the navel's eminence is made of flesh that has become hard in it, or of moisture: then you must tighten the hernia, as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And extract the blood or moisture that you have injected into him.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for the patient with unguents so that the place hardens up.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	Of the canکر.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have already spoken about the division of cancer, and how it is treated with medicines; and how to guard against its spreading by curettage with an iron implement, so that it does not ulcerate: and we spoke about cancer arising in the womb, and about the precautions needed for its treatment.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that when ever cancer is in a place where it can be eradicated: such as cancer that is in the breast, or in the thigh, and similar places, from the member located to extract all of it: especially when it is just beginning.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When however it is old, and is great, it should not be approached.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I cannot heal from him anyone: nor did I see any other who has come to that.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation in it, when it is located like we have said, is, as the saying goes, so that you go ahead and you release the fever from black cholera sometimes.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then phlebotomy itself if it is bloated with evident fullness.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the sick with preparation, in which he is located with the operation.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then throw on cancer the hooks that are suitable for him.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Then wrap up the cancer with all the skin, according to the tracing, until there remains nothing of its roots: and let the blood not run, nor do you tear it quickly, except that you express the places, and wipe away the gross blood entirely by your hand, or with whatever is possible there.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	But if it makes you contrary that the gross blood flows out from the incision of an artery or a vein: then cauterize the vein until the blood is cut off.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the cancer with the remaining cure, until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	§ On the treatment of hydrops.
Caput LIIII.	Head LIIII.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	We have already covered in the division of the species of Hydrops, and how water is aggregated: and the signs of each species, and the cure of it with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And those who are cured with iron, it is not except a single species of asclepius: and it does not approach iron of tympanic species: nor does the species of hyposarcoma go deep: for that is deadly.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you are already treated with this species of Hydrops tympanic with medicines, and your treatment has not been successful: then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	If the sick person has already been afflicted with one kind of illness and then another, different from hydropisis: as when he has cough, or diacrisis of the urinary tract, and such like: then be careful not to treat him with iron: for there is a fear of that.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	But if you see a healthy person with an excess of strength and there is no illness other than hydropisis: nor is he a boy or an old man: then the method of operation in him is, that you should stand him between your hands, and let him express his wind from his hand driving water to the lower part of the rib cage.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a spikelet with thorns, shaped like this.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Set two sharp parts, one long and the other sharp at its end like a spikelet.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	But in him there is something that gradually becomes shorter, so that you do not break it while operating near the intestine, and you do not hurt him.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	For if there is generation of hydropisis from the part of the intestines, then it should be extended with a cut from the navel by three fingers' width, going directly below it on the rib cage.
