Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	But if they do not hold on to the hooks because of their moisture and softness: then take them with a rough cloth or with a twig of willow, and draw them out with your fingers.
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	Then cut them, and sprinkle on them some hot powder after the cut so that they stay in place for a cauterization.
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	Or cauterize them according to what has been said in the chapter of cauterizing.
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with the rest of the cure, until they are healed.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	If the anus does not comply with this exit, then clench the sick person with a small clister that causes pain, so that it may go along with what is in the anus, and complies with this exit when it comes out, if it comes out smoothly.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	But if the hemorrhoids are external from the anus, then your task is easy and simple: you can hold them with your fingernail or with a hook, and cut them off.
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	Then care for them with the above-mentioned means until they are healed.
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	And who loathes incisions with iron, then it is necessary that you administer sutures to them in this way.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	Accept a thread which has been wetted, and introduce it itself into the wound.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	Then remove the thread to the upper side, and let it penetrate with the needle into the root of its other part: and roll the two ends of the thread, in the lower part of the needle, and let them run parallel to each other: and tighten the thread with a strong knot.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	Then tie a knot in the thread, and remove the needle.
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	Do this with all the threads, and let one of them remain: and let it not be attached to its own end, that it may run away from it in case of an excess of blood.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	Then put it on a cloth soaked in rose oil or olive oil, and put it on the wound: and order the sick person to lie down.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	Then remove the cloth, until it has dried.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	When therefore the threads have fallen off, care for them with ointment, and with the remainder of the cure, until they are healed.
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	§ On the care of wounds.
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	For many times there happen from drying up of dung, and from the natural contraction.
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	When therefore they have become old, and do not bear any medicine: then it is necessary that you shave them with the sharp blade of Spatulimilus, or with your own nail, until they are wet, and that you remove from them the upper cortex which prevents them from being consolidated.
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	Then care for them, until they are consolidated, according to what is necessary.
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	If however they do not consolidate: then shave them again with a sharper razor than before, until they bleed much, and then care for them, until they are healed.
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	§ On the cure of scabs, and not of scabs; and of the threads of cicatrices, and of the ants.
Caput LXXXII.	Chapter LIII.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	You should know that Almirmar is not anything but a round nodule according to the color of the body, similar to a claw on the head: and it happens in the whole body, especially in the lower parts of the feet and fingers: and it causes pain when walking.
Oportet ergo ut secetur quod est in circumitu claui, et teneatur cum forficibus, aut cum uncino, et eradicetur ex radice sua.	It is therefore necessary to cut off what is on the edge of the claw, and to hold with pincers, or with a hook, and to remove it from its root.
Deinde cura illud: et si uis cauteriza illud secundum quod praecessit in capitulo suo.	Then this care must be taken: and if you want to cauterize that according to what preceded in his chapter.
Ex athelil autem siccis unus est eminentia parua, aspera, filtrata, rotunda supra superficiem corporis.	From the animal however one is a small eminence, rough, filtered, round over the surface of the body.
Et multotiens accidunt in manibus puerorum.	And often happen in the hands of boys.
Et curatio eius est, ut extendas athelil, et incidas ipsum: aut stringas ipsum cum filo de serico: aut cum pilo, donec cadat.	And the cure of it is that you should extend the athelil, and press it on: or you should tie it with silk thread: or with wool, until it falls off.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum secundum quod praemissum est cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta: et iam eradicantur athelil inuersi, et non inuersi cum instrumento quod ego dicam.	And if you want to, cauterize that according to what has been said before with fire, or with sharp medicine: and those athelils are removed immersed, and not immersed with an instrument that I call.
Formica autem est etiam eminentia parua filtrata, grossa, super superficiem corporis, uadens in profundum ualde: et quando inuenit eam frigus, sentitur in ea simile mordicationi formicae, et fit in corpore toto: et plurimum eius fit in manibus.	But the ant is also a small eminence, filtered, rough, over the surface of the body, dripping into the depth far away: and when it finds it cold, feels in it a similar stinging of an ant, and becomes all over the body: and most of it is made in the hands.
Et curatio eius est, ut accipias cannulam ex penna anseris, aut penna uulturis forti: et pone illam cannulam super Formicam, donec contineat circulus cannulae ex partibus eius.	And the cure of it is that you take a tube from a goose feather, or a strong turkey feather: and put that tube on the ant, until it holds a circle of the tube from its parts.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum cannula, donec seces quod est in circumitu Formicae: et ponas eam in profundo carnis, et eradices Formicam ex radice eius.	Then turn your hand with the tube, until you separate what is on the edge of the ant: and put it in the depth of the flesh, and remove the ant from its root.
Et si uis, fac illud cum cannula aeris, aut ferri, secundum hanc formam.	And if you want to, do that with an air tube, or a iron tube, according to this form.
Sit superius cannulae ad sublimitatem trahens surdum inuolutum, ut alleuietur super digitum apprehensio eius et ipsius reuolutio.	Let the tube be above a small limit, dragging a soft un-felt, so that it should ease the pressure of its grasp and its retraction.
Et si uis cauteriza Formicam secundum quod praemissum est in cauterizatione Athelil in capitulo de cauterio.	And if you want to, cauterize the ant according to what has been said before in the cauterization of athelil in the chapter on cauterization.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum quae administrantur ad Clisteria in aegritudinibus Ani, et solutionis uentris, et colicae.	On the forms of instruments used for enemas in the ailments of the anus, and for washing away the urine and colic.
Caput LXXXIII.	Chapter 83.
Quandoque Clistere fit ex argento, aut ex aurichalco, aut ex aere fuso, aut malleato.	When cloisters are made of silver, or of gold, or of brass, or of hammered bronze.
Et quandoque fit ex istis Instrumentis paruum, et magnum, secundum illos in quibus administrantur.	And when these instruments are small or large, according to those in which they are administered.
Illud ergo quod administratur in curatione puerorum paruorum, sit paruum: et quorum ani sunt debiles, aut dolorosi, sic et clisteria eorum.	So that which is administered in the cure of young boys who are small, let it be small; and those whose anus is weak or painful, let their cloisters also be small.
Clistere magnum.	A large enema.
Cistere paruum.	A small enema.
Canna eius, id est, caput superius in quo ligatur uter, sit amplum secundum hunc modum: et sit ei distinctio ut ligetur uter sicut uides, et extremitas eius inferior quae intromittitur in anum, sit surda, id est, non aperta, lenis, ualde, trahens ad subtilitatem: et in uno laterum eius sint duo foramina, et in latere altero foramen unum.	The cane of the instrument, that is, the upper part in which it is tied to the uterus, should be wide according to this manner: and let there be a separation so that it is tied as you see, and the lower end which enters into the anus, should be dull, i.e., not open, soft, very gentle, drawing towards finesse: and on one side of its cane there are two openings, and on the other side a single opening.
Et sit amplitudo foraminis secundum grossitudinem radiorum, et grossius parum, et sit uter in quo ponuntur medicinae ex uesica animalis: aut ex charta ouis, quae sit secundum formam asofrati paruae: cuius radix sit palmus unus.	And let the width of the openings be according to the thickness of the radii, and the thicker for the smaller, and let the uterus in which are placed the medicines be of a sheep-skin: or of a piece of paper shaped like an ashen, which is small: whose root is one palm.
Et perforetur foraminibus multis sicut reuoluitur, et sit spacium quod est inter omne foramen grossitudo digiti.	And let many openings be pierced like the wind blows through, and let there be a space between each opening which is the width of a finger.
Deinde intromitte in illa foramina filum forte ex filo crudo, quod sit ex decem filis, aut circiter ea, et aggrega cum eo utrem sicut asofrati.	Then introduce into those openings a strong thread from raw silk, which is made up of ten threads, or something like that, and tie it with one of the threads.
Cum ergo ponitur in eo uter, stringatur in capite clisteris inter duo distinguentia constrictione forti.	When it is placed in this uterus, let a tight constriction be applied to it between the two openings.
Deinde clisteriza cum eo.	Then wash with it.
Et haec est forma circuli utris hic depicta, et foraminum.	And this is the shape of the uterus here depicted and of the openings.
Qualitas autem clisterizandi cum eo, est: ut impleas utrem, aut uesicam ex medicina, quae sit calefacta secundum quantitatem tolerantiae infirmi: et caue ne sit calida ualde, aut frigida ualde.	The quality of washing with it is: that you fill the uterus, or the uterus of a sheep-skin soaked in medicine which has been warmed according to the tolerance of the nurse, and let not be very hot or very cold.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et eleuet crura sua ad superiora: et pone sub eo inthaan, id est, corium super quod iacent homines, aut linteamen.	Then the sick one is placed on his back, and his legs are lifted up towards the sky; and a blanket or mattress is placed under him, that is to say, skin over which men lie, or linen.
Deinde inunge extremitatem Clisteris cum oleo, aut cum albugine oui, aut cum mucillagine foenugraeci, aut similium.	Then the end of the limb is smeared with oil, or with chalk powder, or with mucilaginous foil of fenugreek, or something similar.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in anum cum facilitate.	Then introduce the body into the wound with ease.
Deinde accipiat minister utrem cum duabus manibus suis simul, et exprimat ipsum cum uehementia, donec euacuet totum quod est in Clisteri in intestinum.	Then a servant takes both of his hands and he pushes himself out with great force until all that is inside theClisteri has been expelled into the intestines.
Deinde extrahe Clistere, et eleuet infirmus crura sua ad parietem.	Then take out theClisteri, and lift up the sick man's legs towards the wall.
Quod si medicina cogit eum ad exitum, tunc teneat quantum potest.	If the medicine makes him come out, then hold on to him as much as you can.
Et si dormit cum ea nocte tota, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if he sleeps all night with it, it is more effective for healing.
Si autem clisterizas eum in aegritudinibus solutionis uentris, et festinat exitus eius: tunc itera clistere, donec sanetur.	But if youClisterize him in the solution of a single day, and his departure is hurried: then repeat theClisteri until he is healed.
Quod si in ano sunt hemorroides, aut apostemata laedentia, tunc sit clistere subtile ualde, lene, ex clisteribus quibus clisterizantur pueri.	That if there are hemorrhoids, or sore posthemiums: thenClisterize with a thin solution very gently, wax, andClisteri from which the boys areClisterized.
Et haec sit forma clisteris subtilis super quod sit stricta cutis.	And this is the form of a thinClisteri over which there is a tight skin.
¶ De curatione Vulnerum capitis sine fractura ossis.	¶ For the healing of head wounds without fracture of bone.
Caput LXXXIIII.	Head, 84.
Iam dixi in diuisione de curatione uulnerum quod conueniebat libro, et ego dicam hic curationem eorum cum manu, et cum medicinis secundum complementum.	I have already said in the division of the healing of wounds which belonged to the book, and I now say here those healing with the hand, and with medicines, according to the second preparation.
Dico ergo, quod uulnera diuersificantur secundum illud quo fiunt uulnera, et secundum locum super quem cadit uulnus.	I say then that wounds differ according to that by which they are made, and according to the place on which the wound falls.
Res ergo quibus fiunt uulnera multotiens, sunt sicut iactus lapidis: aut incisio ensis, aut cultelli: aut percussio cum lancea, aut ligno, aut sagitta: et similibus illis ex rebus multis.	Therefore the wounds which are often made, are like the blows of a stone: or the cut of a sword, or of a dagger: or the strike of a lance, or of a wood-splinter, or of an arrow. And of many other such things.
Vulnera autem quae fiunt secundum loca corporis sunt, sicut uulnus quod cadit super caput, aut collum, aut pectus, aut uentrem, aut epar: et similia ex eis membris.	Wounds that are made according to the places of the body, such as an arrow that falls on the head, or the neck, or the chest, or the belly, or the side: and similar members from them.
Et ego sum narrans curationes quorundam uulnerum, ut ponam eam ratiocinationem et regulam super reliqua uulnera.	And I am telling about the cures of certain wounds, so that I may put forth a reasoning and a rule for the remaining wounds.
Et ego incipiam a uulneribus capitis simplicibus: quoniam rememoratio compositorum ueniet in principio capituli tertii.	And I will begin with simple head wounds: because the memory of the composers will come at the beginning of the third chapter.
Dico ergo.	I say:
Quando accidit in capite uulnus simplex, et non est fractura ossis: considera tunc, si est ex iactu lapidis, aut ei similibus, et iam fregit cutem tantum: et est uulnus magnum, et times super infirmum euentum apostematis calidi: tunc propera, et phlebotoma cephalicam statim: et non tardes illud: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis eius: si non fuerit prohibens aliquid a phlebotomia, praecipue si fuerit sanguis qui egreditur ex uulnere paucus.	When it has happened in the head a simple wound, and there is no fracture of bone: then consider, if it is from a stone's throw, or similar to it, and already has frayed the skin only: and it is a great wound, and fear about possible gangrene of the warm: then approach, and immediately phlebotomy cephalic: and do not delay that: and extract therefrom according to the quantity of its effectiveness: if it were not prohibiting anything from the phlebotomy, especially if it were the blood which comes out from the wound little.
Et sit phlebotomia ex contrario partis uulneratae.	And let the phlebotomy come from the opposite side of the wounded part.
Et caueat infirmus sibi a repletione, et uino, et cibis grossis.	And let the sick person take care not to drink anything, and no wine, and no heavy food.
Si autem minutionem prohibet aliquid, tunc minoretur ex cibo, et non appropinquet carnibus, neque uinis.	If however there is a prohibition of something, then it will be reduced from the food, and does not come near to meat, neither wine.
Et pone super uulnus si accidit ei apostema calidum, cotum infusum in oleo rosato solo, aut cum uino in quo est stipticitas.	And place over the wound if it has happened to him a warm poultice, wet infusion in oil of rosemary alone, or with wine in which is stipticitis.
Si autem securus fueris ab apostemate calido, tunc pone super uulnus, si est recens cum sanguine suo, et non mutauit ipsum aer, puluerem quem ego narrabo post paululum: et si iam mutauit ipsum aer, tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, donec sanetur.	If however you are safe from a warm poultice, then place over the wound if it is new with its own blood, and has not changed itself air, dust which I will tell after a little while: and if it has already changed itself air, then place over it some ointment, until it heals.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, aut est ex incisione ensis, et similium: et non aggregantur labia eius per puluillos, tunc aggrega ipsa cum sutura, secundum quod ego narrabo in uulneribus uentris de sutura eorum.	If however the wound is large, or it is from an incision of a sword, and similar: and if its edges are not gathered by dusts, then gather them themselves with a stitch, according to what I will tell after about the wounds of the hand regarding their stitches.
Si autem uulnus iam detectum est ab osse, et pendet, et non est retentio eius, nisi in suspensorio paruo: tunc incide ipsum.	If however the fracture has already been detected from the bone, and is hanging down, and there is no retentive force, except a small one in the suspender: then cut it off.
Deinde cura uulnus cum medicinis, et restaura in eo carnem duram loco cutis, et praecipe infirmo, ut alatur cibis in quibus est grossitudo, sicut sunt capita, et triticum coctum, donec sit ut puls: et eis similia.	Then care for the wound with medicines, and restore to it tough flesh in the place of the skin, and order the sick person to eat food in which there is moisture, such as are grains, and cooked rice, until it has healed like a scar: and give them similar things.
Quod si inuenis in cute putrefactionem, et non adhaeret ossi: tunc incide putrefactum totum, et proiice ipsum: deinde cura illud.	That if an injury is in the skin and does not attach to the bone: then cut off the whole of the putrid part, and throw it away; then care for that.
Si autem in his uulneribus est arteria, aut uena ex qua fluit sanguis: et non abscinditur per medicinas, tunc inquire super arteriam.	If however there is an artery in these wounds, or a new one from which blood flows: and does not stop with medicines, then inquire about the artery.
Si ergo inuenis eam non sectam, tunc seca eam cum Spatumili, aut liga eam.	If however you have not cut off the injury, then dry it up with sputum, or bind it.
Quod si necessitas prouocat quando non confert illud quod diximus, tunc cauteriza eam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	That if necessity compels you when it does not give what I have said, then burn it off, until the blood stops flowing.
Si autem uulnera ista sunt parua, simplicia, tunc res eorum est facilis, leuis: ita ut puluerizes super ea hunc puluerem: quoniam consolidat ea antequam mutet ea aer.	If however these wounds are small and simple, then the work on them is easy and light: so that dusting over them this dust, for they will harden before they change.
¶ Modus Pulueris incarnatiui.	Method of Powder for Burned Wounds.
Recipe olibani partem unam, et sanguinis draconis partes duas, et calcis non extinctae partes tres: teratur totum multum, et cribelletur: et impleatur ex eo uulnus, et constringatur constrictione bona, donec adhaereat super ipsum bene, et coaguletur cum sanguine.	Recipe one part of olive oil, and two parts of dragon's blood, and three parts of burned stone that has not been extinct: all are ground together, and sieved: and it is filled with it, and tightened with a good constriction, until it adheres well to the wound, and clots with blood.
Deinde stringe ipsum desuper cum puluillis, et dimitte ipsum, neque soluas ipsum dum permanet, ita quod non apostemetur.	Then tighten it on top with the powder, and leave it, and do not remove it until it has dried up: so that it does not ooze out.
Nam non eradicatur ab eo medicina, donec sanatur.	For it will not be cured by medicine, until it is cured.
Et quandoque facit illud calx sola, quando non sunt tibi in praesenti olibanum, et sanguis draconis etiam facit eandem operationem in multis ex uulneribus magnis, quando conuenit ut ponatur super ea et stringantur, et sunt uulnera recentia cum sanguine suo, quae non alterauit aer.	And when it has done this lime alone, when you do not have with you olive oil, and dragon' s blood also does the same operation on many large wounds, when it is put on them and tightened: and are wounds recent with their own blood, which has not been altered by air.
Quod si iam alterauit ea aer quadam alteratione, praecipue quando est in tempore aestatis, tunc non est in positione huius pulueris intentio: cura ergo ipsum cum eo quod diximus, ita ut ponas super ea quaedam unguenta digestiua: aut ponas super ea pultes ex farina hordei, factas cum aqua et melle, donec emittant pus.	If I have already changed the air by some change, especially when it is in the time of summer, then this powder's purpose is not in this position: therefore take care of him with what we said, so that you put on her some unguents digesting: or put on her some flours from barley, made with water and honey, until they emit pus.
Deinde cura ea reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	Then take care of the rest with this cure, until they are healed.
Si uero accidat cum uulnere fractura in osse, et est parua, tunc extrahe illud cum Gesti: et ego iam dicam curationem fracturarum capitis in eo quod futurum est.	But if it happens that a bone fracture is small and has been broken, then remove it with the Gesti: and I have already said the cure for fractures of the head as it will happen.
¶ De uulneribus Colli.	Regarding wounds of the neck.
Caput LXXXV.	Head LVII.
SI Autem uulnus accidat in Collo, tunc non est inter ipsum differentia in medicatione, et inter uulnus capitis quando est simplex.	If a wound is in the neck, there is no difference in treatment between it and a wound of the head when it is simple.
Si autem iam incisus est neruus Colli, aut arteria: tunc si est neruus, non est in eo ingenium, nisi ut deuitetur curatio eius cum eo quod facit stipticitatem uehementem, sicut ziniar, et zegi, et eis similia.	But if a wound has already penetrated the neck's nerve, or artery: then if it is a nerve, there is no skill in it except to let it run its course with what makes a harsh stipulation, such as vinegar, and dressing, and things like that.
Quoniam nocent neruis, et contrahunt eos.	Since they are harmful to the nerves, and make them twitch.
Et non ponas super uulnus aliquid frigidum omnino: quoniam substantia neruorum est frigida, et continuatio eius est cum cerebro, quod est sublimius membrorum: et sit illud quo curatur ex medicinis lene, sicut calx lota cum aqua dulci aliquotiens infusa cum oleo, aut cum oleo rosato, et tuthia, quando abluitur etiam cum aqua dulci: et reliqui lapides minerales, secundum hunc modum, et unguenta humida.	Do not put anything cold on the wound at all: since the substance of the nerves is cold, and its continuance is with the brain, which is a noble member: and let this be used with what cure is made from lene, such as calx lota with sweet water sometimes infused with oil, or with rosewater oil, and thistle, when it is rinsed with sweet water: and also the mineral stones, in this way, and wet unguents.
Si autem uulnus est magnum, tunc administra suturam: aut coarta labia eius cum puluillis.	But if the wound is large, then administer a suture: or cover its lips with powder.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of him, until he is healed.
Si uero uulneri est profunditas, aut accidit in eo sinus in inferiori parte eius, in quo iam aggregatur pus, tunc perfora ipsum in magis depresso loco in eo.	But if a wound is deep, or has occurred in it a pocket of pus on the lower part of it, then pierce it in a more depressed place.
Quod si iam incisa est in uulnere arteria, et consecutus est sanguinem eius fluxus: tunc separa, uel seca eam, et liga ipsam: aut cauteriza eam, si prouocat necessitas ad illud.	If the artery is already cut in the ulna and its blood flow continues: then separate, or dry it up, and bind it; or, if necessary, cauterize it.
Si autem iam incidit spondiles gutturis, aut totum, et saluatae sunt alhaudegi: tunc aggrega labia cutis cum sutura super cannam gutturis, et non tangas guttur, imo aequa ipsum, et reduc ipsum super figuram naturalem.	But if the spine has already been injured and some of the spinal fluid has been spilled or most of it has been lost: then join the skin with a stitch above the canal of the fluid, and do not touch the fluid, but make it level and reduce it back to its natural shape.
Deinde stringe ipsum strictura decenti, et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot.	Then tighten the wound with a stitch that diminishes gradually, and leave it for a few days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis in quibus est stipticitas et exiccatio, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound with ointment to prevent pustules and drying, until it heals.
Si autem uulnus iam fecit impressionem in osse, tunc perquire ipsum: tunc si in ipso sunt fragmenta ossis, extrahe ea omnia, aut quae potes ex eis: et quod non praeparatur, dimitte illud, donec putrescat uulnus, et separetur et alleuietur egressio eius.	But if the ulna has already made an impression on the bone, then examine it: if there are any bone fragments in it, remove them all, or as many as you can: and if it is not prepared, leave it until the ulna rots, and separates and comes out gradually.
Quod si uulnus fuerit recens, tunc pulueriza super ipsum puluerem quem narraui.	If the ulna is still new, then powder it with powder that hardens.
Si autem uidetur in uulnere os, et fit Fistula: tunc cura ipsam cum eo cuius rememoratio uenit in capitulo suo.	But if a fistula has developed in the ulna, then treat it with the treatment described in the chapter on that topic.
¶ De uulnere in Spatulis.	On the ulna in spatulas.
Caput LXXXVI.	Chapter LXVIII. On the ulna:
SI Est percussio lanceae, aut cultelli: et uides eius profunditatem, tunc considera.	If the lance or knife has made a deep wound: then examine it carefully.
Si ergo ex uulnere egreditur uentositas, quando anhelat ex eo infirmus, tunc scias, quia uulnus est mortale.	But if from the ulna comes a fever, and the person who has it becomes weak: then you know that the ulna is deadly.
Quod si non fuerit ei profunditas, et est recens cum sanguine suo: tunc non ponas in eo a prima hora puluerem, neque stringas ipsum, ut non retineatur sanguis in profunditate eius, et reuertatur ad cor, et interficiat infirmum: sed pone in ipso unguentum attractiuum, et solue ipsum in die bis.	If it is not deep and is still new with its blood: then do not put powder on it at first, nor tighten it so that the blood does not flow into its depth and return to its heart, and instead make it ooze a little every day.
Si uero unguentum non est tibi praesens, tunc pone in orificio uulneris cotum uetustum, ut sugat illud quod egreditur de eo ex humiditatibus: et fac ut dormiat infirmus super uulnus, ut currat quod aggregatur in eo.	But if the ointment is not present with you, then put a clean cloth on the wound to absorb what comes out of it due to moisture: and let the person who is ill sleep on the ulna so that he may run to catch what is aggregating in it.
Si uero iam praeterierint uulneri tres dies, aut plures, et non accidit infirmo spasmus, neque tremor cordis malus, neque strictura in anhelitu, et uides reliquas dispositiones eius bonas: tunc scias, quia uulnus est saluum.	If indeed they have already been three days or more without injury, and there has occurred no spasm of illness, nor a bad tremor of the heart, nor a narrowing of anxiety, and their remaining vision is good: then you will know that the wound is healed.
Cura ergo ipsum et cum liciniis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	So take care of it with care and with the rest of the cure, until it is healed.
Si uero excusatur sanatio eius, et iam aperitur semper, tunc scias, quia iam factum est Fistula.	If indeed the healing of it has been excused, and it has now opened forever, then you will know that it has now become a fistula.
Cura ergo ipsam ex capitulo suo.	So take care of it from its own chapter.
Et si uulnus est ex incisione ensis, aut cultelli, et est simplex in superficie pectoris, aut dorsi: tunc cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit ex sutura, si est magnum: aut cum puluere, si est paruum.	And if the wound is from an incision of a sword, or of a knife, and it is simple on the surface of the chest, or of the back: then take care of it with what precedes it from suturing, if it is large: or with dust, if it is small.
Si autem iam fecit impressionem in osse, et incidit ex eo frusta: tunc inquire uulnus, et propera ad extrahendum illa frusta, si sunt separata.	But if indeed it has made an impression on the bone, and has cut it from there with a club: then inquire about the wound, and quickly approach to remove those clubs, if they are separated.
Si uero non sunt separata, tunc dimitte ea, donec putrefiat uulnus, alleuiatur enim extractio eorum.	But if they are not separated, then leave them, until the wound has rotted away, for the extraction of them is a relief.
Reliquorum autem uulnerum accidentium in reliquis membris iudicium in curatione, est iudicium eius quod diximus.	But of the remaining wounds and accidents of the other member, the judgment in the cure is the same as that which I have said.
¶ De uulneribus Ventris, et exitu intestini, et exitura eorum.	Of the wounds of the belly and the exit of the intestines and the coming out of them.
Caput LXXXVII.	Chapter LVII.
Disruptio quae accidit uentri, est magna, et media, et parua.	The break that happens in the belly is great, medium, and small.
Ex magna igitur quandoque egreditur intestinum, aut numerus intestinorum.	So then when and how often the intestine exits, or the number of intestines.
Quare fit intromissio eorum, et eorum sutura uehementior et difficilior.	Why do they enter each other, and their stitching is more painful and difficult.
Et disruptio parua etiam fit difficilis ex modo alio.	And a small break is also difficult in another way.
Sequitur ergo, ut sit reductio eorum difficilior, si non properas in intromissione sua ad locum suum statim: quoniam inflatur, aperitur, et ingrossatur: quare fit difficilis introitus eius.	So follow, so that the reduction of them is more difficult, if you do not incline to the place of their entry at once: for indeed it swells up, opens up, and thickens up: why does the entrance of it become difficult?
Propter hoc ergo fit melior disruptionum disruptio media: quoniam cum ea non fit difficilis reductio intestini, sicut fit dissicilis in his duabus speciebus.	Therefore, it is better to make a mid-way disruption: for when the intestine does not reduce easily, as it does in these two species, a mid-way disruption is made.
Scias, quod sutura uenris est secundum quatuor modos.	Know that the suturing of wounds is done according to four ways.
Duae suturae communes conueniunt in sutura uentris, et in sutura reliquorum uulnerum corporis: et duae suturae aliae proprie communicant reliquis uulneribus.	Two common sutures join together in the suturing of the eye, and in the suturing of the other wounds of the body; and two other sutures, each by itself, communicate with the rest of the wounds.
Verumtamen sunt magis propriae cum sutura uentris: et ego narro tibi unamquamque cum expositione, et declaratione.	However, there are more proper when it comes to the suturing of the eye; and I will tell you each one, with exposure and explanation.
Dico ergo, quia quando uulnus est paruum, et egreditur ex eo aliquid ex intestino, et fit difficile reducere ipsum: tunc illud est propter unum duorum modorum.	I therefore say that when the wound is small and it is coming out of it some intestines, and it is difficult to reduce them: then this is done for one of two ways.
Aut propter paruitatem disruptionis, sicut diximus: Aut quoniam in intestino est inflatio propter frigus aeris.	Or because the disruption is small, as we have said; or because there is swelling in the intestine due to cold air.
Quando ergo illud est ita, tunc oportet ut calefacias ipsum, ita ut submergas spongiam, aut pannum humidum in aqua tepida sola.	When then should this be done? Then you should warm the wound, so as to submerge a sponge or a wet cloth in warm water alone.
Aut decoquas in aqua squinantum, et cyperum, et spicam, et embroces cum ea intestinum, donec resoluatur inflatio.	Or you should decongest with squinantic water and celery and pepper, and blend it with the intestines, until the swelling goes down.
Quandoque facit illud uinum in quo est stipticitas: et est melius quam aqua sola in resolutione inflationis.	When then does the wine do, in which there is stipticitis: and it is better than just water in resolving swelling.
Cum ergo uides inflationem iam resolui, tunc humecta intestinum cum aqua in qua decocta est altea, aut malua.	When then you see the swelling has already gone down, then wet the intestines with strong beer or wine.
Nam per illud alleuiatur introitus eius cum re parua.	For through this the entrance is relieved, when it is smaller.
Si autem excusatur reditus eius post hanc curationem, tunc finde in disruptione parum, cum instrumento quo secantur hemorrhoides.	If, however, the retreat of it is excused after this treatment, then find a little disruption with the instrument with which they are torn hemorrhoids.
Et curatio prima est melior quando praeparatur, quam sectio: et non fit coactio ad secandum post necessitatem et defectum instrumenti.	And the first treatment is better when it is prepared, than the section; and there is no coercion to cut after need and a lack of instruments.
Sit pars eius una quae est torta, acuta, et pars eius altera non acuta, et extremitas subtilis non sit cum subtilitate Spatumilis, imo sit obtusior parumper: et est illa quae similatur caiada, sicut uides.	Let one part of it be twisted, acute, and the other not acute, and its extremity is fine, a little less sharp than the spine of the pen; and it is like the sawn piece, as you see it.
Cum ergo amplificatur uulnus, et ingreditur intestinum, tunc oportet, ut sit reductio eius secundum formam suam naturalem in loco suo sibi proprio, si possibile est super illud: quoniam est melius.	For when the ulna is enlarged and the intestines are put in, then it is necessary that his reduction be made according to his own natural form in his own place, if possible above it: for it is better.
Quando uero disruptio est ampla in inferiori parte uentris: tunc oportet ut facias iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et pone crura sua altiora capite suo.	When, however, the fracture is wide in the lower part of the uterus: then it is necessary that you should place the sick one on his back, and put his legs higher than his head.
Et si est in superiore parte uentris, tunc pone caput eius, et pectus ipsius altiora quam eius inferiora.	And if he is in the upper part of the uterus, then place his head and his chest higher than his lower parts.
Et similiter si est disruptio in una duarum partium uentris, tunc pone intentionem tuam, et tuam considerationem semper in hoc, ut pars in qua est uulnus sit altior parte altera.	And likewise, if the fracture is in one of the two parts of the uterus, then place your intention and your attention always on this, that the part where the ulna is should be higher than the other part.
Et ita oportet, ut admimistres illud in uulneribus magnis, et in uulneribus mediis.	And thus it is necessary, so that you treat the wound in large wounds and in middle-sized wounds.
In uulneribus autem paruis, pone illud secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	But in small wounds, place it according to what is prepared for you.
Deinde fac ut sit praesens inter manus tuas minister pius, qui teneat disruptionem totam manu sua: et aggrega labia eius.	Then make sure that a faithful minister who holds the whole fracture with his hand is present between your hands: and gather his lips.
Deinde detege ex ea ei qui sequitur suturam aliquid post aliquid: et iste est modus suturae communis unius.	Then identify from him who follows someone to sew something after something: and this is the method of common sewing of one thread.
Et est, ut accipias acum, aut numerum acuum secundum quantitatem amplitudinis uulneris.	And it is, so that you take an amount, or a number according to the quantity of the width of the wound.
Deinde dimitte ab extremitate disruptionis quantitatem digiti anularis, id est, medici: et fige acum unam praeter quod intromittas in eam filum in duabus extremitatibuis cutis, cum duabus extremitatibus sifac quod est sub cute ab interioribus, donec facias eam penetrare ab alia parte, et tu iam aggregasti duas extremitates cutis, et duas extremitates sifac: et fiunt quatuor ordines.	Then let go of the end of the fracture by the amount of a finger's length, that is, doctor: and fix now one in front of which you enter into it a thread in the two ends of the skin, with the two ends of the silken thread that is under the skin from the inside, until you make it penetrate from the other side, and you have already gathered the two ends of the skin, and the two ends of the silken thread: and there are four orders.
Deinde stringe cum filo duplo in circumitu acus aliquotiens a duabus partibus simul, quousque sint aggregata duo labia uulneris aggregatione decenti.	Then tie it with a double thread around the needle from both sides at the same time, until the two lips of the wound have been gathered together by the falling in: and there are two threads.
Deinde dimitte grossitudinem digiti etiam, et fige in eis acum aliam: postea reta eam cum filo, sicut fecisti cum acu prima.	Then let go of the grosness of the finger as well, and fix another one in it: then make it straight with a thread, as you did with the needle first.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum eo quo indiges ex acubus, donec compleas constrictionem uulneris totius.	So do not cease doing this with it as long as you feel pain from the spine, until you complete the compression of all the wounds.
Et sint acus mediae inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem: quoniam acus subtiles ualde uelociter incidunt carnem: et grossae sunt difficilis introitus in cutem: propter illud oportet ut sint mediae in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	And let the points be of a medium size between thickness and slimness: for thin points wound the flesh quickly; and thick ones enter difficultly into the skin: therefore it is necessary that the points be of a medium size both in thinness and in thickness.
Et non oportet, ut figatur acus in duabus extremitatibus cutis propinquae multum: ut non incidatur caro uelociter, et aperiatur uulnus ante consolidationem sui, et non elongentur etiam cum sutura, ut non prohibeatur uulnus a consolidatione.	And it is not necessary that the point should be placed near both ends of the skin very much: lest the flesh be wounded quickly, and the wound open before its consolidation, and also be stretched with the stitch so that the wound does not be prevented from its consolidation.
Deinde incide extremitatem acuum, ut non laedant infirmum apud somnum suum: et pone eis puluillos ex pannis ab omni parte, qui teneant extremitates acuum: et dimitte eos, donec scias quod uulnus iam consolidatum est.	Then cut the ends of the points so that they do not hurt the sick person while he is sleeping: and put thereon little pieces of cloth from all sides which shall hold the ends of the points: and let them alone until you know that the wound is consolidated.
Et haec quidem species suturae cum acubus taliter est conuenientior in uulneribus paruis.	And this sort of stitch with points is much more convenient for small wounds.
Quoniam sufficit in sutura eorum acus una, aut duae, aut circiter eas.	For a stitch of their points is sufficient, or two, or three around them.
Sutura autem secunda communis est, ut aggreges cum sutura extremitates quatuor: extremitates, duas cutis, et extremitates duas sifac in uice una, cum acu in qua sit filum inuolutum aequale in subtilitate, et grossitudine.	But a second common stitch is to bring together the ends of four: the ends of the two pieces of skin, and the ends of the two sutures in one thread, with a point in which the fillet is rolled up of equal thinness and thickness.
Deinde quando penetraueris cum acu has extremitates quatuor, reduc acum a parte a qua incaepisti eadem, ut cadat filum retatum a superiori parte uulneris: ut sit sutura, sicut sutura panni quo stringuntur panni, et pone inter omnem suturam quantitatem grossitudinis digiti minoris.	Then when you have penetrated with the point the four ends, draw it back from that part from which you began to take it, so that the fillet is stretched from the upper part of the wound: in order that there may be a stitch, as if it were a stitch of a cloth with which the cloth is tied up, and place between each stitch a quantity of thickness of the little finger.
Hanc autem suturam sciunt homines.	This kind of stitch is known to men.
Et cum hac sutura ego sui uulnus quod acciderat uiro in uentre suo, qui fuerat uulneratus cum cultello, et erat disruptio uulneris maior palmo uno: et exierat ex intestinis circiter duos palmos ex intestino medio, et erat disruptio in medio uentris.	And with this stitch I sewed up a wound in the man's belly, which had been cut by a knife, and the cut was deep about a handbreath: and there came out of his bowels round about two palms' length of middle intestine, and the cut was in the middle of the belly.
Reduxi ergo illud postquam stetit intestinum eius extra uulnus xxiiii horis.	He then reduced that after the intestine had rested outside the pelvis for 24 hours.
Consolidatum est ergo uulnus in spacio quod fuit circiter XV dies: et curaui ipsum, et sanatus est: et uixit post illud annis multis, conuersatus in suis dispositionibus.	So the wound had healed in about 15 days, and I nursed it, and he recovered: and after that he lived for many years, in good health.
Et medici iudicauerant, quod non sanaretur.	And the doctors said that he would not recover.
Et ex miraculo fuit, quod non curaui illud cum unguento.	But by a miracle I healed it without ointment.
Quoniam fui in loco in quo non inueniebatur unguentum, neque aliquid ex medicinis.	Because I was in a place where the ointment was not available, and there were no medicines.
Posui ergo super uulnus cotum uetustum bis in die, et assiduaui ablutionem eius cum aqua mellis, donec sanatum est.	So I put a wet cloth on the wound twice a day, and I bathed it with honey water until it healed.
Duas autem species suturae proprias dicam secundum narrationem sermonis.	But there are two kinds of surgical sutures, which I will describe according to the account.
Et est, ut incipias cum sutura acuta: et intromittas acum ab exteriori ad interiorem partem.	And it is as if you were to begin with an acute stitch, and to insert the thread from the outside to the inside part.
Cum ergo penetrat acus in cutem, et in lacertum euntem secundum longitudinem et latitudinem totius corporis: dimitte extremitatem sifac in latere in quo intromisisti acum, et fac penetrare in extremitatem aliam ab interiori parte ad exteriorem in extremitate altera mirach.	When the needle therefore penetrates the skin, and goes into the fold according to the length and width of the whole body: release the end of the thread that you inserted from the outside, and let it penetrate the other end from the inside to the outside at the other end.
Cum ergo feceris eam penetrare, tunc fac eam penetrare secundum hoc in eadem hac extremitate mirach ab exteriori parte ad interiorem: et dimitte extremitatem sifac, quae est in hoc latere, et fac penetrare acum in extremitatem alteram ab interiori parte ad exteriorem: et fac penetrare cum penetratione tua qua facis eam penetrare in sifac extremitate mirach, quae est in parte eius, donec penetret in ipsum totum.	When you have thus made it penetrate, then let it penetrate according to this in the same end towards the back from the outside to the inside: and release the end of the thread that you inserted from without, and let it penetrate the other end from within to without at the other end.
Deinde incipe etiam ab hoc eodem latere, et sue ipsum cum extremitate, quae est ex sifac in latere alio, et extrahe acum ex cute quam penetrauit.	Then also from this same side, and with the same end, and draw it out of the skin where it penetrated: and take the thread that has passed through the skin.
Deinde reduc eam in illam cutem, et sue extremitatem sifac, quae est in latere alio, cum hac extremitate mirach: et extrahe eam ex cute quae est ex parte eius, et fac illud uice una, et alia: et fac illud uice post uicem, usquequo suas extrinsecum totum secundum illud exemplum.	Then also reduce it into the same skin, and with the other end draw it out of the skin, and take the end that was in the back with this end towards the front: and let it go out of the skin from that part, and make this end move once, and the other move twice: and let it move so as to go round all outside according to this example.
Et summa huius suturae, est ut suas sutura pellipariorum qua suunt pelles: ita ut suas sifac uice una ex parte una extremitate cutis: et ut dimittas eam uice alia ex parte alia, donec compleas.	And the outline of this stitch, is as its stitches are sewn together by the skin: so that its one thread goes from one end of the skin; and so that you dismiss it with another thread from the other side until you have finished.
Secunda species suturae propriae, quam dixit Gale nus.	The second type of stitch is a special kind of stitch, which has been described by Galen.
Iste eius sermo narratus est, ut suas eam secundum similitudinem, qua suunt eas quidam medicantium, ita quod aggregant omnem partem ad comparem suam conuenientem per naturam: et applicant extremitatem sifac ad eius aliam extremitatem, et extremitatem mirach ad extremitatem eius aliam.	This description of the stitch is told as if it were saying, in accordance with a certain similarity, how some physicians put it together, so that it gathers all its parts in a way that is appropriate to nature: and they apply one end to another end, and one end to another.
Et illud fit secundum quod narro tibi.	And this is what I will tell you.
Oportet ut figas acum in extremitatem mirach propinquam tibi ab exteriori parte, et facias eam penetrare ad interiorem in eo solo: et dimittas duas extremitates sifac.	It is necessary that you fix this at the end of the midline near to you from the outside part, and let it penetrate into the inside in that place alone; and dismiss two ends of the thread.
Deinde reuolue acum, et fac eam penetrare ab exteriori parte ad interiorem in duas extremitates sifac, scilicet utrinque.	Then turn around this again, and let it penetrate from the outside part to the inside at both ends of the thread, that is to say, on either side.
Deinde reuolue utrasque, etiam fac penetrare utrasque ab interiori usque ad exteriorem, in duas extremitates mirach alias, quae sunt in latere opposito.	Then turn around both of them, and also let both of them penetrate from the inside to the outside, in two ends of the midline, which are opposite on either side.
Et iste modus suturae est melior sutura communi facili, et est sutura cuius praecessit rememoratio.	And this mode of sewing is a better stitch than an ordinary one, and it is a stitch whose recollection came before.
Iste est ergo sermo Galeni etiam.	This is, then, the speech of Galen as well.
Et dixerunt quidam.	And certain people said:
Retificatur sutura uentris cum duabus acubus.	The stitch should be straightened out for the foot with two toes.
Quod est, ut intromittas in eis utrisque filum unum: et incipe cum intromissione acus, ex eo quod est apud te, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, secundum suturam eorum qui suunt coria aequaliter.	That is, so that you put one thread into both of them; and begin with the introduction of the acupuncture from there where it is in you, and let it penetrate to the other side, following the pattern of those who sew their skin together evenly.
Et scias, quod quando disruptio est in medio uentris: tunc sutura eius est difficilior quam reliquorum locorum uentris.	And you should know that when the break is in the middle of the foot: then the stitch of it is more difficult than at other places of the foot.
Iudicium uero medicationis uulneris, est iudicium reliquorum uulnerum.	The judgement, however, on the treatment of wounds, is a judgement on the other wounds.
Quod est, quia quando tu consequeris uulnus recens cum sanguine suo, antequam alteret ipsum aer: et reducis intestinum, et suis ipsum, et aptas ipsum: tunc pone super puluerem incarnatiuum.	That is, because when you sever a fresh fracture with its own blood, before it alters itself with air; and reduce the intestines, and its own self, and fit self: then place on the powder of incisions.
Quod si aer iam alterauit uulnus: tunc pone super ipsum quaedam unguenta, quae sunt tibi praesentia, donec faciant pus: et cadant fila, et consolidentur sifac, et mirach.	If the air has already altered the fracture: then place on the wound some ointment, which are present with you, until it makes pus: and fall off the strings, and solidify the sifac, and improve.
Deinde cura illud sicut est curatio reliquorum uulnerum, donec sanetur.	Then care for that as is the cure of other wounds, until it heals.
Si autem non sunt tibi praesentes medicinae, tunc pone super ipsum statim, exquo incipit emittere pus, cotum uetus: et permuta ipsum bis in die, sicut docui te, donec sanetur.	If you do not have the present medicines, then place on the wound at once, so that it begins to emit pus, and change the poultice every day, as I have taught you, until it heals.
Nam tu non indiges medicatione alia in pluribus dispositionibus, quando uulnera sunt simplicia.	For you do not need other medicine in many dispositions when wounds are simple.
Si autem times, quod communicet uulnus membris principalibus in laesione, tunc oportet ut submergas lanam lenem in oleo temperatae caliditatis, aut in oleo rosato: et pone ipsam in circumitu locorum quae sunt inter inguina, et sub ascellas.	If you should suspect that the fracture is communicating with a main member in the injury, then it is necessary that you dip the linen in oil of moderate heat, or in rose oil: and place it on the wound in the circle of the places which are between the hips, and under the armpits.
Quod si sentit dolorem, aut punctiones, aut putrefactionem in intestinis suis (nam multotiens accidit illud) tunc clisteriza ipsum cum uino stiptico, nigro, tepido: praecipue si putredo iam peruenit in intestino, et facta est exitura penetrans usque ad concauitatem eius.	If it feels pain, or punctures, or putrefaction in its intestines (for this often happens) then clisterize the wound with black wine, hot, especially if putridness has already reached the intestine, and has made an exit penetrating up to excretion.
Et scias, quod illud quod est ex intestino grosso, est facilioris sanationis: et quod ex eis est ex subtili, difficilioris sanationis.	And know that what is from the large intestine is easier to heal: and that which is from the small one is more difficult to heal.
Intestinum autem quod nominatur Ieiunum, non suscipit sanationem ex uulnere quod accidit in eo omnino: et illud est propter multitudinem eius, quod est ex uenis, et magnitudine earum, et propter subtilitatem corporis eius, et propinquitatem ipsius naturae neruorum.	But the intestine which is called Jejunium does not accept healing from a fracture that has happened in it: and this is because of the multitude of its folds, that it is from fractures, and its great length, and because of the lightness of its body, and the nearness of its nerves.
Si autem illud quod procedit ex uulnere est zirbum, et consequeris ipsum recens: reduc ipsum secundum reductionem tuam, qua reducis intestina aequaliter.	If however that which proceeds from the fracture is sharp, and you succeed in reducing it: reduce the intestine according to your reduction, reducing the intestines equally.
Si uero praeteriit ei spacium, et iam factum est uiride, aut nigrum: tunc oportet ut stringas ipsum cum filo supra locum qui denigratus est ex eo, ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	If he has indeed passed the time, and it has already become viridescent or black: then you should tie him up with a rope above the spot that has been darkened by him, so that blood does not flow.
In zirbo enim sunt uenae et arteriae.	For in such a place there are veins and arteries.
Deinde incide quod est praeter illud ligamentum, et pone duas extremitates fili pendentes ex inferiori parte uulneris extra ipsum: ut alleuietur super te attractio eius, et extractio ipsius apud casum zirbi, et emissionem pus uulneris.	Then cut where that ligament is, and place the two ends of the rope hanging down from the lower part of the wound outside of himself: so that there will be a drawing away from you of his attraction, and extraction of himself from the wound at the side of the sinew, and emission of pus from the wound.
¶ Rememoratio uulneris quod accidit in Intestino.	Remembering the wound that happened in the Intestine.
Quando accidit disruptio in Intestino, et est parua: tunc possibile est, ut restauretur in quibusdam hominibus: propterea, quia ego uidi qui fuit uulneratus in uentre suo cum percussione lanceae, et erat uulnus a dextra stomachi, et antiquatum est uulnus: et factum Fistula, et exiuit ex eo egestio, et uentositas.	When the rupture happened in the Intestine, and it was small: then it is possible that he can be restored to some men: indeed, for I saw who was wounded in his belly by a lance thrust, and there was a wound from the right side of his stomach, and an old wound: and there was a fistula, and there came out excrement, and vomiting.
Posui ergo curationem, usque quod ego non fui confisus in sanatione eius: neque cessaui subtiliare ipsum, donec sanatus est, et consolidatus est locus.	So I applied the treatment, until I was confident about his recovery: and I did not hesitate to examine him, until he was healed and the place had been hardened.
Postquam ego uidi locum iam consolidatum, timui super infirmum, quod accideret super infirmum accidens malum in uentre suo: et non accidit ei ex illo accidens malum.	After I saw that the place was now hardened, I feared for the illness that might happen to him in his belly: and it did not happen to him from that event any evil.
Et remansit in melioribus dispositionibus suis, comedens et bibens, et futuens, et intrauit balneum, et exercitatus est in dietis suis.	And he remained in his better state of health, eating and drinking and enjoying himself, and going into a bath, and exercising himself in his walks.
Et iam dixerunt quidam experimentatorum, quia quando accidit in Intestino uulnus, et est paruum: tunc oportet ut ligetur secundum hunc modum.	And some of the experimenters said, for when it happened in the Intestine a wound, and it was small: then he should be tied up in this way.
Et est, ut accipias formicas magnorum capitum.	And is, so that you take big-headed ants.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, et pone formicam unam ex eis quae habeant os apertum super duo labia uulneris.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound, and place one ant on them, which has an open mouth on the two lips of the wound.
Cum ergo capit super ea, et stringit os suum, abscinde caput eius, adhaeret enim, et non soluitur.	So when you lift it up over them, and tie his mouth: a knot is tied in it, for it clings to them and does not untie itself.
Deinde pone formicam aliam prope primam, et non cesses facere illud cum formica post formicam secundum quantitatem uulneris totius.	Then place another worm near the first, and do not cease to make that worm move after the second quantity of wounds on the whole body.
Deinde reduc ipsum, et sue uulnus.	Then reduce the wound, and apply the poultice.
Illa enim capita remanent annexa in Intestino, donec cibetur Intestinum, et sanetur, et non accidat infirmo nocumentum penitus.	For those remaining heads attached to the intestine, until the intestine is fed, and heals, and does not cause any harm to the whole body.
Et iam possibile est, ut ligetur Intestinum etiam cum filo subtili: quod abstersum est ex intestino animalis, annexo cum eo postquam intromittitur in acum.	And it is also possible that the intestine be tied together as well with a thin thread: which is taken from the animal's intestine, attached to it when it is inserted into the wound.
Et est, ut accipias extremitatem huius fili ex intestino, et excarnetur multum.	And it is, so that you take the end of this thread from the intestine, and let there be a lot of flesh removed.
Deinde liga in extremitate eius filum lini subtile inuolutum.	Then tie the end of this thread with a thin piece of linen.
Deinde intromitte illud filum in acum, et sue cum eo intestinum.	Then insert that thread into the wound, and apply it to the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum in disruptionem.	Then reduce the wound to the dissection.
Et iste modus suturae cum formicis et intestino, non est nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	And this method of suturing with the worm and the intestine is not anything but second to the first in trust and hope.
Scias, uulnus quod est magnum, amplum, praecipue si est in uno intestinorum gracilium: tunc non est ingenium nisi subtiliatio, neque est eius sanatio omnino.	Know that the wound which is large and broad, especially if it is in one of the thin intestines: then it is not a skill unless it is a delicate operation, nor is its healing at all certain.
¶ De cura Zuchemen, et Fistularum.	The care for Zochaemen, and Fistulae.
Caput LXXXVIII.	Head LXXVIII.
Scias, quod omne uulnus, aut apostema quando ueterascit et antiquatur, et fit ulcus, et non consolidatur, et emittit pus semper, et non abscinditur: tunc nominatur uniuersaliter in quocunque membro fuerit Fistula, et nos nominamus ipsum Zuchemen.	Know that all wound, or ulcer when it is old and aged, and turns into a sore, and does not heal, and always discharges pus, and does not close: then it is called generally in any member a Fistula, and we call it by that name Zochaemen.
Et Fistula quidem est secundum ueritatem nodatio filtrata, dura, alba: cum qua non est dolor, cui est concauitas pennae auis: et propter illud nominant eam quidam Risati, id est, pennam.	And a Fistula is indeed by the bitterness of an ulcer, hard, white: which does not cause pain, with which the feathers are bent inwards: and for that reason it is called by some Risati, that is to say, feather.
Et est in quibusdam horis humida, quae emittit pus.	And it is in certain hours moist, which discharges pus.
Et fortasse scinditur humiditas in quibusdam horis.	And perhaps it is broken up by moisture at certain times.
Et quandoque est haec humiditas multa, et est pauca: et est grossa, et est subtilis.	And when this moisture is much, and it is little; and it is thick, and it is fine.
Et ego iam praemisi in diuisione, tunc cum dixi uulnera, quod omne ulcus quod non sanatur, neque nascitur in eo caro, non est illud nisi propter unam nouem caussarum.	And I have already pre-empted in the division, then when I said wounds, that any wound which does not heal, nor is born in it flesh, is not this but only because of a new cause of diseases.
Quarum una est, aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore: aut propter maliciam eius: aut quoniam inter ipsum, et super labia eius est caro dura, prohibens natiuitatem carnis: aut quia est multae sordis et sordiciei: aut quoniam ulcus in seipso est putridum, et materia quae mittitur ei est malae qualitatis: aut quoniam medicina est inconueniens in curatione eius: aut quoniam corruptio cadens in regione est genus pestilentiae, aut per proprietatem in regione, sicut accidit in Caesaraugusta: in qua fit difficilis digestio aegritudinum, et tardatur in ea sanatio apostematum per naturam: aut quoniam in eo est os unum, aut numerus ossium.	Of which one is because of the scarcity of blood in the body; or because of the malice of it; or because it is between itself and on its lips hard flesh, preventing the birth of flesh; or because it has much dirt and filth; or because the wound is putrid within itself, and the matter that is cast out of it is bad quality; or because the cure is inconsistent with its cure; or because the corruption falling in the region is a kind of pestilence, or by virtue of the region, as happened in Caesaraugusta: for in this it is difficult to digest diseases, and healing is delayed in it by nature's means: or because there is only one jaw, or because the number of bones.
Et ego iam ostendi omnes istas caussas et signa earum, et curationes ipsarum cum medicinis in diuisione: et oportet hic ut faciam te scire curationem Fistulae et Zuken, quae fit per uiam operationis cum manu.	And I have already shown all the stations and causes and signs of them, and their cures with doctors in a division: and it is necessary here that I should tell you about the cure of the fistula and the zuken, which is done by means of an operation with the hand.
Scias ergo, quod Fistula accidit in omnibus membris corporis.	You must know that the fistula happens in all the members of the body.
Nam ex eis sunt Fistulae quae perueniunt ad uenas magnas et arterias, aut neruos, aut sifac: aut ad intestinum, aut ad uesicam, aut ad aliquam ex costis: aut ad aliquam ex spondilibus dorsi, aut ad aliquam iuncturarum compositarum compositione: sicut manus, et pedis: et ex eis sunt quae uadunt ad propinquitatem membri principalis, et similium.	For from them are the fistulas that reach to great veins and arteries, or nerves, or to the intestines, or to the urinary bladder, or to some of the ribs: or to some of the vertebral bones, or to some of the joints made up: like the hands and feet: and from them are those that reach to the proximity of the main member, and similar.
Quae ergo ex his Fistulis est secundum hunc modum, est ex aegritudinibus difficilis sanationis, et non recipit curationem, et occupatio cum ea est labor et ignorantia.	Which of these fistulas is difficult to heal from this illness, and does not receive a cure, and the occupation with it is work and ignorance. Et quod in illis est sanguinis interius, et materiola putrida mittitur, et per eam uel male uel mediocrem curare possumus: sicut in fistula que facit inter nervum occipitulos, cuius causae sunt capite oribus, et torqu
Quod si est ex Fistulis aliqua cuius profunditas non peruenit ad haec loca quae dixi: et speras, et confidis in curatione eius, et uis peruenire ad cognitionem illius, tunc accipe tentam ex aere, aut ferro, si Fistula tendit secundum rectitudinem, et perquire eam cum ipsa.	If it is from fistulas of whose depth does not reach these places which I said: and you hope and trust in its cure, and you see to the understanding of it, then take a trial from air or iron if the fistula runs according to the right way, and examine it with itself.
Si autem in Fistula est tortuositas, tunc inuestiga eam cum tenta de plumbo subtili.	But if there is a curvature in the fistula, then investigate it with a thin lead probe.
Quoniam plumbum cum lenitate sui corporis alleuiatur, et curuatur circa tortuositatem.	For lead, with its gentle alleviation of one's own body, and its curative power concerning curvature.
Quod si Fistula est habens orificia multa, non est tibi possibile ut significes super eam cum tenta.	That if the fistula has many openings, it is not possible for you to indicate it with a probe.
Clisteriza ergo ex eis orificium ex orificiis suis.	Therefore let one inspect the openings from among its openings.
Nam humiditas qua clisterizas ipsum, uadit uersus orificia alia, et currit ex eis.	For because of the moisture that clisterizes him, it examines towards other openings, and it runs out of them.
Deinde exquisite inquire secundum quem modum est tibi possibile: ut cognoscas quod illic est os, aut neruus, et est Fistulae concauitas longinqua, aut propinqua: aut est Fistula una cui sunt orificia multa, et sta super totum illud, cum summa fortitudinis tuae: cum interrogatione tua, qua interrogas infirmum, et inuentione doloris apud compressionem cum manu tua super locum, et similibus ex significationibus et caussis accidentibus apostemati.	Then ask to inquire after the manner by which it is possible for you: that you may know that there is a mouth, or a nerve, and that the fistula runs distant or near: or that the fistula is one of whose openings are many, and that it stands over all of them, with your greatest strength: when your inquiry, that you interrogate the sick, and your finding of pain at compression with your hand on the place, and similar indications and causes of accidents apostemated.
Cum ergo steteris super omnia illa statione uera, tunc uade ad curationem secundum confidentiam: et est, ut consideres tunc, si est Fistula propinqua apparens, aut in loco saluo longinquo a iunctura, aut a neruo, aut arteria, aut uena, aut uno locorum quae dixi tibi: tunc seca Fistulam secundum quod praemissum est ex narratione mea, et aufer quod est in ea ex filtratione, et carnibus corruptis, quod nascitur in orificio eius ex carne, aut thelul, et similibus: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	When then you stand by all of those stations with a true stance, then proceed to cure according to your confidence: and it is, when you consider then, if the fistula is near apparent, or in a healthy place distant from the junction, or from a nerve, or an artery, or a vein, or one of the places which I said to you: then dry up the fistula according to what was preceded in my narrative, and remove whatever is in it from filtration, and corrupted meats, which grows in its orifice out of flesh, or a tendon, and similar things: and cure it, until it heals.
Si autem Fistula est longinquae profunditatis, et est secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut seces eam in profundo quantum est tibi possibile.	But if the fistula is of a deep distance, and runs according to the right way: then it is necessary that you separate it in the depth as far as it is possible for you.
Deinde mundifica ipsam ex omnibus carnibus eius corruptis.	Then wash it with all its corrupted flesh.
Deinde administra licinia inuoluta in medicinis acutis: et intromitte ea usque ad concauitatem Fistulae quam comprehendisti cum ferro: fac cum ea illud aliquotiens, donec corrodat medicina acuta totum quod remansit in concauitate Fistulae ex corruptione.	Then administer the poultice of vinegar mixed with acute medicines: and insert it until the fistula which you have confined with iron is closed; do this several times, until the acute medicine has completely eaten away what remains in the closure of the fistula from the corruption.
Deinde restaura ipsam cum unguentis quae generant carnem sanam, donec sanetur.	Then restore it with ointment which generates healthy flesh, until it heals.
Si uero non sanatur per illud, tunc cauteriza ipsam secundum quod narrauimus.	If it does not heal with this, then cauterize it according to what we have described.
Si ergo caussa Fistulae est os, et certificatur apud te illud: tunc inquire ipsum, et seca ipsum secundum quod narraui tibi: si non prohibet te aliquid ex uena, aut neruo, aut membro principali, sicut diximus.	If the cause of the fistula is an orifice, and you have confirmed this to me: then examine it, and dry it up according to what I have told you: if it does not permit you to do anything of the new tissue, or nerve, or main member, as we have said.
Si ergo detegitur tibi os, et est in eo quiddam corruptionis, et nigredinis: tunc rade ipsum, donec auferatur corruptio eius tota.	If an orifice is discovered on you and there is some corruption and blackening: then shave it, until all the corruption is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the flesh with whatever will heal the flesh, until it heals.
Quod si non sanatur, et emittat pus sicut faciebat: tunc scias, quod tu non peruenisti ad totam eradicationem corruptionis.	That if it does not heal, and it discharges pus as it did before: then you should know that you have not completely removed the corruption.
Detege ergo super illud secundo, et exquisite fac rasionem eius, et mundificationem ipsius cum ultima fortitudine tua.	Therefore examine it again with a scalpel, and feel whether there is any resistance to the razoring of flesh, and wash it thoroughly with your last strength of cleansing.
Deinde restaura ipsum.	Then restore it.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est: et si non, tunc scias quod illa corruptio est in profunditate longinqua corporis, quam non es consecutus.	If it heals well, then that is good; and if not, then you should know that that corruption is deep within the body, to which you have not gained access.
Non est ergo tibi in ea ingenium, nisi dimittere ipsam naturae.	It is therefore not your work, unless you let nature take its course with it.
Quod si corruptum est os paruum, et est possibile tibi, attrahe ipsum cum forficibus subtilibus quae conueniunt ad illud.	That if the corruption is in a small orifice, and it is possible for you, attract it with subtle hooks which are appropriate for it.
Si autem sunt ossa multa, tunc exquisite fac attractionem eorum omnium, neque dimittas ex eis aliquid cum tua fortitudine.	If there are many bones, then feel whether all of them can be attracted, and do not let anything go with your strength.
Si uero contrarietatem facit tibi aliquid ex humiditatibus, et non est in incisione eorum timor, uel error: tunc incide illas humiditates et carnes, si sunt illic, et libera ossa.	If anything that you are attracting from moisture causes you any difficulty, or there is any error or doubt in cutting them, then cut the moisture and flesh, if they are there, and free the bones.
Si uero non est tibi praeparatio auferendi ossa ex hora tua, tunc pone super uulnus quod putrefaciat ipsum: et dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat quod est in circumitu illorum ossium ex carnibus et humiditatibus.	If indeed you are not prepared to remove bones from your body at the right time, then place them on the limb that should decay; and let go of them until they decay, as they decay around those bones from flesh and moisture.
Et custodi uulnus ut non consolidetur.	And guard the bone so that it does not harden.
Et constringatur sectio quam tu secuisti in operatione tua.	And let the incision that you followed in your operation heal.
Imo pone super ipsum, si times, cotum submersum sulfure trito cum oleo: aut cotum submersum in unguento aegyptio, aut aliquo unguentorum uiridium.	Then place on top of the bone, if you wish, three times soaked in sulfur with oil: or three times soaked in Egyptian ointment, or some other ointment.
Nam quando putrefient illae scilicet humiditates, et separantur ex eis ossa, alleuiatur ablatio eorum, et ipsorum attractio.	For when those humors begin to decay and the bones separate from them, it is a relief to remove them, and their attraction to each other.
Si autem est os unum magnum, sicut os cruris, aut os coxae, et similia illis, et quod ex eo corruptum est, est pars magna: tunc rade ipsum rasione ultima, donec auferatur illa nigredo et corruptio.	But if it is a large bone, such as a thigh or hip bone, and similar ones, and one that has decayed, then make the incision with a last cut until it is removed, until the decay and blackening are gone.
Deinde restaura uulnus.	Then restore the limb.
Si uero quod est in eo corruptum, est pars magna, et corruptio iam consecuta est medullam ossis, tunc necesse est serrare ipsum, et incidere ipsum totum usque ad locum, ubi peruenit corruptio: tunc cura ipsum, donec consolidetur.	But if that which is decayed in it is a large part, and the decay has already reached the marrow of the bone, then it is necessary to cut it off, and to make an incision all the way to the place where the decay begins: then care for it until it hardens.
Et ego narro tibi zuken, quae accidit uiro in crure suo: ut ponas ipsam exemplum et adiutorium super operationem tuam.	And I will tell you the story of the man who had a leg infection. So that it might serve as an example and a help for your operation,
Fuit uir iuuenis aetate circiter triginta annos, cui accidit dolor in crure suo, a caussa quae mota est super ipsum intra corpus, id est, ab interioribus, donec peruenerunt materiae ad crus, et apostematum est apostemate magno: et non fuit ei caussa extrinseca.	He was a young man of about thirty years of age, who had a pain in his leg, due to a growth that had risen up from within the body, that is, from inside, until it reached the flesh, and caused a large boil: but there was no external cause.
Extensum est ergo cum eo tempus cum errore medicorum, donec apertum est apostema, et concurrerunt cum eo materiae multae.	So when the time came with an error of the doctors, until it opened up and many fluids came out.
Et postposita est curatio eius, donec fistulatum est crus, et facta sunt in eo orificia multa: quae omnia emittebant pus, et humiditates corporis.	And his treatment was postponed until his leg was wrapped up, and many holes were made in him: all of which discharged pus and body fluids.
Curauit ergo ipsum multitudo medicorum circiter duos annos, et non fuit in eo sapiens in arte manus, donec uocatus sum, et uidi crus eius, et materias quae currebant ex illis orificiis cursu magno: etiam omne uiri corpus iam tabuerat, et color eius citrinus erat.	Therefore many physicians had dealt with him for about two years, and there was no wise man in the art of hands until I was called, and saw his wound, and the materials that flowed out of those orifices with a great course: also all his body was already dismembered, and his color was citrine.
Intromisi ergo tentam in uno locorum orificiorum, et peruenit tenta ad os.	So I inserted my hand into one of the orifices, and it came to the mouth.
Deinde perscrutatus sum orificia omnia: et inueni ea peruenire ad se inuicem ex omnibus partibus cruris.	Then I scrutinized all the orifices, and found them to pour out into one another on every side of the limb.
Properaui ergo, et secui super unum illorum orificiorum, donec detexi partem ossis: et inueni ipsum corruptum: quod iam corrosum erat, et denigratum, et putruerat, et perforatum erat, donec penetrauerat usque ad medullam.	Then I dished it up, and followed one of the orifices until I detected part of the bone: and I found it to be corroded: which was already corroded, and blackened, and rotted, and pierced, until it penetrated all the way into the marrow.
Serraui ergo quod detectum est mihi, et praeparatum ex osse corrupto.	Then I sharpened what I had detected, and prepared it from corrupt bone.
Et deputaui, quod non esset in osse nisi illa corruptio, quam abscidi, et serraui.	And I sheared off what was not in the bone except that corruption, which I could scrape off and sharpen.
Et ego iam eradicaueram eam.	And I had already scraped it off.
Deinde posui restaurationem uulneris cum medicinis consolidatiuis spacio longo.	Then I placed the wound with medical consolidates, spaced out in a long area.
Et non est consolidatum.	And this was not consolidated.
Deinde tentaui, et detexi super os secundo supra detectionem primam: et inueni corruptionem continuam cum osse: et serraui quod apparuit mihi etiam ex illa corruptione.	Then I inserted my hand again, and detected it on top of the first detection: and I found a continuous corruption with bone, and sharpened what was evident to me from that corruption as well.
Deinde conatus sum restaurationem eius.	Then I tried to restore it.
Et non est restauratum.	And this was not restored.
Detexi ergo super ipsum iterum, et non cessaui incidere os particulatim, et conari restaurationem eius: et non est restauratum, donec incidi ex osse circiter palmum unum, et extraxi illud cum medulla sua.	Then I detected on top of the limb again, and did not cease to cut the bone in pieces, and try to restore it: and this was not restored until I cut from the bone a palm-length piece, and extracted it with its marrow.
Deinde restauraui ipsum cum medicinis, et consolidatum est uelociter, et sanatum: et non fuit necessaria haec iteratio in operatione eius, et sectione ipsius, nisi propter dispositionem debilitatis infirmi, et paucitatem tolerantiae eius, et timorem meum super ipsum de morte: quoniam accidebat ei in omnibus horis ex superfluitate euacuationis syncopis mala.	Then I restored it with medical consolidates, and it healed quickly, and was cured: and this iteration in the operation, and cutting of itself, would not have been necessary but for the weakness of the nurse, and her lack of tolerance, and my fear over it dying: for it happened to him at all times from excessive bleeding during a syncopes.
Sanatus est ergo sanatione integra: et nata est in loco ossis caro dura, et bona facta est dispositio in corpore suo, et rediit uirtus eius: et conuersatus est in dispositionibus suis: et non fecit ei contrarietatem in ambulatione nocumentum omnino.	He was therefore whole in his healing: and a new bone grew in the place of the old one, and good order was established in his body, and his strength returned; and he continued in his habits: and he did not cause him any harm at all in his walking.
Si autem os eminens in loco corporis iam fractum est: tunc oportet ut serres ipsum, secundum hunc modum: et est: ut accipias ligamentum, et stringe ipsum in extremitate ossis eminentis: et praecipe alicui, qui extendat ipsum ad sursum: et pone ligamentum aliud ex lana grossius ligamento primo.
