But if the jaw is broken high up in the body already: then it should be closed by this means: that you take a piece of rope and tighten it at the end of the prominent bone; and you order someone to stretch it upwards: and you place another piece of rope, thicker than the first one, under the first.
Deinde liga ipsum super carne, quae est suh osse: et extende extremitatem eius, ut trahas carnem ad inferiora: et tu detegis carnem super locum quem uis serrare, ut non laedat Serra carnem.	Then tie the wound over the flesh which is next to the bone; and extend the end of it, so that you pull the flesh down from below: and then you cover the place where you want to close it up, so that the flesh does not hurt when you cut it.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a piece of wood or a board under the bone from below: because when you do this, it does not hurt the corrupted flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it should be so that there is a little space over the corrupted flesh, so that the bone does not appear in its appearance; and it does not seem to feel any pain: and it pushes at its own will towards another closure.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	That if the bone is corrupted and not prominent, a part of it continues with another part; and the corruption is in the middle of it or in one of its parts: then you cover all the flesh completely.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place a piece of wood below.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Then close that part from the first where there is corruption until it continues in another part; and let the closure be at a little distance from the corruption in length as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	That if the corruption is in the joint, then cut that joint which is corrupted, and close the bone where it continues from the other part.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	But if the corruption is in the connection of two joints, then there is no sense of touch in it but only abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	That if the corruption is in the palm of the hand or in the sole of the foot: then the matter in it is difficult to do much with.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	It is true that you should inquire how corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And cut off that part and clean it up in whatever way is possible for you, and with whatever skill you possess: when it does not give you a contrasting vein or nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that many tools and saws are used to cut these bones depending on the position of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness and fineness, and their size and smoothness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that you prepare the instrument suitable for any type of operation.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations require a long study when you hold the instrument in your hand.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And the knowledge of these methods will be a witness to your skills; for then you will have found out by yourself what is suitable for each disease and disorder.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am confirming to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments, which you should present as examples for those that you cut and test by your own experience on others.
Forma Serrae.	The form of a saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	The form of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The form of a third saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The form of a fourth saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This is the drawing of the above-described saw.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let it be made with an arch at its top and sharpness from steel: and its handle from beech, and let it be made with a pyramid-like angle at its base.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The form of the blade that cuts with ease.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this razor be made in the shape of a star-shaped claw: and its edges be made in the form of an ellipse.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not suitable unless it rubs with the head of the razor when it rusts, or has a wide and large opening.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	The form of a larger razor.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of a medium-sized razor.
Forma Rasorii lati.	The form of a wide razor.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	The form of the closed razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Form of a razor other thin.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Form of a razor other curved extreme.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	Form of a razor smooth, thin edge.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	Form of a razor with which bones are incised.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	Form also of a razor large.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to a Razor, and the end is like an edge of a saw: it is exhibited in many places from the incision of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	Form of a razor that comes together with its incision which has been pierced through from the bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	The end of it is triangular, acute at the ends.
Fit ex Indi.	Fit from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And also let everything that we have said about razors, incisers, and saws be.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On the incision of ends, and fastening of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Head 89.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The ends putrefy, or for an external cause, or an internal one.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	But when the patient has been cured of the corruption by the medicine of medicines, and there is no cure: and you see that the corruption incises on the member, which does not affect anything: then it should be incised on that member until where the consequence of corruption goes, so that the sick person may be healed through it from death, or from a worse defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of what has happened to it is that the member is ruined, until it is healed: which burns itself up, or腐敗s after decay: until it incises on that which follows it on the member, and grows into all the body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Place then with its incision, and likewise if the cause of corruption is from pounding of some fruits: as of sea-scorpions, and flies, and nettles, and others similar.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	But if the corruption or pounding is at the end of a finger, then cut off the finger, and not leave space for the corruption, so that it may incise all the way to the remaining hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And likewise if it has happened in the hand, then cut off from the root of a fire-steel, and not leave space for the corruption, until it takes hold in the arm of the steel.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if he has broken it, then cut the arm at the shoulder in its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If, however, it is a fracture and you see that he has gone all around the shoulder: then death is imminent for him.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And besides that cure, the amount of strength is necessary.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And likewise do for the foot, when there is a fracture in the toe, then cut it at the joint: and if he catches in the nail, then cut the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If, however, he has climbed up to the knee, then cut the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	That if the fracture has already reached above the knee, then there is no hope of recovery, unless amputation and forsake the sick to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the way to cut a limb off, or to break it is, to hold the lower ligament tight, which you want to cut: and tighten another ligament above that place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And stretch one minister of the ligaments downward: and stretch another minister of the ligaments upward upward.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you shall separate the flesh that is between the two ligaments with the chisel widely, until all the flesh is discovered.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then cut it, or break it.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it should be that you put all the parts of a cloth, so that the saw does not touch the healthy place: and cut the lame with added heat, and put on poultices.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If, however, there is a flow of blood inwards while you are working, then burn the place quickly: or put on some powder that stops the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then turn to your own cure, until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a fitting ligament, and cure it, until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I will tell you what happened to the man in his foot, this same thing that I told you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is, because it happened to the man's foot, a blackness that resembles the burning of fire: and that corruption first occurred in his toe, until it covered his whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore the boy recovered from the pus, after he saw the corruption affect his member with a great deal of pain and a change in its color; and it infected him at the joint, and he was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed, the same corruption happened to him in the third finger of his right hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	So he came to me, and I tried to heal the excess with him when I put on his hand from the medicines after purifying his body: and the excess did not respond, and it began to hurt again in another finger; until the corruption began to affect his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	He called me to cut his hand off: and I would not do it, hoping from me regarding the excess response: and I was also afraid of death by cutting his hand off next to the incision.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	Because the strength of the boy was above dying.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	And after he was disappointed from me, he returned to his land: and he came to me about it, because he wanted to recover, and he cut off all his hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I did not bring this account unless it be an aid to that which falls from the kind of this disease: and to show what means, and according to what happens.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	Regarding the care of abscesses, and the quality of the clisterization with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter XC.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When an abscess happens to be in some fleshy member, and the abscess lasts long, until it collects pus: then it bursts, or pierces, and that which is in it comes out, and there remains a hollow place like a pit: and the skin that is over it is as thin cloth: and does not spread to the last degree of corruption, nor imprisons into the mouth, the nerves, or the ligaments: it deserves to be called a sinus: but does not carry the name of a fistula: nevertheless, if it prolongs its space, until it impresses corruption in some of these members, then it is called a fistula, or a sore.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the cure is that you should strike off his whole skin like a sleeve; and especially when it has become thin, and made like a sheet of cloth; and believe that it will not stick to the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	But if you hope that the skin will stick and that that corruption will not come to pass at the last consequence: and if there is a thickness of flesh on the skin, then cure him with clister; and consider towards the neck.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus that is discharged from it has a foul odor: then clisterize him with Egyptian medicine, which is vinegar, and oil, and myrrh, taking equal parts, mixed together in a vessel; and let them boil on the fire, until the medicine reddens; and let it come to a syrup.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need; and dissolve it with water and honey, and clisterize it with him with the sin; and tighten the orifice of it, and let the medicine flow into it for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract him with the expression; let him be for days until the sin is clean, and the smell is gone.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And when you clisterize it with water of ash, when this medicine is not present with you; and is, that you should take the ash of oak wood, or the ash of oak; and throw it on the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then boil it, and clisterize it with it, until you believe that the sin is now washed away.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	That if the sick person does not tolerate Egyptian medicine or water of ash, then clisterize him with water and honey, to which has already been added some crushed myrrh.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or clisterize him with honey and wine mixed, for the property of honey is to clean and wash away; and the wine makes the sin adhere, especially when there is an abundance of stimulative and dry.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this sometimes and have trusted that the corruption of the sin has already been removed: then let him make him a clister, with what he does, to bring flesh into him.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is so that you may take from the plaster dyafinicon: and dissolve him with rose oil, and wine astringent: or make him a clister with certain medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I have written in the book of ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	That if the opening of the sinus is strict, in which the tube of the clister does not enter: then enlarge it a little with iron: or put in it the licorice that has been soaked in oil, in Egyptian ointment, or in basilico ointment, until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And likewise if the opening is also wide, then join the lips together with a stitch: and let go out of it a quantity in which the clister is to be made without adding anything.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And likewise if the opening from which the pus runs is elevated towards the upper part: then dry him up in a lower place that is in him, so that the pus may run down from it: because when the pus is constricted in the depth of the sinus, it prohibits flesh to be generated in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	That if it is not possible for you to dry the sinus all around below it according to what you want: then try, so that you prepare the member with preparation by which the pus runs out from it with ease according to what is prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try so that nothing of the pus is left in it at all: and take medicines consolidatio that are placed over the mark, suited to what you want.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them on a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	And have there such a quantity of cloth that it may communicate with the whole sinus.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps on the direct opening of the sinus hole, a little larger opening of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then spread on the other cloth with soft ointment according to the quantity of the hole: and put it in a distant position from the opening of the sinus, so that the outlet of the pus may be eased: and do not hold the cloth large, except after some days.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	And yet he who is above the sinus opening, he whom you stir at all times so that he emerges from it with pus: and as you know, the infection that comes out of it is much or little, digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And when you consider this place of the sinus again, whether the master feels pain there or not; and if there is no pain there, and if there is a pus there, or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When your treatment therefore extends thus far, and you see the matter that comes out above the sinus opening; then know that the sinus is already attached, or approaching attachment: then therefore solve it in the morning, or on the third day; and when you have solved the wound, then change the cloth with another, and renew the unguent.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If however the pus comes out of the sinus after a long time, do not despair concerning its attachment, for its healing approaches, since there are people who delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and there are those who bring it about in the opposite way.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	But if the pus comes out of the sinus after many days, then know that the sinus is not attached.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	But if the attachment of the sinus is delayed and its course is prolonged; then add to the drying up of medicines, that the doctors may make them dry in their substance, and in their power so as to be like the dyphinicon unguent, when added to it in excess of what is necessary from the oil.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And from this last, as regards its treatment, it is that you should take the dyphinicon unguent, and solve it with rose oil, and rub it on the old wound to the same extent as to its substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then therefore bind it up with it, and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And this same action is similar to that of the dye-finicon unguent when it is not present with you, and honey when you have decanted it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Take myrrh and aloe and olive oil; let them be thoroughly mixed together and then put on honey while it is still hot above fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then bind a cloth over the wound and tie it tightly around the sinew: and with the honey that you have prepared, cover the wound until it thickens: and then apply the powder on the wound, and bind it again to the cloth, and tie it up.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And when that is administered in it aristorcia long, and roots of the celestial liliy, and the liliy it self, and herb flour, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use either simple or aggregate ingredients, strain it through a sieve, and then apply the powder over the honey that you have poured out: and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If it does not heal with this cure: then you will know that there is corruption in its depths: or if it has already made an impression on the bones, or on the other hard parts of the body, or on the ligaments: then treat it with the cure of fistulas, as has been described.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	Of the cure of the panaritus and the scratched nail, and the cutting of the finger added, and the sectioning.
Caput XCI.	XCI.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	Panaritus is an abscess that comes out under the nail of the thumb or foot, and perhaps also from the other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When it is then prolonged in its course, and the cure of it is neglected, and an abscess forms under a warm thumb: or if it corrupts, and discharge pus, until it corrupts the nail root: and perhaps it also corrupts all of it, and perhaps it reaches corruption to the mouth, until it has a foul odor: and makes the tip of the finger wide, and makes its color dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When you then treat the wound, with what we have said in connection, and your treatment does not bring about a cure: then you must cut off all the excess that is left from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the nail after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	For the cauterization of the nail, for the wound is hot.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If the bone is indeed healthy, and the nail too, and the nail's additions are already compressing the flesh towards the insides, and it begins to sting and hurt: then you should put Radium under the angle of the nail that stings the flesh, and push it upwards: and cut into the flesh with ease, and place on top what remains of the flesh from the burning medicines, until it has all moved away.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for that with the nail, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	But if the corruption has already impressed on the bone, then you should cut into that bone and remove it: for it does not heal at all while it remains in it.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see the corrosion and the corruption penetrating into the finger, then cut it at one of its joints, according to what has been said above in its remembrance.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for that, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	But if there is a pulling or pounding of the nail: and there is a sharp pain in it, then you should let blood from the wounded part at first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp Spatemile, cutting across from top to bottom.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard it, so that the cutting does not reach the flesh under the nail, for you would make happen through it a very painful pain for the sick person, and it would be a cause of the birth of flesh added in place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for that place with what sits there pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger that is added in some hands of men, perhaps is whole of flesh: and perhaps there are bones in it, and perhaps there is a nail in it: and the birth of some of its joints, or the birth of its nail, perhaps is in the knuckle joint, or perhaps it is born in some of the joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	So this that is born in some joints of the finger does not move: and this that is born in the joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, if he is a man who has flesh, then it is easy to cut him.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, so that you strike him at the root with a broad knife.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	But for one whose birth is in the root of the joint, cure is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore, abstain from cutting him.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	But in that person who is born in the finger near the last knot, then it is necessary that you strike his first flesh with a round incision all the way to the mouth.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then clamp the jaw with one of those clamps that are convenient for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for the person, until he is healed.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	But the consolidation that happens in fingers opposite to each other, often happens or from the birth of a man, that is, he is born with it, or from the consolidation of a wound, or from a fire burn, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore, it is necessary that you separate that consolidation, until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them a chisel, or cloth soaked in oil with rose water: so that they do not unite quickly, and separate them: or place between them a thin piece of lead, until the spot joins together as it should.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And also if such a consolidation happens in some fingers with the palm, then dry that consolidation, according to how it is prepared and becomes the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	Regarding the wound:
Caput XCII.	Head XCI.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	The veins are closed, large, and full of melancholy effusions that occur in many parts of the body: and most of them are found in the legs, especially in the thighs of those who move about a lot, and of those who carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore, it is necessary that you administer strong purgation to the body from time to time with black cholera in order to eliminate the excesses.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then take blood from the patient with a bazilicus needle.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of these veins with iron is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And the other mode is, that he should hold fast the vein and draw all out.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	But the sectioning of it is according to this mode.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Clutch the leg first with warm water a lot, until the thick foul blood has dissolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then tighten the wound of the nurse from the upper side of his hip, all the way down to the knee with the rope.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry the leg in one place, or two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then he should hold fast the blood, that is to say, draw it out with his hand from the lower part of the leg, all the way up, and let it run first to the upper part.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the nail down below: until he walks out of blood, as much as you see will suffice, and what strength the nurse can bear.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Then bind it up: and order him, that he should refrain from foods which generate black cholesterol; and again let him undergo an evacuation and a phlebotomy, when the veins are filled, and that pain does the sick man.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	But his elevation is according to this mode.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	Scrape off the leg nurse, if there are many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then put him into a bath: or clutch him on the leg of himself with warm water, until he is red, and the veins are flowing; or exercise him strongly, if there is no present bath, until he is warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin at right angles to the vein's section along its length; or in the end of it near the knee, or in the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with a hook, and scrub off the scar from all parts, until you can feel it; and is it at the appearance of it, that you see it turn red to black by the decay.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	Then when he has come out from under the skin, you will see it white as a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce below it the radium, until it has been removed and has exited the skin: suspend it with a blind hook, gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then dry off another section next to that section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the buttocks until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then remove it with radium as you did, and suspend it with another hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then dry off another section, or more sections if you wish to do so.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then remove it and cut it at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then pull it out to the section above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And make it, until you have pulled it out of the upper section, or longer sections, until it has exited all of it: then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not submit to you for being removed and cut: then introduce a strong double-edged knife and tie it up, and remove it: or introduce below it the radium: and move your hand around all of it until it has exited.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And make sure that it does not get cut.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it will be difficult for you to remove it well, and it will enter into the body and cause harm.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	But when you remove it all: then place it on a place wet with wine and oil, or oil only: and take care of it, until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	That if the vine is contracted, having a tortuosity where it turns to the parts of it, and is not like what we have said according to the straightness: then you must find on all parts of its tortuosity, and the places of its turning.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with a hook, until you have removed it all: and make sure that you do not get cut by the section next to it, or hurt yourself: for it will be difficult for you to remove it from on top of you, or to pull it out.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Conserve therefore your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The form of incident which heals is vitis.
Forma Vncini caeci.	The form of incised wound which heals is vinum coptum.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	It is not curitis like the other Incision, nor is it acute extremity, so as not to wound the vein; and it is gross flexibility, mild: for if it were thin, it would be hurt by its own subtility: but there is a superfluity of grossness in it, as we have said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the extraction of a vein from the leg.
Caput XCIII.	Head 83.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in warm lands, such as Alizegi and the land of the Arabs, and in arid, hot lands, little tender, that is, in which grass does not grow, nor trees.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And indeed its generation is from putrefaction which occurs under the skin, as it happens within the bodies of serpents and worms ascariuses, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this vein is, that it happens in the leg a hot inflammation.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then the place becomes blistered.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then the vein begins to issue out from the place of its blistering, as if it were a root of a plant, or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	But when this extremitas of it appears, you shall then bind thereupon a fragment of lead whose weight is from a drachm to a claw-weight, up to two drachms and mark the same: and let go the lead suspended out of the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Howsoever it shall go forth from it to the externals, bind it within the lead and mark it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	Which if it should be prolonged for a long time, then cut a part of it, and bind the remainder.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it up into roots before it shall have gone forth all out.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if you should cut it, then it will contract itself and go into the flesh; and it makes happen a pustule, and decay in that place, and a bad wound.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	So then it should be handled gently and slowly extracted until it has completely emerged from the last of its own, and nothing remains in the body: and from this very vein emerges in some people which is five palms long and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And I had already reached it because he had emerged from 20 palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	But if you are injured at the time of your medical treatment: then insert a ray into that hole and pierce it with a long blade along with the body until all the contents have been completely discharged from it: and administer putrefaction to the site with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then take care of him with the cure of wounds.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this very vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears in the ankle of the foot, or in the foot itself: and many openings occur to it, and a branch emerges from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	So then take care of it as we have said in division, and with the above-mentioned things that were preceded.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	Regarding the section on worms born under the skin, and it is called the "bad trouble".
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter 82.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This "Illness" is called in some country "the bad trouble": for this often happens that worms emerge bare and a single one is born, which appears between skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it was felt throughout the body when it rose and fell: and it was perceived by touch when it walked from one member to another, until it stopped wherever it stopped in the skin, and emerged.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its origin is from the putrefaction of certain kinds of dung.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As happen worms and snakes, that is, earthworms, and pinworms in the stomach.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And they fear its maliciousness.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when he begins to move in the body and rises to a head, then perhaps it opens within him, and emerges, and destroys an eye: and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	So then if you are going to care for him and extract it, then that will not happen unless he walks or feels it himself.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, so that you keep what is above him, and what is below with strong constriction of the ligament.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry on top of him, and then extract him.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it penetrates into the flesh, and not into his whole body: then place on the spot a cautery with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And greater what is feared is corruption of him, which corrupts his eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	But if you see it has already reached the head near the eye, then tighten what is below with good tight constriction.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry on top of him, and then extract him.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the sick one uses his own purification, with medicines dissolving bad putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And he protects himself from foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	§ On the section on disease of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Head 105.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This disease is called in our land Nakir, and it is a pain that happens in some member, and then it changes from a member to another.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And indeed I have already seen him, according to what I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was called to a sick woman in some rooms.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And she took her arm, and I saw swelling of the lung in the arm joint.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after an hour had passed, I saw one swelling walk with a flame as if it were fire, rising faster than it can go: like silver in flight, when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	So then the pain left that place, and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then he sat for an hour, and ran through the remaining body, until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that he was writhing all over his whole body, according to what I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I am astounded at the swiftness with which he transfers his member from one part to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I too did not see this disease before, with my eyes, in such a way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I see many who suffer from the pain that one member causes another: and I do not see this one with my eyes, as I saw it in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that this is, except that it is for this reason, because that woman was from those who are from dry bodies of stinking limbs: hence it appears to the sense that this swiftness is transferred.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary so that it does not appear in this way with regard to those who are luscious and have humid bodies, of secret limbs.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When you then apply the cure to him, and the patient feels this pain: then if it appears to your eyes, as we have said, then lift him up quickly: and dry him out on top of him until he walks in that swiftness: and caustice the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If, however, you do not see this one with your eyes: then cure him by scrubbing the body, and with it what drives out the swiftness, and makes them red with foamy pills, and pills of bitter wormwood, and others like them.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	Regarding the extraction of arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter LXXVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows differ according to their species, and according to the places in which they are embedded in the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	However, there is a difference between them: for some have large tips, and some are sharp; and some are convexed, and some are concave.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And of these some have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And of these are the tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And of these are the stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	However, those that fall into members according to the two ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or if members are from main concavities, like the brain, heart, liver, lung, kidney, intestine, bladder, and similar to them.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore he falls upon any of these limbs, and the signs of death appear to you, which I shall tell you afterwards, then it is necessary that you should extract that arrow from him, for death will overtake him in that position.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these bad signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not buried deep within the limb, then extract it, and be concerned for the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	For when the signs of injury to the brain appear, when an arrow falls into it, and pierces the bone, and comes out above the brain, there happen: for there is a violent headache, and blurring of vision, and dizziness, and reddening of the eyes, and swelling, and reddening of the tongue, and spasm, and confusion of thought, and loss of memory, and cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood comes out from the nose, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is severed, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And there comes out of the wound's place a white, pulpy moisture.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And there comes out of it similar to a meat broth.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	But if these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it has not come out.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow that falls into the heart are: for it is near the left nipple: and feels as if fixed to a hard thing, not to a soft one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the arrow has a movement similar to a pulse: and black blood runs from the limb.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And follows it coldness of the limbs, and cold sweat, and fainting fit.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	So you know that death has certainly come.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow that wounds the lung is: blood spitting from the limb is frothy: and the veils that cover the neck, fall down, and change their color in front of the eyes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he breathes out great, deep breaths: and seeks cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If the arrow falls into the chest, which is within the breastplate: then it is close to the lower back: and it causes a great fever with severe pain, with sighing: and all the limbs of the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if an arrow falls into the belly, then perhaps it has exited from a little indigestion from something eaten.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly, and lodges there: it exits some stool from thebowels, or a piece of flesh, or an intestine which has already been torn.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	So there is no hope for its cure, nor for the extraction of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If an arrow falls into the bladder, and it exits urine: and it proceeds from it something to the outside, and the pain is stronger over the sick one: then know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining limbs, such as the face, neck, mouth, spleens, ribs, hips, and legs, are saved according to multiple dispositions: when the arrow does not hit a blood vessel or nerve: and the arrow is not harmless.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you that I saw such arrows, which he used to indicate by way of example for your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is, because an arrow fell into the eye of a man's tear duct, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	So I extracted it from him on the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and there was no harm to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from the Jew, which had fallen into his fat under his lower eyelid: and the arrow was now hidden, and I could not get it out unless I cut off part of his cheek, to which it was attached in its own wood: and it was a large arrow among the arrows of the Turks, with a soft iron, in which there were no bars.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	So the Jew was healed, and there was no bad happen to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I drew another bow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And it was an Arab bow, and that is where the ears are.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	Then I followed behind it with two arrows: and now she was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	So I went with care, until I had drawn her out: and the Christian was well.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I drew out another arrow from a man who had fallen into his belly: and we thought that he should die therefrom.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After which I left him for thirty days, and there was nothing changed in him from his habits, then I followed behind the arrow: and I followed it up, and drew it out: and he was well, and no misfortune happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man to whom the arrow had fallen on his back, and it was mending over him.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After which it was after seven years, the arrow came out at the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom the arrow had fallen into her belly, and it was mending over her, and the arrow remained within her: and there was nothing changed in her from her habits, and the woman did not find any harm in any of her natural actions.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man to whom the arrow had fallen on his face, and it was mending over him, and remained, not finding much pain in it: and there were many such things like this.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I drew out an arrow from the prince of the king, which had fallen into his nose, and was declining a little on the right side: and the arrow was hidden all together.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	So I was called to his cure after the fall of the arrow for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	Then I found the bow string very tight.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	So I asked her with careful touch, and I did not feel it: but he himself felt the prick and pain under his right ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	I therefore hoped that it was that point at the end of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	I therefore prepared the plaster with which to draw out the force of attraction and digestion, confident within myself that if I should remove the place, a sign would appear to me of the arrow, so that I might cut over it: and this did not happen in the place suggesting that the arrow was lying in wait there.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	I therefore persevered with the plaster for many days: and nothing happened, and the fracture was healed in the meantime: and he remained weak from being unable to remove it from that space for a number of days, until one day he felt an arrow in his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	I therefore placed sharp medicine on that fracture for many days, until it was open: and when I tried to move him, I felt the end of the arrow sticking into the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added the sharp medicine to the fracture through which it was open for a number of months, until we could see the end of the arrow clearly: and time passed with him while I was adding the sharp medicine.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then when the fracture had healed and I was able to push the bones together, and make them move, and they would not come out: then I did not cease to apply gentle pressure, and to devise means over it, until one day I pushed on it with bent forks, according to the form of their ends at the end of a chapter, so that I pulled it out.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the fracture.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And the doctors say that cartilage in the nose has not been restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	I therefore restored it, and the fracture was healed, and all the injury was healed with complete health: and he did not suffer from anything at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I will tell you the quality of extracting a certain kind of arrow: so that you may have a rule and a sign on it, which I did not mention.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	For the parts of this art and their distinctions do not comprehend with a description: nor does that book understand it, and the craftsman is prudent to compare little with much: and when he is present with him who is absent, he finds an operation new, and a tool new for going down matters foreign to this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	I say then, that arrows do not depart from the member on which they are fixed except by two ways.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Or by attraction from the place from which it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or by the opposite of the other part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And those that have exited from where they entered, or are an arrow going in a fleshy place: and is attracted, and exits.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	That if it does not submit to the exit at the time when it falls: then it is necessary that you should let go of it for a few days, until the flesh which is around it decays: and the attraction of it will be alleviated, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And likewise if it is drawn into a bone, and does not submit to you to the exit, then let go of it also for a few days: and again with the attraction and movement every day, until it exits.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	That if it does not submit to you to the exit after a few days, then you should make a hole in the bone from all sides with a sharp object, until the arrows increase.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then attract it, and remove it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	But if the arrow is fixed in the bone of the skull, and has already gone into one of the winds of the brain, and there appears to be some of the accidents I have mentioned: then refrain from attracting the arrow, and let it go, until it becomes equable after a few days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if the arrow reaches the skull, then death does not prolong for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, unless it is in the body of bone only, and does not penetrate as far as the skull: and remains for a few days sick, and does not happen to him any of those accidents: then use your wit in attracting the arrow and removing it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	But if it is fixed firmly, and does not submit to you to the attraction: then administer a sharp object around the arrow, as a nail: and then take care of the place, until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If however the arrow is already hidden in the place of the body and concealed and hidden from sense: then examine it with effort.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then attract it with some instruments that are suitable for attracting it.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot get above it, because of the constriction of the wound, and because of the length of the arrow in the deep: and there is no bone, or nerve, or vein: then find above it, until the tendon is enlarged, and it is possible to remove the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	That if there are ears that hold it, then free the flesh that is fixed in them from all sides, with all the effort that you can: and efforts, if it cannot be healed on the ears, and their twisting, until it heals.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And you when you administer the extraction of the arrow, wherever it is, then use the twisting of your hands, with forceps to all parts, until you make it heal: and the last subtility, so that the arrow does not break, and becomes difficult for you to attract it, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	That if you cannot get above it in one hour, then leave it for a few days, until what is around it putsrefies.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat it: for sure bandages If however the contradiction is causing you a flow of blood, then administer what we said in its chapter on healing: and protect your skill from cutting a vein, or a nerve, or a tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer the efforts in every way that you can possibly heal the arrow: and let it be with ease, and tranquility, or tardiness, and firmness, as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it should be that, when you take out the arrow, it is with a view to making the injured person recover his health according to the figure, according to which the arrow was in the wound of the arrow itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	For it is more certain.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	But if it is not possible for you to do that, then administer what is possible for you from figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	But if the arrow that comes out of the other side is already going out from it a little towards the outside: or makes a bump on the ends of the arrow by touch from the top part of the skin nearby, and you see it sticking out: then cut off over it, and make the incision according to the quantity that they hold in them the arrows.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then attract it: for it becomes easy to exit.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	But if it retains in the bone, then twist your hand according to its roundness, until it impresses the arrow in the bone, and magnifies itself: then attract it.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: leave it for a few days: then repeat it, until it exits.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	That if the arrow is in it, then push it with that.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	But if it fell wood, and you have to administer the push: then introduce into it an instrument that is smooth, so that it enters smoothly from its tail the arrow: then push it with that.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	But if the arrow is smooth, then push it with an instrument that enters into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow is relieved by this.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	That if the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary, so that smooth meat, in which is venenum: if it is possible for you to do this.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then take care of it with that when it comes into contact with that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	That if the arrow is falling in the chest, or in the abdomen, or in the groin, and it is close to you that you touch with your hand, and it is possible for you to cut over it: then cut off, and take care away from the incision of the vein, or nerve, and remove it.
