Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound, if you see it, and take care of that, until it is healed.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of the forceps, with which the arrows are removed.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	If the ears are similar in shape to the nose, and have been made like iron: when they are placed over the arrow, they do not allow it to move.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And from them there result many kinds, great and small and moderate, according to the quantity of the size of the arrow and its width and the constriction of the wound.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Their shape is a kind of cone.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And their form is deaf.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is the shape of deaf ears like a cone, so that the entrance into it may be relieved and driven in with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	This is the shape of a deaf ear, conic like a feather; so that the entrance into it may be relieved and driven in with it.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	Regarding the lancing of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Head 57.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty veins from which blood is drawn.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these in the head there are sixteen: two pulse veins, which are behind the ears, called the two herbs; and two arteries, which appear in the two temples; and two veins which come from the two eyes, which are called the two lookers-about; and a vein which is prepared in the middle of the forehead; and a vein which is at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guide-veins, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins which are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins which are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	These are called the Algecirich veins.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And two veins, which are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	But the veins that are bled in the arms, there are five veins in every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of these ears is called the cephalic, and proceeds from the side of the skull; and it is named by the common name the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And the Scaly.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And there is a middle vein, which is composed of a basal and a cephalic branch; and it is named the common body vein.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And the Basilica, and it is placed in the domestic side: and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And it is named by the people of many hands.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the tendon of the bicep, and it is placed on the edge of the wrist: and that one is in which bloodletting is done, and that one which appears above the thumb with a visible protrusion.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And the salvatory, and it is new which is between the ring and the little finger: and they are two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three hands.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is that which is under the thumb on the side of the palm.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is the saphenous vein, and its place is at the heel from the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And the third is the nerve, and its place is at the heel on the side of the palm.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three hands like those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	Now concerning the bloodletting of two veins after the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The bloodletting of two veins which are after the ears is an ancient practice for hemiplegia, hemianopia, saphena para, and bad ulcers on the scalp.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of bloodletting depends on how much is drawn.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, like a washing cloth for the head: and it rubs the back of the neck with a good rough rubbing.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then tie the sick man by his neck with a strap, until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their places are after the ears in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	So ask them with your finger, and where you feel the pulse of the veins under your finger, there are the signs with a caustic substance.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take the scalpel of the bloodletter, and that one is called the incisor.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then insert it into the flesh under a vein, until the bloodletter comes to the mouth.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then wipe your hand with the vein and the skin from above, and cut the vein with a cutting of the skin.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	The length of the incision should be equal to that of two fingers spread out, or about that: and let blood flow as much as necessary.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then tighten it with powder, and let it go, until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And already at the beginning of this book he preceded in the incision of ears, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	De the phlebotomy of the two arteries in the temples.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	In fact the two arteries which are in the two temples for phlebotomy, are for the old hemianopsia: and salt the palatine bone, and press hard: and run the course of the flowing acutes towards the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of phlebotomy is according to what I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	Let the patient turn his neck very much, until two veins appear with a manifest appearance: and show me the pulse of the ears under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	For then are the signs with the caustics.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then wet the skin above the vein with your index finger, and insert the phlebotome below it, and wet the vein above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut it, as you did with the two other veins: and let blood flow according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then remove the tourniquet and place your finger on one vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Then put on a powder and strings, and tighten it with strong pressure: and let go until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And already at the beginning of this book he preceded in the remembrance of ears, and their incision, and their extraction.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	De the phlebotomy of the frontal vein after phlebotomy of the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	In fact the iuementum of phlebotomy of the frontal vein is after phlebotomy of the head, for old diseases of the face: and for hemianopsia, and redness: and foul sores.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is according to what I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The injured man held his neck with his hands while blood flowed from him, until a new cloth appeared.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument called "Fossorum".
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its shape:
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the prominent point that is in the head of the "Fossor" above the cloth, and strike it with a pestle or something else in this manner; and let the blood run according to the quantity you want.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then solve the piercing wound, and tighten it, until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes open with a phlebotomist on the side.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, it is not necessary that there should be an acuter-ended phlebotomist like the other phlebotomists, rather than a wider-ended one.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And phlebotome it according to the transvention: since the mouth is near: and perhaps, when it is thin, the phlebotomy breaks when it is pressed.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	As for phlebotoming the veins in two tear-shaped places.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	However, the two veins which are in the two tear-shaped places of the two eyes, run to the eye from a wart and redness; and darken the eye, and cause facial ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of this phlebotomy is, that it should tighten the injured man's neck with blood flowing from him.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then phlebotome them: and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And the phlebotomy shall be made according to the transvention a little in length, with a little pestle, for there is no flesh in this place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If the phlebotomy is thin at the end, it may break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then let the blood run according to the quantity that you need.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place a cloth on them, and tighten them at night, and solve them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	As for phlebotoming the veins of the nose:
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	The veins of the nose are phlebotomized, which is useful for an acute fever, a strong blood pressure, facial illnesses such as hemianopia, and redness that has occurred in the face; above all, when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that it tightens the weak neck.
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then take his nose with your left hand, and take the phlebotome thin, long; and fix it on the mid-leporis of him, between that which distinguishes the nose according to the straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	For the new one is not apparent to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary that you make your hand with the phlebotome a little loose: and let the blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it up for one night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	For that is quickly healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	The Phlebotomy of the new-born Guidegi.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	For the two phlebotomies of Guidegi is to constrict the feverish, and to take hold of leprosy, and melancholy diseases, and impetigo and bad ulcers, and corrupting ones, that is, herpes zoster.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of these phlebotomies is such that they tighten the weak neck with a ligature on each side: and let the workman stand over the sick man's head, and let the sick man sit on a chair.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then take one phlebotomy long and wide a little.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out the measured quantity of blood, or according to what you see is necessary for that one.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do the same with the other new-born.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Then loosen the ligature and tighten two strings in the middle, so that the sick man does not get tighter.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let it go until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	For the wound is healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	The Phlebotomies of Al-Ghaberich:
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Al-Ghaberich is the phlebotomy to constrict: because it brings to the drink in the mouth, and corrupting of the tongue: and bad ulcers, also those that are in the naso, and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of phlebotomy is so that you may make the sick sit before you; and tighten his neck with a strap.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then you will open his mouth and look at the two nostrils; the one on the right side of the mouth is called the right nostril, and the second on the left side is called the left nostril, and each has a different color: the right nostril is red, and the left nostril is black.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And this is true: because there are little nostrils around them, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	So cut each one as you cut.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	But if there is a doubt about them on you, and you do not know which one of them it is: then you will cut at the larger nostril, and you will make known its quality.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And also do the same for the two nostrils that are on the upper lip; and much more so because the custom is with it: and cut the two nostrils that are on the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	De phlebotomia: Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	The two veins that are under the tongue phlebotomy is to test: it is true, because phlebotomy of the head is to make a test for any disease that is in the throat, and any disease of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of phlebotomy is so that the sick person sits between your hands to the sun: and wash his tongue, and look under his tongue on one side with one vein, and under his tongue on the other side with another vein; and let each one’s color change into blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	So phlebotomize each one of them, and take care not to hold your hand in phlebotomy.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For the veins are under it, and perhaps it will happen that there is a flow of blood out of them.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	De tribus venibus: Venae pedis sunt ad podum; venae coeque ad circumcisio
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The three veins that are cut in the foot; but there is a phlebotomy custom on all people.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And phlebotomy from them [i.e., the lungs] is done in two ways.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either pricking with a phlebotomy needle on the side: or oiling at the place of a cautery, and it is called Anelid; either drying with a phlebotomy knife, and it is called Alnelid.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is the form of it.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Anelid is, which is fitting for sectioning.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And from them are two kinds of phlebotomy needles, and they differ according to the width of the veins and the thickness of the skin; The form of the phlebotomy needle with which one makes a section is wide, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is fitting for opening closed veins, full, coming from the body, visible, thick, and those which contain  thick blood, turbulent.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this phlebotomist is of lesser width, and more delicate at the extremities.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is fitting for phlebotomy of small veins that contain  subtle yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	## On the Phlebotomy of the Basilica [vein].
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The bazilica, which is a single vein among three veins, the phlebotomy with a knife is a good thing.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from the ailments that are under the throat and the neck, which is next to the chest and the belly; and it is fitting for the phlebotomist to cauterize it, and let him fear what lies under it, because there is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he should make a mistake, and he adds to the phlebotomy a piercing, he will strike that artery, and he will spill the flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is fitting, so that one does not pierce it with a phlebotomy needle: but let him dry it with Anelid.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	That if it does not appear with a manifest appearance, then one should remove it, and turn it to another, or you will seek a branch of it: or you will phlebotomize the place where it is.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	It itself is manifest, and dry it with Anelid phlebotomy, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If, however, you wish to bloodlet him from himself, then it is necessary that you should strike before the stricture of the arm, so that you may touch the place, until you know the place of pulsation.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then mark the spot with a causticum, then the arm, and dry up the vein with a cautery, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And let the percussion not fall away from the space of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, when you tighten the ligament, the swelling in the place that you have marked with the causticum, then that swelling is the swelling of the artery: therefore remove it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	That if you see the blood rising with the bloodletting, like a boy's urine, and it is thin blood, red: then you will know that it is from the blood of the artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore bring your hand near, and place your finger on the space for a long time, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	And if blood is cut off (for it is often cut off) then tighten the arm, and release him: and let the injured be at rest from his movement: and sit on his fear.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And let him not move for a few days, until he is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	But if blood is not cut off, and it overpowers you: and there is no present medicine for you in the moment of your need, then strike an artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For its extremities do contract, and blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take a piece of cork, and find it: take a half, and tighten it on the place of the stricture of the vein going down, with a ligament and powder until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not: then take care of the person with him, remembering the place where the blood was cut off: and cutting off his blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the small wound, and the possibility of a ligament from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On the venesection of the dark-colored blood.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	But the venesection of the dark-colored blood is a procedure that draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower part of the body: therefore, because it is composed of the branch of the Basilica and the branch of theCephalica, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it belongs to the phlebotomist to do this, lest he suffer from phlebotomy, because under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds to the venesection of phlebotomy and finds a nerve, it happens that he falls into a stupor, and his recovery is difficult, and perhaps does not recover completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears often to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	But if it is hidden in some people, and is slender, and does not show itself: then you should place your phlebotomy so that the phlebotomist makes a section with Alnecil, and απομακρύνει τα νεύρα με τη δική σας αντοχή.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	That if the vein is between two nerves, then find a vein in length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the cerebral vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	But the procedure for venesection of the cerebral vein is that it draws blood from the head and contributes to the ailments of the eyes.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And you should use the proper oil in this vein if you want to, so that the phlebotomist pricks it with the phlebotome's olive oil, or with the phlebotome's myrrh: for this is the salvation of all veins, because it is not an arterial vein, nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	But you should be careful with the venesection, so that you only take the head of the laceration and find a more comfortable place: and it does not hurt him if, after the first blow, he does not return to it with venesection from time to time.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	But perhaps he bleeds when he is not venesected at first blow, but it does not hurt him that bleeding from time to time, if it happens in some people.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the utility of phlebotomy and on the precautions to be taken when performing it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy and the complications that may arise from it, which you should consider how to correct.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	First, then, of what you should be aware, that phlebotomy is administered not for the sake of health but to preserve it, and its persistence and caution from the advent of illness.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And so that phlebotomy is performed in one of three positions which a person lies in bed, namely the cephalic, the femoral, and the bazal.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And so that phlebotomy is performed at the beginning of spring on a fasting person, in summer, and in autumn after a feast, when there are signs of fullness.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	And so that phlebotomy is performed on the first or third day after having slept for three hours.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	But phlebotomy which is administered to the sick does not have a determined hour; but when it elicits convenience and necessity towards it, at night, or by day, and at all times, and in all places.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not appropriate that boys should be phlebotomized until they are fourteen years old.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	Nor should a pregnant woman be phlebotomized until the fourth month up to the seventh month.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	Nor should elderly people be phlebotomized who have already passed the age of sixty.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When anyone is to be phlebotomized, it is necessary that he should clean his intestines before phlebotomy with a laxative, if there is much waste retained in them: so that the blood does not attract venereal diseases from the intestines through the main veins.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should a patient who is aching or nauseous from fasting be phlebotomized, nor should those who are drunk have it taken away from them until they have recovered from their intoxication.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor should an invalid with hydrops be phlebotomized.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be repeated again after a fasting fever, and a lack of appetite, and a flow of urine, and an increase in sexual activity, and labor, and exercise, and vigils, and fasting, and all that dissolves virtue from the body or animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider in subtlety of humors before that, if blood is thick with food and drink, and medicines: if possible is him that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then let the bath be introduced, if anything does not prohibit it: or he exercises a little exercise, in order to refine the blood.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place the phlebotomy on his chest in his bosom, about the third day, as we have said: and be careful, that his chest should be drained of that blood that day from all animal bad accidents: such as anger, fear: and all bodily accidents, such as labor, punishment, excesses, and those like them.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And make these things available to him: because the custom of men is that they have always used aromatic substances, and their fragrance, and festivity, and such like, through the quantity of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist sit on a table, that it be higher than the phlebotomy table: then he shall take his arm, and rub it with his own hand twice, or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then let him tie the ligature with the cord, and roll it up once.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the constriction be strict, because constriction is unequal, or by excess in the constriction, then it prohibits the course of blood: or in softening, then also it prohibits the course of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after the constriction, let the phlebotomist rub his hands together skin to skin, until the veins swell, and present themselves to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then let the phlebotomist wipe the phlebotomy with a little oil, old, of his own proper.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then let he put his right index finger of his left hand on the vein at the place where he intends to make a phlebotomy, little: so that the vein does not run away, and the piercing noise is not heard.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	For the veins are like a cord running away when making a phlebotomy: and those are full of blood: and when you put the phlebotomy on them, it is pinched under the phlebotomy, and deceives the phlebotomist, and does not open the vein: and if it opens it, then it is constricted: therefore, in all these things, let the phlebotomist rub himself, and be careful in these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then deposit the phlebotomy.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If then a new wound opens from one vein, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat the other vein beneath that place a little, or above it with haste: if not the place swells up.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	What if it swells up, or if the patient is feeble, then let him be discharged after one or two days: and do not tie a ligature tightly.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	For perhaps the swelling will be drawn in by the heat.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	And do not put him into a bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then repeat the phlebotomy if he likes it.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	What if the opening is small, or blood flows lightly: and be careful not to lose a quantity of blood more than you draw out: then repeat the phlebotomy in the same hole again, and add something to the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do it quickly, before the place swells up: for the place will swell up in many people during a short time.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If then you see that he has already swelled up, then do not repeat the phlebotomy at all, for it does not excuse you with him for anything.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And put something on the spot from a fat oil: for it will ease the course of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And this place is better than his own oil, and other oils better.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And likewise administer the fat oil in all your phlebotomies when you want to stop the course of blood: and they make it with myrrh when put on from one of these spots.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	For blood is thickened and resolved when it is thin.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	What if a great swelling occurs in the place where the phlebotomy has been made, for this often happens, especially when one has not had phlebotomy at that place before, or if a small opening has occurred, then bind it and put over the spot a sponge dipped in warm water and salt, and heat it slightly: and tie it up after an hour: for it is resolved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	It is necessary that you do this after the blood has come out from the wound itself with its own supply, or from another wound.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	Which if it remains in the place for some days of redness or swelling does not harm that; and if there is a wound, put on it some aloe, or dissolved myrrh: or some juice of peppermint, that is, of calamus or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And many times indeed have there occurred injuries and eminences with phlebotomy in the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	So place your hand over it, then if it is soft to the touch when you press it with your hand, then that eminence is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, so that you put on it some of that which we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps it will flow from it blood of an artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a poultice with it where there is a stain so that the place hardens.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then take care of the wound with the rest of the cure, until it heals.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you should give every man blood by the amount of his own virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears from a red color on the blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	For if the blood is black, then let it not come out until it turns red; and likewise if you see it thick: then let it not go out until it thins out; and likewise if it is sharp, then let the sharpness go out from it.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for the one who is full, strong, and resistant to the extraction of blood by a single vein, so that phlebotomy of the green increases, and the phlebothomist stands on the side: but in the weak, stand opposite to it.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he should draw out the wound with a tight hole, and it is better that which is administered in phlebotomy of the green is, so that it is a transverse section, not a cut.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safer from the flow of blood, and from incising a nerve: and it is more praiseworthy, and healthier than phlebotomy by the width and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it is usual to syncopis when phlebotomizing, it is necessary that he eat before phlebotomy a little bread infused with water of granate and muslin: or if he is warmed up, secaniabin; and let him squeeze out blood from the three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if the complexion is frigid, then he should take before phlebotomy a little bread infused in syrup of myrrh, or in syrup of honey perfumed with spices, or in perfumed syrup with fragrant species.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	That if it happens syncopis during phlebotomy, and is the cause of its output of blood much: then it is necessary that he takes in a cup water of meat, and perfumed syrup: and he uses aromatic with algalia, and he spreads his chest with it: and he uses the rest that we have said in the division in the chapter syncopis from the evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	Whoever wants to heal his arm, and let his blood run out: it is necessary for him who whose phlebotomy is for great euacuation, and its power is weak, to let his blood run out little by little through the quantity of power in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	Whoever wants to heal his arm, and let his blood run out second time, and his body is strong: then he should do it after seven hours, or nine from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wants to attract blood from his body to the opposite part of which he leans: it is necessary that he should do it on the second day, or on the third.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In whose body is now much blood warmed up, and it becomes acute, and causes a fever: it is necessary that he should go out of it in a single beat, and extract from it a lot of quantity: and it increases the opening until syncopis happens: after which you have preserved all conditions of phlebotomy: and let you put your hand on his pulse at the course of blood, so that death does not happen at the place of syncopsis.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Therefore, it often happens that the phlebotomist does not know and falls by negligence.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not fitting that when you wish to cut the arm and draw blood in the second place, you draw the blood while the orifice of the vein is already closed, and make the exit of the blood difficult, so that it presses down on itself with a sudden movement, and extends quickly.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For this is an evil thing: let go of it at once until the phlebotomist draws blood in the second place.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Or take away the coziment of the blood which is in the orifice of the vein with the phlebotomist, and put a little dissolved salt in water on it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And put on it some of the tar-salt or green-salt, and put the compress on it slightly, until the blood exits.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	But if the vein is already torn, then let go of it, and do not tie it up, until it cicatrizes.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	That if necessity compels you to draw blood a second time, and there is no excuse, then either phlebotomize the person above that place, or in another arm at another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	But the vein of the arm is phlebotomized in the place of the Musculi, and Basilicae, which are not visible, because it is made up of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of his phlebotomy is such that he puts his own hand into hot water, until it turns red, and the vein appears clearly.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then tie it tightly on top with a little constriction of the middle ligature.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then phlebotomize the second time slowly, not widely and not along its length; and let the opening be broad, and your phlebotomy should be done just above the knuckle, so that it does not hurt as much.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	That if the exit of the blood is prevented, then repeat your hand in hot water, and let the blood run into the water until you satisfy your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	But if you are in summer days, then you are excused from washing your hands in warm water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And indeed a great deal is put forth regarding the flow of blood in hot water during the cold season.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And phlebotomy of this vein is healthier for all veins, since it is not pulsatile and there are no nerves.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	But phlebotomy of the right hand is salutary for people with liver ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that you should wrap the hand with a ligature, or your hand, after having introduced it into warm water, until the vein constricts and clearly feels very sensibly.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then phlebotomize her by passing through.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut her entirely, it will not hurt her at all.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And preserve, do not introduce your hand after phlebotomy.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	For under it are the nerves of the fingers denuded from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then repeat your hand to warm water, and let the blood run in it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not repeat the hand in warm water, the blood will coagulate at the opening of the vein, and the flow will be prevented.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	But when you extract a quantity of blood as required, then put oil and salt on the vein so that it does not harden quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And likewise you should do, as you make with every tight branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	But the procedure of phlebotomy from the left hand is: for it is suited to liver ailments; and likewise do with phlebotomy as you did with the second equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	But the phlebotomy of the saphenous vein is for ailments that are in the lower part of the body, such as liver ailments, and retention of menstruation, and diseases of the kidneys and bladder, and old ulcers of the legs and buttocks, and similar ailments from diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of phlebotomy is such that he should introduce his weak foot into warm water; and let him make friction over it until the veins give off a strong scent, and then bind above the ankle with a ligature.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And indeed the site is at the heel, which appears opposite the thumb: and many branches extend from it on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, let us draw blood from it in a larger branch of its or near the heel in a group of its: for it is better and healthier.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	That if you draw blood from it on the face of the foot, then be careful of the nerves that are under it on the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your phlebotomy where you wish to draw blood from behind, so that you do not want to injure it: and let the phlebotomist be safe.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	But if the flow of blood is prohibited, then turn over his foot into warm water: and let the blood not run into it until it has been emptied.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	That if the phlebotomist has made a mistake in the first cut, then let him keep with the phlebotomy to the upper part somewhat, for the site is healthy, and do not be afraid of injury from it when you draw blood, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And also with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	But the location of the sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the heel from the side of the forest.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the support for the phlebotomy is, to the pain of the ankle, when it is because of warm blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is, that it may enter into a weak bath and quicken: and tighten his leg from the side of the ankle up to the heel with four fingers, for it does not appear unless because of it.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When it does appear, then draw blood from it according to whatever ability you have, or its transmutation: and it is better, or as if you want to injure it, or separate it by a cut.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	For the site of it is healthier, and it itself is hidden in many people greatly.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	That if you do not injure it, and does not appear at all to the sense: then draw blood from one of its branches, and that appears on the back of the foot, and opposite the ear: and be careful of the nerves, and let the blood run in a certain amount as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then cut away tightly, and place the skin over the site of bleeding, and tighten the site.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	For this quickly heals.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	(The text continues with a discussion of ventosisation and its quality of use.)
Caput XCVIII.	TITLE On Ventosation
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Bones are made from horns, and from brass, and from urine.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And Ventosection is done according to two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	When with scarification and drawing of blood, and one is ventilating without scarification.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this Ventosection which is without scarification, is according to two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or indeed it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And the ventilations which are administered with scarification and drawing of blood, are four dozen places in the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	Of which one is Ventosection of the Al-Nocrati, and it is lastly of the head: and Alkhel, and it is middle of the neck: and uentosae Alhagdahim, and they are two laminae of the neck from both sides simultaneously: and uentosae of the mind, and it is under the mandible in the lower mouth: and uentosae of the two spatulas: and uentosae of the tail end: and uentosae of the two fires, and they are middle of the two arms: and uentosae of the two legs: and uentosae of the two shanks.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And indeed the ventilation does not draw blood from you out of small scattered veins in the flesh, and for this reason the power does not come out of them, such as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	And it is not necessary that ventilation is administered with fire or without fire in any sickness which is caused by fullness, until the whole body is emptied.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	That if necessity calls for ventilation from sickness, or because of custom, we shall administer it at any hour at the beginning of the month, at the end of it, and at its middle, and at whatever time it shall be.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	That is, for a man is one who, when he is multiplied with blood, until he needs extraction by ventilation, finds in his head a great swelling, and swells.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And of them is one who finds fullness and redness on his face, on his head, and on his neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And from these comes the itch in his face and forehead, and darkness and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And from these comes the scalp, which is full of hair.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And from these comes the riser, who laughs a lot.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And from these comes one who finds the taste of blood in his mouth, or spits it out with his tongue, and swallows it.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And from these comes the one whose sleep is disturbed.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	Who sees blood and red color in his dream, and those who have been killed, and plagues, and things like that.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When we then see anything from them, and especially if it is on the third day of the month: then let us make the scalp appear, after having passed two or three hours since morning.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	But the sign of the scalp is this: for it brings a burden to the head and that it flows down to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it should be after the evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this is called a scalp because it has been pulled by phlebotomy of the head.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it should not be worn by one who has a cold complexion, or one who is hoarse.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it does great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And for this reason it should not be worn by the elderly, and not by those who have cold ailments in their heads.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	But he who is diligent with it, falls into oblivion.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for this reason you should order the scalper to put his hand with the scalp when it is somewhat lower down, fearing the generation of oblivion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosation or alkohl is the place of phlebotomy of the brown vein, and phlebotomies of the basilic veins, and for this reason it brings sneezing, constriction of the throat, fissures in the instrument of constriction, coughing, and filling up.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it should be driven out by alkohl thoroughly, for if it is put below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	To draw out wind and the agues, observe the pains of the head, and eyes, and headache, and perforations, and pain in the roots of the teeth; and it is the place for phlebotomy at the Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And you should prevent the ventosator from holding his hand too soon with the scarification, lest he hit an artery and cause a rush of blood to flow.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	But if it is under the chin, observe the wines in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and similar ailments that are in the mouth; and it is the place for phlebotomy elsewhere, which are in the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	But if it is with the spatula, observe toward the alchafach (a type of wound), which is made by retraction and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	However, if it is in the internal parts of the two folds (of the skin), observe the phlebotomy of the three veins, Basilica, Fusca, and Cephalica: for they draw blood from all the small veins that are in the flesh; and these small veins draw the blood from other larger veins until they reach the three veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And you should prevent the ventosator from proceeding too far with the scarification: for the place is bare of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	But if it is a ventosation that vents on the alchaus, observe the hemorrhoids of the anus, and ulcers lower down.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And you should prevent the ventosator from making it too large, and from making it of iron: for the place does not tolerate strong suction, and perhaps the fine ones break; and it is scarified with a large scarification.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	But if the winds are in the crura, they diminish little by little: for they draw blood from all the body, and cause the old pains in the kidneys, and membranes, and bladder; they provoke menses, and cause bowel movements, and vomiting, and it is the place for phlebotomy between two saphenous veins, and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	Indeed, the body grows weak, and it often causes syncope in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the pressure of the two krur winds is close to the pressure of the two krur winds.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the winds is that you place the wind in the first place with a moderate pressure and do not prolong the position of the winds but put them quickly and move them quickly so that they bring the humors to the appropriate place: and do not cease to repeat this and continue, until it seems to you that the place has already become red and swollen, and it appears red blood: then therefore you make a incision, and repeat the suction slowly.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider in the arrangement of the bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For whoever among people has tender flesh and rare pores, it is necessary that he make the incision once, not more: so that the site does not ulcerate.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And order the winds to amplify the incision and make it deep: and moderate the suction in ease, and speed, and smooth motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is a lot of blood, then you should make the incision twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	Indeed, in the first place the way of the subtile blood is opened and made to flow: and in the second place, in the perscrutation of the exquisite extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If, however, the blood is very foul, then let the incision be made in the fourth place: so that the last result is obtained.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And to the last, when we want to extract blood slowly, a little or not at all, one incision is enough for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we want to extract a lot of blood, let us make multiple incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick: then it is necessary that the incision be deep: and the equal term in the incision is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What is this that needs to be administered from oils when positioning the winds, and what does the wind-shift cause?
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that, indeed, whose skin is thick, tough, dark, and whose pores are tight, it is necessary that the places of Ventration be anointed with open, soothing, and resolute oils: if in season of summer, as is the oil of many, or the oil of black seed, or the oil of sweet almonds, or the oil of cucumber seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in season of winter, then the oil of narcissus, or the oil of lily, or the oil of chamomile, or the oil of sassafras: and to these similar ones.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	And if there is a superfluity of heat, then let it be the oil of amber, or the oil of myrrh, or the oil of albus, or the oil of annatto: and to these similar ones.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	And if it is windy and has wide pores and tender flesh, then it should be prevented from the oil, and these places of Ventration should be washed after wind with rose water, or cold water, or spring water, or cucumber water, or portulaca water: and similar to these.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	But that which has much blood of humidity should wash the windy places with vinegar, or with myrtle water, and sumach: and similar to these.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	Whose superfluities are thick, should wash their windy places with old wine, or with samsou water, or with the decoction of althaa, or chamomile: and similar to these.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it should be prevented that wind should be taken in a bath, or in a shower-room; and moreover it should be administered after leaving the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not fit that anyone should sleep after wind.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is that which is to be observed that Ventration and Phlebotomy may be made before wind?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after that, you should observe in the first place: then if Ventration or Phlebotomy are on the choler, and their sharpness and inflammation are directed to his blood: then it should take something cooling, such as granatum mus; also lettuce with vinegar and radish, and marjoram: and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And put his food-vessels near him, and meat which he relished, and cooked foods with herbs: and things similar to these.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And if his complexions are cold, he should take in drink syrup of honey, or of almond-milk, or alsican made from seeds: and drink a wine with a strong odor, which is between new and old: and let him be commanded to eat little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And put his food-vessels near him, and meats of birds: and let him eat doves, that is, young pigeons: and let him eat cooked pigeons.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drink of his diurnal rest and bloodletting be more than the food: and it is necessary that a remedy be given in drink to some men at certain hours with turpentine-alcohol, or medicine made from musk, that is, muscat, or alselith before bloodletting: and after bloodletting, or before: so that the principal members may be strengthened, and the blood subtilized.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it is not necessary that they drink it in a warm drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	On Bloodletting without Scarring.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	And the Bloodlettings which are without Scarring, are those laid on the liver, and the spleen, and the stomach, and over the belly, and places of the testicles, and the pixis of the anus: for these members do not suffer from scarring on their own.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And is not sought through them, unless by an attack from a member of blood to a member: such as we lay a Bloodletting on the breasts in the sickness of a flux of blood to the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them, that we may cure a member's Cold Bloodletting which has been irritated: such as we lay a Bloodletting on the belly, and the umbilical region.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it rarefies the member, and warms it, and takes away pain because it resolves the Bloodletting.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	Also is laid on the kidneys, when there happens to be a deposit of bile, or a stone.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	For with its strength it either opens the wound or removes the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And likewise when laid upon to heal, and the spleen to be handled within them both.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these Wind-afflicted are to be dealt with by a sharp cut only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And when they are treated with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And when they are treated with warm water in pleural diseases: and that is, so that the Wind be filled, and be great, only warm water, or water in which have been boiled herbs fitting for the purpose.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	The form of the Wind-afflicted when treated with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.
